# Introduction

This document outlines the basic guidelines on writing LLM-friendly documents, and provides templates on various Knowledge Base document types.

# LLM-Friendly Document Guidelines

Best Practices for LLM-Friendly Documents

- Consistent Structure: Use standardized headings and sections across all documents.
- Clear Metadata: Ensure all documents contain the basic metadata and tags to aid in classification and retrieval.
- Modularity: Design each section to be self-contained for effective vectorization.
- Conciseness: Write in clear, succinct language to optimize text embedding quality.
- Inter-document Linking: Consider including cross-references to related documents when applicable.
- Easy to parse format: Use .md (markdown) format for writing text-based documents as markdown is easy to parse and process, representing the consistent structure of the documents

# Template in .md (markdown) format

> Info: Visit knowledge-base-templates to access up-to-date templates.

metadata.title: Template / Guidelines on Writing LLM-Friendly Knowledge Base Documents

ate in .md (markdown) format

> Info: Visit knowledge-base-templates to access up-to-date templates.

## Key Term Calculation Definition Template

```
#### Reorder Point

What is Reorder Point: Describe the definition here
The estimated inventory level to hold in order to cover the demand
(incorporating the demand volatility) within the cover period.
How is this Reorder Point Calculated?: ...
Why Reorder Point is used?: ...
```

## For a Knowledge Base on a Calculation Flow

```
# Metadata

- Domain: Replenishment/Allocation/Forecasting
- Topic: Topic Name i.e. Target Calculation
- Tags: (Basic tags for indexing, e.g., “replenishment”, “inventory”, “analytics”)

# Overview

A succinct summary of the document’s purpose and scope.

Objective: Describe the problem or process addressed.
Scope: Define the replenishment or retail analytics aspects covered.

# Background

Set the stage by outlining the background information on the topic the document
is about.

## Terminology & Definitions

The estimated inventory level to hold in order to cover the demand
(incorporating the demand volatility) within the cover period.
How is Reorder Point Calculated?: ...

# Core Content
This section details the methodologies, processes, calculation logics,
and technical or analytical insights.
```

content:
Welcome to the Gensight contributing guide!

This document is designed to help you get started with contributing to our project.

Whether you’re fixing bugs, adding new features, improving documentation, or writing tests;

this guide outlines the necessary steps, coding standards, and best practices for working with our codebase. Follow the instructions to set up your development environment, adhere to our code style and commit conventions, and understand our project structure to ensure a smooth and efficient contribution process.

## Development Setup

Before moving forward, please make sure that you have followed the

[Setting up a Local Development Environment](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/DEV/pages/3494969347/Installation+of+PySpark+and+Development+Setup#Setting-up-a-Local-Development-Environment) guide.

### Prerequisites

- Python 3.10 or higher
- Make
- Docker
- Git

### Installation

1. Clone the repository:

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
equisites

- Python 3.10 or higher
- Make
- Docker
- Git

### Installation

1. Clone the repository:

Execute following command in terminal / command prompt / powershell:

```
git  clone  https://github.com/inventanalytics/gensight.git
cd  gensight
```

If you haven’t set up your Git configuration yet, please configure it as:

```
git  config  user.name  "Full Name"
git  config  user.email  "full.name@inventanalytics.com"
```

1. Create a virtual environment using uv (which is a python package manager; see uv documentation for details):

If you don’t have uv installed, first install uv;

```
pip  install  uv
```

If you’re using Windows,

execute the following command in git bash / command prompt / powershell:

```
uv  venv
.\.venv\Scripts\activate
```

If you’re using Linux or Unix based system, or WSL2 on Windows,

execute the following command in terminal:

```
uv  venv
source  .venv/bin/activate
```

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
on Windows,

execute the following command in terminal:

```
uv  venv
source  .venv/bin/activate
```

The first line `uv venv` creates a virtual environment, ant the second line activates the virtual environment

1. Install gensight library dependencies (requires VPN)

```
uv pip install -e ".[dev,vectordb,ingestion,aws,azure,qa_solution,hf,fastapi_dev]"  \
--index-url https://pypi.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/
```

1. Install gensight API dependencies

```
uv pip install -r api/gensight_backend_app/requirements.txt \
--index-url https://pypi.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/
```

### Setting the PYTHONPATH Environment Variable

Certain parts of the application (for example, the `tests` and `api` folders) are not installed as an installable package by our design.

To ensure these modules can be located and executed correctly, you should add their paths to the `PYTHONPATH` environment variable.

#### Linux/macOS (Bash, Zsh, etc.)

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
should add their paths to the `PYTHONPATH` environment variable.

#### Linux/macOS (Bash, Zsh, etc.)

1. Open your shell configuration file in a text editor (e.g., ~/.bashrc for Bash or ~/.zshrc for Zsh).

Examples are given using `nano`, but you can also use `vim` based on your preference.

```
nano ~/.bashrc  # or nano ~/.zshrc for Zsh
```

1. Add the following line at the end of the file, replacing the paths with the actual paths to your gensight root folder

```
export PYTHONPATH="$PYTHONPATH:/path/to/gensight"
```

1. Save the file and then reload your configuration

```
source ~/.bashrc  # or source ~/.zshrc for Zsh
```

#### Windows

In Windows, you can either use System Environment Variables, or set them through

the PowerShell profile.

##### System Environment Variables

Open the Start menu and search for “Environment Variables” or “Edit the system environment variables.”

In the System Properties window, click on the Environment Variables button.

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
environment variables.”

In the System Properties window, click on the Environment Variables button.

Under System variables (or User variables if you prefer), click New if PYTHONPATH does not already exist. If it does exist, select it and click Edit.

Set the variable value by adding the path to your gensight root folder:

```
C:\path\to\gensight
```

##### PowerShell Profile

Alternatively, if you prefer using PowerShell and want the variable set automatically each time you open a PowerShell session, you can modify your PowerShell profile:

1. Open your PowerShell profile in a text editor. You can find the profile path by running

```
$PROFILE
```

1. Add the following line to your profile, replacing the correct gensight root folder path:

```
$env:PYTHONPATH = "$env:PYTHONPATH;C:\path\to\gensight"
```

1. Save the file and restart PowerShell.

Reference Guides

- Python Docs on PYTHONPATH

## Project Structure

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
he file and restart PowerShell.

Reference Guides

- Python Docs on PYTHONPATH

## Project Structure

```
gensight/
├── .cicd # CI/CD pipeline for gensight library builds and API deployment
├── api/ # FastAPI application for gensight backend APIs
├── gensight/ # Entrypoint for gensight library
│ ├── config/ # Config files
│ ├── core/ # Core library functionality
│ ├── llm_solutions/ # Implementations for LLM solutions
│ ├── pipeline_steps/ # Batch ingestion pipeline steps
│ ├── pipelines/ # Ingestion pipeline definitions and pipeline classes
├── tests/ # Test suite
```

## Development Workflow

Before making any changes, you should create a new local branch. In order to create a branch, first create a Jira issue. All branches should be named with a Jira issue including bug fixes and documentation.

### Branch Naming Convention

Always include the JIRA ticket name in the branch names.

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
cumentation.

### Branch Naming Convention

Always include the JIRA ticket name in the branch names.

- Feature: <JIRA-TASK-ID>-feature-definition
- Bug fix: <JIRA-TASK-ID>-fix-xxx
- Documentation: <JIRA-TASK-ID>-docs-xxx
- Refactor: <JIRA-TASK-ID>-refactor-xxx

### Creating a new branch

Use the following command to create a new git branch:

```
git switch -c your-branch-name
```

### Commit Messages

Use [Conventional Commits](https://www.conventionalcommits.org/en/v1.0.0/) templates

and always include JIRA task ID in the beginning

```
<JIRA-TASK-ID>: type(scope): description

[optional body]
[optional footer]
```

Types: feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, test, chore

### Pull Request Guidelines

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
ional footer]
```

Types: feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, test, chore

### Pull Request Guidelines

- Creating a Pull Request: Once your changes are committed to your branch, submit a pull request (PR) to the main repository. Include a brief description of the changes and reference the associated JIRA ticket.
- Review Process: Your PR will be reviewed by at least one team member. Please be prepared to address feedback or requested changes.
- Merging: Once approved and all tests pass, your PR will be merged. Make sure to update your branch with the latest changes before merging.

## Code Style

### Python Standards

- Follow PEP-8
- Maximum line length: 79 characters
- Use type hints for function arguments and return values
- Format code with ruff
- Use absolute imports
- Remove unused imports
- Use f-strings instead of .format() or % formatting

### Docstring Format

Use ReST format for docstrings. See the example below

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
ormat() or % formatting

### Docstring Format

Use ReST format for docstrings. See the example below

```
def function_name(param1: str, param2: int) -> bool:
    """
    Short description.

    Detailed description of the function.

    :param param1: Parameter description
    :type param1: str
    :raises: ValueError: specify exceptions if any
    :return: return value description
    :rtype: bool
    """
```

### Linting and Code Quality Tools

We use several tools to maintain code quality:

#### Ruff

Our primary linter is Ruff, which handles both linting and formatting:

Run Ruff linter

```
ruff check .
```

Run Ruff formatter

```
ruff format .
```

#### Pre-commit Hooks

Git hooks are custom scripts executed by git before or after some certain actions (i.e. commit, push, merge). Pre-commit hooks are triggered to execute a script before committing.

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
ns (i.e. commit, push, merge). Pre-commit hooks are triggered to execute a script before committing.

Gensight project contains a pre-commit hook to linting staged files before commit is completed to prevent potential lint errors before CI/CD step. We recommend using a pre-commit hook to automatize linting process in local development environment.

[pre-commit](https://pre-commit.com/) tool is used to install and use pre-commit hooks easily. Once you have installed [pre-commit](https://pre-commit.com/), you can activate our pre-commit hook by running Pre-commit hooks are configured to run automatically before each commit.

If you would like to run manually, you can use the commands below:

Install pre-commit hooks

```
pre-commit install
```

Run hooks for staged changes in git

```
pre-commit
```

Run hooks for manually

```
pre-commit run --all-files
```

#### Linter Configuration

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
re-commit
```

Run hooks for manually

```
pre-commit run --all-files
```

#### Linter Configuration

- Ruff settings are in pyproject.toml
- Pre-commit configuration is in .pre-commit-config.yaml
- Maximum line length is set to 79 characters
- Full PEP-8 compliance is enforced

#### IDE Integration

For Visual Studio Code users:

1. Install the Ruff extension
2. Enable format on save in .vscode/settings.json:

```
{
  "[python]": {
    "editor.formatOnSave": true,
    "editor.defaultFormatter": "charliermarsh.ruff"
  }
}
```

## Testing

Tests are organized to mirror the application structure. When adding new tests, follow the existing patterns.

### Running Tests

It is suggested to use your IDE test explorers for exploring and running tests.

Verify that you have the test set-up correctly by running the test collection.

Test collection does not runs the test, but discovers the test files.

```
pytest  --collect-only
```

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
est collection does not runs the test, but discovers the test files.

```
pytest  --collect-only
```

Additionally, you can use the commands below for running tests.

Run all tests

```
make  test
```

Run a single test file

```
pytest  tests/path/to/test.py
```

### Writing Tests

Use python unittest.TestCase format, and use derived test classes.

Make sure you start test methods with “test_” prefix.

```
from unittest import TestCase

class  TestClass(TestCase):
    def test_xxx(self):
    ...

    self.assertEqual(a,b)
```

## Running the API

Use the following command to run Gensight Backend API in the development mode.

```
fastapi run api/gensight_backend_app/main.py
```

Visit `http://127.0.0.1:8000/docs` for opening the Swagger UI.

### Setting up AWS Credentials

Please refer to [Aws Cli and S3 Browser Installation]

### Set environment variables for local vector database

If you’re using the API locally and want to connect to a local LanceDB vector database,

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

content:
or database

If you’re using the API locally and want to connect to a local LanceDB vector database,

you can set “GENSIGHT_API_VECTOR_STORE_CONN_STRING” environment variable to

locate your vector database folder.

You can either modify the default value of `VECTOR_STORE_CONN_STRING`

in `gensight.api.gensight_backend_app.core.config.Settings`

(Make sure you are not committing this change), or run the API as;

```
GENSIGHT_API_VECTOR_STORE_CONN_STRING=/path/to/your/vectordb fastapi dev api/gensight_backend_app/main.py
```

metadata.title: Contributing - Setting up Local Development Environment

# Introduction

This document presents our vision and strategy for integrating AI capabilities into our platform. We have evaluated multiple alternatives across several key areas: model inference deployment, data storage mechanisms, network topology, security measures, tenancy arrangements, backend services, and monitoring/logging solutions. Our goal is to build a robust, scalable, and secure AI integration framework that meets rigorous industry standards and protects client data throughout its lifecycle.

Our approach covers:

rigorous industry standards and protects client data throughout its lifecycle.

Our approach covers:

- Model Inference Deployment: Exploring both third-party APIs and self-hosted options, including fine-tuning capabilities.
- Data Storage: Managing analytical data, and both metadata and vector representations, with alternatives for self-hosted or third-party solutions.
- Network Topology: Configuring access—from public endpoints to completely private network environments.
- Security: Enforcing strict input/output guardrails, adherence to compliance and certifications, and robust access controls.
- Tenancy: Ensuring multi-tenant data isolation so that each client's data remains completely separated.
- AI Backend Services: Choosing suitable compute platforms such as container orchestration or serverless functions.
- Monitoring, Logging, and Feedback: Building observability into our AI systems for performance, error detection, and continual improvement.

lding observability into our AI systems for performance, error detection, and continual improvement.

# Model Inference Deployment Models

Choosing the appropriate model inference strategy is critical to achieving the right balance of integration ease, security, privacy, and data governance. We evaluate four main deployment alternatives. We are currently using Third-Party AI Service Provider Integrations, however, other options that include:

- Self-Hosted Open-Source Models
- Fine-Tuned Third-Party Models
- Fine-Tuned Self-Hosted Models

| Deployment Model | Integration Capabilities | Security | Privacy | Data Governance |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Third-Party AI Service | Quick API-based integration; scalable and managed | Vendor-controlled security; multi-tenant risk mitigated by contracts | Data not used for training by default; risk managed by contractual Data Processing Agreement (DPA) s | Centralized, subject to vendor compliance and DPAs |
| Self-Hosted Open-Source Models | Highly customizable; requires in-house expertise | Full, internal end-to-end security | Complete data control, no external exposure.Data remains entirely in-house; best privacy | Fully managed internally; high flexibility |
| Fine-Tuned Third-Party Models | Enhanced domain-specific performance; managed fine-tuning | Leverages vendor’s secure fine-tuning processes | Fine-tuning data subject to vendor policies; opt-in usage | Governed by vendor agreements and compliance audits |

ata subject to vendor policies; opt-in usage | Governed by vendor agreements and compliance audits |
| Fine-Tuned Self-Hosted Models | Maximum customization; best for niche use cases | Full, internal end-to-end security | Data remains entirely in-house; best privacy | Fully managed internally; high flexibility |

## Third-Party AI Service Provider Integrations

Examples:OpenAI, Azure OpenAI, Amazon Bedrock, Anthropic, Google Gemini, OpenRouter, etc.

We are currently using public OpenAI services, and considering using Azure OpenAIprivate deployments.

Integration Capabilities:

- Ease of Integration: These services are delivered via standardized cloud APIs, enabling rapid integration with existing applications using RESTful interfaces or SDKs.
- Scalability: Managed services offer auto-scaling, reducing the need for infrastructure management.

Security:

ty: Managed services offer auto-scaling, reducing the need for infrastructure management.

Security:

- Vendor-Controlled Security: Providers adhere to stringent security standards (e.g., SOC 2, ISO 27001, GDPR, HIPAA, FedRAMP) and use enterprise-grade encryption (TLS for transit, AES-256 for storage).
- Multi-Tenant Considerations: While services typically share hardware resources, robust logical isolation and contractual assurances safeguard against cross-customer data exposure.

Privacy:

- Data Usage Policies:By default, customer data (inputs and outputs) is not used for training base models unless explicitly opted in (e.g., OpenAI’s opt-in policy for model improvement).Providers like Azure OpenAI guarantee that data remains isolated and is never used for training.
- Data Residency: Some providers offer limited control over data residency, which may be important for regulatory compliance.

Data Governance:

ted control over data residency, which may be important for regulatory compliance.

Data Governance:

- Contractual Oversight: Vendors typically provide Data Processing Agreements (DPAs) that specify data ownership, retention, and handling practices.
- Compliance Audits: Frequent external audits ensure adherence to industry standards and legal regulations.
- Centralized Management: Data is managed on secured cloud environments but may require careful review to align with internal governance policies.

## Self-Hosted Open-Source Models

Examples: Deploying models such as LLaMa, DeepSeek within a self-managed environment (on-premises or in a self-managed cloud).

Integration Capabilities:

- Customizability: Complete control over deployment architecture and integration, enabling tailored solutions to specific business requirements.
- Development Overhead: Requires in-house expertise to integrate, optimize, and continuously maintain the model infrastructure.

Security:

use expertise to integrate, optimize, and continuously maintain the model infrastructure.

Security:

- Full Control: As the entire stack is managed in-house, security measures (firewalls, encryption, network segmentation) can be customized and audited internally.
- Responsibility: The security and maintenance burden lies entirely with our team, necessitating robust internal DevOps and cybersecurity practices.

Privacy:

- Data Ownership: All data remains within our environment, ensuring that sensitive proprietary data is not exposed to external vendors.
- Isolation: No third-party involvement minimizes risks associated with multi-tenancy or data leakage.

Data Governance:

- Internal Management: Allows full adherence to our organization’s data governance policies, from access controls to retention schedules.
- Flexibility: You can implement tailored logging, monitoring, and auditing practices, but it demands continuous oversight and resource allocation.

ng, monitoring, and auditing practices, but it demands continuous oversight and resource allocation.

## Fine-Tuned Third-Party Models

Utilizing a vendor’s base model and augmenting it through fine-tuning with proprietary data, typically via the provider’s secure platforms.

Integration Capabilities:

- Enhanced Performance: Fine-tuning enables the model to specialize in our Retail domain, delivering improved accuracy and relevance.
- Managed Process: The fine-tuning process is often supported by vendor tools, enabling integration without significant infrastructure modifications.

Security:

- WE NEED A DETAILED SECURITY INVESTIGATION!
- Vendor Security Adherence: Fine-tuning happens on the vendor’s secure and audited infrastructure, which adheres to established security standards.
- Data Segregation: Contracts typically ensure that our data used for fine-tuning is segregated from other customer data.

Privacy:

ypically ensure that our data used for fine-tuning is segregated from other customer data.

Privacy:

- Limited Control: Although the service is enhanced for our use, the fine-tuning process occurs on vendor infrastructure. Data used remains under strict controls but is subject to the vendor’s policies.
- Opt-In Policies: Ensure that the vendor’s policies explicitly state that training data is not used to update base models without our explicit consent.

Data Governance:

- Vendor Agreements: Detailed contractual agreements define how our data is handled, stored, and deleted after fine-tuning.
- Regulatory Compliance: Providers offer compliance guarantees (e.g., GDPR, SOC 2) that cover both the base model and the fine-tuning process.

## Fine-Tuned Self-Hosted Models

# Data Storage

Effective data management is critical for achieving high performance and ensuring data security and isolation. Our data storage strategy covers the following types:

## Analytical Data Storage

Purpose: Storing and processing analytical data that drives insights and reporting.

Technologies:

- BigQuery: For high-volume, analytics-driven workloads, configured to support isolated data instances per client.
- PostgreSQL: For smaller analytical datasets where custom queries and direct access are required, with per-client isolated instances.

Considerations:

- Ensuring that analytical data is isolated for each client.
- Balancing performance and data residency requirements, especially for large-scale query operations.

## Vector Database

Purpose: Storing vector embeddings along with essential descriptive data required for semantic search.

Alternatives:

vector embeddings along with essential descriptive data required for semantic search.

Alternatives:

- Self-Hosted Solutions:Self-hosted LanceDB on Client Object Storages (High Security, High Latency)Self-hosted LanceDB on Cloud File Systems (i.e. EFS) with a single mount (Requires Data Sync operations, no data isolation, lower latency)Self-hosted LanceDB on Cloud File Systems (i.e. EFS) with multiple access points (Requires Data Sync operations, data isolation, lower latency)
- Third-Party Integrations: Managed vector database services available in the cloud.

Considerations:

- Data isolation (prevent cross-client leakage).
- Trade-offs between latency and dedicated storage.
- End-to-end encryption and regular audits to ensure data integrity.

# Network Topology

Our network design balances accessibility with the highest security. We consider three main configurations:

## Public Access

es accessibility with the highest security. We consider three main configurations:

## Public Access

- Description: Services are accessible via the public internet.
- Use Cases: Globally accessible services with robust encryption (HTTPS) and strong authentication.
- Considerations: Requires stringent security measures to mitigate public exposure risks.

## Private Access (Internet-Enabled)

- Description: Services operate in a private network environment but maintain controlled internet access (e.g., for calling third-party APIs).
- Use Cases: Hybrid scenarios requiring external communication while preserving internal control.
- Considerations: Use of VPNs, secure gateways, and controlled outbound connections.

## Private Access (Isolated)

ns: Use of VPNs, secure gateways, and controlled outbound connections.

## Private Access (Isolated)

- Description: Services are hosted in entirely isolated networks with no direct public internet exposure.
- Use Cases: Highly sensitive operations demanding maximum data isolation.
- Considerations: Utilizing private endpoints, isolated Virtual Private Clouds (VPCs)/VNets, and secure internal communication protocols.

# Tenancy

## Multi-Tenant Data Isolation

Our architecture supports a multi-tenant model where each client's data should be logically isolated, even in shared environments.

Implementation:

- Using dedicated database schemas, storage containers, and isolated service instances.
- Strict access controls and network segmentation ensure that each client’s data is handled separately.

We should ensure data confidentiality and integrity, ensuring that no client data is inadvertently exposed or shared across tenants.

# Introduction

Protecting the proprietary and sensitive commercial data of our clients is critical. This document describes our security practices and privacy measures when integrating advanced AI services, such as Large Language Models (LLMs) from different providers including OpenAI and Microsoft Azure, as well as our chosen vector database providers, ensuring confidentiality, security, and integrity.

# Glossary

AI Service Provider: Companies providing cloud-based or managed AI services (e.g., OpenAI, Microsoft Azure OpenAI, Anthropic) used by applications for inference tasks.

Third-party AI Integrations: Utilizing AI models hosted and managed by external AI providers through secure APIs.

Large Language Model (LLM): An advanced AI model trained on vast textual datasets, capable of generating human-like text, understanding context, and performing natural language tasks.

capable of generating human-like text, understanding context, and performing natural language tasks.

Inference: The process of applying a trained AI model to new inputs (e.g., queries, images) to generate predictions or responses.

Self-hosted Models: AI models deployed and managed within our own or client-controlled infrastructure, ensuring full data residency and security control.

Fine-tuning: A technique for adapting general pre-trained AI models to perform better on specific tasks by further training them on specialized datasets.

Vector Representations (Embeddings): Numeric representations of data (text, images, etc.) used to perform semantic searches and similarity analysis, enabling effective retrieval and analysis of unstructured data.

Virtual Private Cloud (VPC): A secure, isolated cloud environment that allows organizations to control access to resources, communications, and data flows within a private network, separate from the public internet.

sources, communications, and data flows within a private network, separate from the public internet.

Data Retention: Policies and practices defining how long data is stored after processing. Usually temporary, retention supports troubleshooting, compliance, and monitoring.

Zero Data Retention (ZDR): An optional enhanced security measure where no client data is retained after processing, even temporarily. Data is immediately deleted once the task is complete.

Encryption at Rest (AES-256): Securing data stored on disk or storage systems using the Advanced Encryption Standard with a 256-bit encryption key, widely recognized as secure.

Encryption in Transit (TLS 1.2+): The process of securing data transmitted over networks (e.g., internet) using Transport Layer Security (TLS), version 1.2 or later, to prevent unauthorized interception or tampering.

# Deployment Modes

Our AI infrastructure supports both self-hosted models, deployed within our single-tenant architecture for applications trained by [http://invent.ai](http://invent.ai)  and specialized for our clients, and integrations with third-party AI services, which we utilize for leveraging foundational models and inference.

In self-hosted AI model deployments, AI models are trained and hosted entirely within our secure, private infrastructure. These models are specifically customized and optimized based on proprietary client datasets, ensuring complete alignment with clients’ needs.

# Third-Party AI Integrations

## Data Security and Compliance Standards

We are working with trusted global AI service providers that adhere to stringent security and compliance standards. Here are some of our AI providers and their security and compliance standards:

compliance standards. Here are some of our AI providers and their security and compliance standards:

- OpenAI: Certified with SOC 2 Type II, GDPR-compliant, and offers contractual Data Processing Agreements (DPA). Data encryption at rest (AES-256) and in transit (TLS 1.2+)
- Microsoft Azure OpenAI Service: Includes comprehensive security certifications, such as SOC 2, ISO 27001, GDPR, HIPAA, FedRAMP High, and FIPS 140-2. Data encryption at rest (AES-256) and in transit (TLS 1.2+)

## Security of Data During Third-party AI Service Integrations

Ensuring the secure handling of data during integration with third-party AI services (e.g., OpenAI, Azure OpenAI) is a core part of our infrastructure strategy. We follow strict security controls to maintain data security, privacy, and confidentiality at every step of AI data processing, clearly defined below.

### Data Retention and Privacy

ntiality at every step of AI data processing, clearly defined below.

### Data Retention and Privacy

- Temporary Retention: By default, third-party AI service providers securely retain inputs and responses for up to 30 days. This temporary retention is solely for abuse monitoring or troubleshooting purposes. User inputs are never used for training purposes. Data retained temporarily is encrypted using AES-256 (at rest), with strict access controls and auditing in place.
- Zero Data Retention (ZDR) Option: Clients with higher sensitivity can request special agreements to disable even this short-term retention entirely, ensuring that no client data is stored beyond immediate processing. Under the ZDR policy, data is immediately and permanently deleted after real-time processing, with no temporary storage or retention occurring at the provider's infrastructure.

### Use of Data for Model Training

OpenAI:

r retention occurring at the provider's infrastructure.

### Use of Data for Model Training

OpenAI:

- Data sent through OpenAI's API or enterprise-grade integrations is not used to train or improve OpenAI’s base models.
- Contractual Data Processing Agreements (DPAs) explicitly state these conditions to ensure compliance.

Azure OpenAI Service:

- Data sent through Azure OpenAI Service is never used for training or improving Microsoft’s models.
- All AI inputs (text, images, or any other data types) remain isolated within a dedicated Azure instance, ensuring complete confidentiality.

### Secure Submission of Images

thin a dedicated Azure instance, ensuring complete confidentiality.

### Secure Submission of Images

Images submitted through third-party AI services are never used to train or enhance the provider's AI models. Currently, third-party AI services do not support Zero Data Retention (ZDR) for image data inputs, solely for abuse monitoring and troubleshooting. Images are securely retained for the standard 30-day period strictly for troubleshooting and security purposes, after which they are permanently deleted.

When sharing proprietary image data (e.g., product images), image data can be securely transmitted using:

sharing proprietary image data (e.g., product images), image data can be securely transmitted using:

- Public URLs: Secure HTTPS endpoints publicly accessible, protected via secure channels (TLS encryption).
- Private URLs: Temporarily generated, pre-signed URLs that expire after a defined, short duration, ensuring minimal exposure.
- Direct Uploads (Base64 Encoded Blobs): Directly embedded images as byte representations in encrypted API requests, ensuring end-to-end data security in transit.

## Data Security and Isolation

We employ comprehensive approaches to ensure robust security and strict data isolation for all client data, including vector representations (embeddings), and analytical datasets. Our strategy combines logical isolation methods, dedicated storage solutions, and stringent access controls to prevent any unauthorized or unintended access.

### Data Types and Storage Solutions

Our infrastructure supports secure storage and processing of different data types:

torage Solutions

Our infrastructure supports secure storage and processing of different data types:

Vector Data (Embeddings):

- Stored in specialized vector databases.
- Each client's vector data is logically isolated ensuring no possibility of cross-client data leakage.

Analytical Data:

- Stored in secure and isolated client-specific instances using enterprise-grade data solutions (e.g., PostgreSQL).
- Each client's analytical data is isolated physically and logically.

## Network Security

Our AI services operate within a secure and isolated Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) infrastructure hosted on AWS. This VPC architecture is integrated closely with our core web applications and adheres to strict network access and control policies.

### Access Controls and Isolation:

Inbound Traffic:

to strict network access and control policies.

### Access Controls and Isolation:

Inbound Traffic:

- Access to AI services is strictly controlled and available only through internal private network connections within our secure VPC.
- Direct public inbound access to AI services is not permitted.

Outbound Traffic:

- Our AI services have strictly controlled outbound access to the public internet, which is explicitly limited to communication with approved third-party AI providers (e.g., OpenAI or Azure OpenAI APIs) over encrypted HTTPS channels (TLS 1.2+).
- No general internet access is permitted from these services. All external connectivity undergoes regular auditing and strict firewall enforcement, ensuring communication remains secure and monitored.

### Third-party Integration Security:

rcement, ensuring communication remains secure and monitored.

### Third-party Integration Security:

- Communication with third-party AI services is always conducted via secure, authenticated, and encrypted protocols (HTTPS/TLS).
- Any outbound integration endpoints are pre-approved, explicitly defined, and continuously monitored for suspicious or unauthorized activities.
- Data sent to third-party services for inference is transmitted using secure and authenticated channels only.

## Public vs. Private Deployments (OpenAI vs. Azure OpenAI)

Our third-party AI service providers can provide publicly accessible third-party AI services that adhere to industry security standards with access control, or offer private deployment strategies where the data never leaves a private virtual network.

Public Deployment (e.g., OpenAI Public APIs):

here the data never leaves a private virtual network.

Public Deployment (e.g., OpenAI Public APIs):

- Access occurs through the public internet over encrypted and authenticated channels (HTTPS/TLS).
- Security policies ensure outbound communications are strictly limited to secured endpoints.

Private Deployment (e.g., Azure OpenAI Private Service):

- Services reside entirely within a dedicated private network with no direct public internet exposure.
- Private endpoints and secure gateways ensure data remains isolated within the client's own network environment, fully compliant with regional data residency and privacy requirements.

# Logging and Monitoring of AI Services

Our AI-enabled applications log interactions (user inputs, system outputs) securely to:

- Monitor and ensure high-quality system performance
- Detect and prevent abuse or misuse
- Troubleshoot technical issues proactively

These practices allow us to proactively ensure system reliability, detect and mitigate threats, maintain regulatory compliance, and continually enhance the quality of our AI services.

Privacy Commitments for Logging

compliance, and continually enhance the quality of our AI services.

Privacy Commitments for Logging

- Logged data remains secure and strictly access-controlled.
- Logs will not be used for training AI models without explicit client permission.
- Clients retain the right to request deletion of logged data or opt out from logging entirely.

Optional Client Feedback Loop

- With the consent of our clients, we may use logged data internally to identify areas for service improvement and optimization.

# Internal Model Training and Fine-Tuning

[http://invent.ai](http://invent.ai)  is committed to advancing AI capabilities while maintaining the highest standards of data protection. In addition to using third-party LLM services, we may also develop, train, and fine-tune our own AI models within our secure, private network. This enables us to:

elop, train, and fine-tune our own AI models within our secure, private network. This enables us to:

- improve our service offerings based on aggregated insights.
- Refine models using client data in a controlled environment that is isolated from external networks.
- Maintain strict access controls and auditing throughout the training and fine-tuning process.

Exclusive Use:Client data used for internal model training is processed exclusively within our secure private network.

## Cross-Client Data Usage

- In some cases, anonymized or aggregated data across multiple clients may be used to further enhance model performance.
- This cross-client data usage is governed by strict protocols that ensure the original identities and proprietary details remain confidential.
- Client Consent: Our clients will have the opportunity to provide explicit consent for any such aggregated data use, ensuring transparency and control over their data.

The backend uses a shared AWS EFS file system with per-tenant Access Points (APs) and read-only file access from the FastAPI app. Below, we detail controls at the infrastructure, application, and process levels, along with monitoring and audit practices. | Isolation Layer | Mechanisms Implemented | Purpose |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Storage (File System) | EFS Access Points per tenant (unique root dirs)​POSIX user mapping (UID/GID 1001) | Segregate each tenant’s files at the storage level. The AP’s root directory confines file access to that tenant’s folder, and root-squash prevents root user bypass. |
| Identity & IAM | IAM roles with least privilege for ECS and pipelines; EFS file system policies denying ClientRootAccessand limiting AP usage | Ensure only authorized services can mount/read the file system, and even they cannot escalate privileges. Each pipeline writes only to its tenant’s AP; the web app role is read-only. |

escalate privileges. Each pipeline writes only to its tenant’s AP; the web app role is read-only. |

This prevents any external or unintended internal source from reaching the file system. |
| GenAI Backend Application (FastAPI) | Tenant ID context for every request; secure path handling (no ../ traversal)​read-only file operationscode checks on path scope | The app logic ensures each request only accesses its tenant’s directory. Path traversal is blocked and the app cannot write or load data outside the intended scope. |

content:
with EFS Access Points:

Each tenant has a dedicated directory on an AWS EFS file system, exposed via an EFS Access Point. An Access Point defines a unique `rootDirectory` for the tenant (for example, `/tenant-a` on the shared EFS) and a fixed POSIX identity (UID/GID set to 1001:1001 for all tenants). This means that when the GenAI Backend Application container mounts the file system through a tenant’s AP, it sees only that tenant’s subdirectory as the root. Access Points are *“application-specific entry points designed to enforce a specified POSIX identity and root directory for connected clients,”*[link](https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2023/01/amazon-efs-increases-access-points-file-system/#:~:text=Amazon%20EFS%20Access%20Points%20are,tenant%20environments) making it easier to isolate data in a multi-tenant environment. By enforcing a root directory for each AP, we ensure the app can operate only within that tenant’s folder, preventing unauthorized access to other data​

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
the app can operate only within that tenant’s folder, preventing unauthorized access to other data​

### ECS Fargate Task Mount Configuration:

The ECS task definition includes an EFS volume for each tenant’s Access Point, mounted to a distinct container path (e.g. mounting tenant X’s AP to `/efs/X`). We enable IAM authorization on these volumes (`"authorizationConfig": { "iam": "ENABLED" }`) and require encryption in transit (`"transitEncryption": "ENABLED"`) for the mounts​. Enabling IAM authentication has two key benefits:

(1) Mount access is controlled by IAM – the ECS task’s role must be allowed to mount that file system/Access Point

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
ss is controlled by IAM – the ECS task’s role must be allowed to mount that file system/Access Point

(2) Root-squash is activated – if the container runs as root, EFS will map it to an unprivileged user (UID 65534) because the role lacks `ClientRootAccess`​ [link](https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/aws-efs-csi-driver/issues/300). In practice, we also run the container processes as the non-root user 1001, matching the AP’s owner UID, so the app has the needed read permissions without any root privileges. Each volume is mounted with the `readOnly` flag set to true in the task definition to enforce that the GenAI Backend Application can’t write to client vector databases on EFS.

### Least-Privilege IAM and EFS Policies:

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
pplication can’t write to client vector databases on EFS.

### Least-Privilege IAM and EFS Policies:

At the AWS IAM level, we restrict who can mount or access the EFS. The ECS task role is granted only the necessary EFS actions (e.g., `elasticfilesystem:ClientMount` and `ClientRead` for the specific file system). We deliberately do not grant `elasticfilesystem:ClientWrite` to the web application role since it only needs read access, and we exclude `ClientRootAccess` to avoid any privilege escalation​.

The EFS file system has a resource-based policy as an additional guard: it allows the ECS task role to access it only via the Access Points. For example, the policy can use a condition to allow `ClientMount` actions only when the AccessPoint ARN matches one of the tenant APs associated with that role

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
Mount` actions only when the AccessPoint ARN matches one of the tenant APs associated with that role

In practice, our GenAI Backend Application is a single service that handles all tenants, the role might have access to all AP's it needs. if we ever separated services by tenant, we’d give each service role access only to its tenant’s AP ARN.)

Data pipeline jobs (which run per-tenant to write files once a day or based on a schedule) each have their own IAM roles with permission to mount or write only to their tenant’s Access Point, ensuring no pipeline can accidentally write into another tenant’s directory. This combination of IAM and EFS file system policies implements defense in depth: even if the app tried to mount or access a different directory, AWS will prevent it at the API/NFS level unless the credentials and AP match.

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
a different directory, AWS will prevent it at the API/NFS level unless the credentials and AP match.

Access Point Design and Root Directory Enforcement: We ensure every EFS Access Point is created with the correct `RootDirectory` pointing to that tenant’s folder (and that folder exists with proper ownership).

In the ECS task definition, we either omit the `rootDirectory` (letting it default to `/`) or set it to `/` explicitly for each EFS volume, because when an AP is used, the mount will automatically be rooted at the AP’s path​. This prevents any possibility of the app using the mount to escape to the parent directories. In effect, even if the container had access to multiple AP mounts (for different tenants), each mount point is isolated to a specific sub-tree of the file system. Since all tenant directories use the same UID in this design, POSIX perms don’t distinguish between tenants in the container; however, the AP separation ensures the container never sees two tenant directories in the same mount namespace. (If in the future we wanted per-tenant Linux users for even stronger OS-level separation, we’d need a more complex container setup. For now, APs with one shared UID is simpler and sufficient given other controls.)

x container setup. For now, APs with one shared UID is simpler and sufficient given other controls.)

### Encryption and Data Protection

The EFS is configured with encryption at rest using AWS KMS. Thus, all files are encrypted on disk which helps meet data-at-rest requirements of SOC 2/ISO 27001. Encryption in transit is enabled as noted (`transitEncryption: ENABLED` in ECS), meaning all NFS traffic between Fargate and EFS is tunneled over TLS​. Between encryption, IAM, and network restrictions, the storage layer is strongly secured.

We use encryption at rest and in transit for all sensitive data. This maps to SOC 2’s confidentiality criteria and ISO 27001. Data on EFS is encrypted with AWS-managed keys, and only the application has access. In transit, TLS (NFS over stunnel) protects against any potential sniffing, aligning with best practices for protecting data in transit.

### Data Segregation and Privacy

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
fing, aligning with best practices for protecting data in transit.

### Data Segregation and Privacy

We achieve logical separation with guaranteed isolation (each tenant’s data resides in a separate directory, accessible only through a specific AP). In an ISO 27001 context, this addresses [A.8](https://www.isms.online/iso-27001/annex-a-8-asset-management/)(asset management – each tenant’s data is treated as a separate asset class) and [A.13](https://www.isms.online/iso-27001/annex-a-13-communications-security/)(segregation in networks / systems). From the customer perspective, we can state that their data is never co-mingled or accessible by others, which is a key trust point.

## Secure Access Patterns in GenAI Backend Application

### Tenant Context and Request Routing:

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
nt.

## Secure Access Patterns in GenAI Backend Application

### Tenant Context and Request Routing:

The GenAI Backend application must associate each incoming request with the correct tenant. Typically, this should/can be done via authentication tokens or API keys that include a tenant ID claim. For example, a JWT might have `tenant_id = "tenant-a"` in its payload, or the subdomain of the request might determine the tenant.

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
`tenant_id = "tenant-a"` in its payload, or the subdomain of the request might determine the tenant.

Our current implementation is depending on getting the tenant id via request post body, which is insecure. We want to implement a dependency or middleware in FastAPI that extracts the tenant identifier from an access token or API key on every request and attaches it to the request context (or only allows the request to proceed if the tenant is determined). All further handling of that request will use this tenant ID to choose data. This ensures that handlers don’t accidentally mix up tenants – they will never explicitly get to specify a tenant, it’s derived from auth.

### Secure Path Construction

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
will never explicitly get to specify a tenant, it’s derived from auth.

### Secure Path Construction

When the app needs to read a file, it will construct the file path by joining the tenant’s mount path with the expected filename. For instance: `base_path = f"/efs/{tenant_id}/"` and then `file_path = os.path.join(base_path, filename)`. We never take a full file path directly from the client. Instead, if a client provides a filename or partial path, we will validate it.

One crucial step is to prevent directory traversal attacks, where a malicious user could try to escape their directory by using `..` or encoded characters to trick the path logic. To counter this, after constructing a path, we resolve it to an absolute canonical path and check that it still begins with the tenant’s base directory. Wewill raise an error if a path tries to break out of the base. The key point is that the final resolved path must lie within the tenant’s folder, otherwise the access will be denied​.

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
t the final resolved path must lie within the tenant’s folder, otherwise the access will be denied​.

The application code should make it impossible to accidentally open another tenant’s file. We will achieve this by not exposing the tenant ID in request parameters that directly feed into file paths. The tenant ID comes from auth, not from an arbitrary user input.

### Automated Testing (CI/CD):

In our CI pipeline, we include tests that specifically target multi-tenant isolation:

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
ting (CI/CD):

In our CI pipeline, we include tests that specifically target multi-tenant isolation:

- Unit tests: We will test functions like path sanitization thoroughly (e.g., give it inputs with .., with long paths, with URL-encoded sequences, etc., and ensure it correctly flags them). We should also test that the file reading code raises an error if pointed to a disallowed path. We can simulate the mount structure in a temp directory in tests to ensure our logic works as intended.
- Integration tests: We spin up the application (perhaps using a Docker container with a similar setup, though EFS mounts are not in test, we can simulate with local folders). Then:Create dummy files for two tenants in separate dirs.Authenticate as tenant A and try to access tenant A’s file (should succeed).Try to access tenant B’s file with tenant A’s credentials (should get 403 Forbidden). We confirm the response code and that no data is leaked.

### High-Security Tenants:

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
403 Forbidden). We confirm the response code and that no data is leaked.

### High-Security Tenants:

If a particular tenant requires an extra level of isolation (due to contractual or regulatory reasons), our architecture can adapt:

- Put that tenant’s data on a dedicated EFS (still mounted to the app but via a different file system). This would ensure even at the storage level, their data is separate. We’d use a separate security group and maybe even a separate IAM role for that EFS. It complicates the app slightly (multiple EFS mounts), but it’s doable.
- Or deploy a separate instance of the whole stack for that tenant (account-level isolation). That’s beyond the scope of our primary multi-tenant design, but it’s an option for extreme cases and shows that we’ve considered data isolation at all levels (logical to physical).

### Region Based Isolation

We can also add an extra level of isolation to comply with regional data isolation procedures, our architecture can adapt:

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
ra level of isolation to comply with regional data isolation procedures, our architecture can adapt:

- Use multiple EFS systems for dedicated for each region. This would ensure that, regional data is separated so that our clients' data wont leave their region.

| Stage | Component | Key settings | Purpose |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Schedule | CRON Schedule from Airflow | rate(1 day) or cron (0 2  ? *) | Fires exactly when its schedule has come, or triggered, per tenant, to call RunTask on ECS Fargate cluster. |
| Task Definition | tenant‑X‑ingest | EFS volume using tenant Access Point fsap‑X (read‑write) | Runs a short‑lived container, mounts only its own AP, downloads from Azure Blob or AWS S3 based on tenant, writes into /efs. |
| Networking | Two options | Public Internet: task in public subnet with IGW/NAT, outbound 443 to *.blob.core.windows.net.VPN / ExpressRoute: task in private subnet, routes 10.0.0.0/8 (Azure vNet) through a Site‑to‑Site VPN or DX.Security group opens outbound 443 only. | Needs clarification with DevOps team. |
| IAM Role | ecs‑ingest‑tenant‑X | elasticfilesystem:ClientMount,ClientWrite only on fsap‑X (no ClientRootAccess) | Lets the task mount its AP and write, but gives it zero rights elsewhere. |

Network Options

| Option | Subnet type for the ingest task | How it reaches Azure Blob & AWS APIs | NAT GW needed? | Typical when… |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| A. Public‑IP | Public subnet | Task gets its own public IPv4 address via the Internet Gateway; SG allows outbound 443 to *.blob.core.windows.net | No NAT (public IP instead) | You’re OK with the task having a routable IP and want the simplest setup. |
| B. Private‑IP + NAT | Private subnet | Outbound traffic is SNAT‑ted through a NAT Gateway in a public subnet, then to the Internet | Yes | You don’t want public IPs on tasks, and you’re not using a VPN/ExpressRoute to Azure. |
| C. Private‑IP + VPN / DX | Private subnet | Routes destined for Azure’s vNet flow through the Site‑to‑Site VPN (or DX) ENI; AWS APIs are reached via VPC interface endpoints (ECR, CloudWatch, Secrets Mgr, etc.) | No NAT (traffic stays on the private link) | You have—or must meet—“no‑Internet‑egress” or low‑latency private‑link requirements. |

metadata.title: Data Isolation in Vector Databases Stored in AWS EFS

content:
ivate link) | You have—or must meet—“no‑Internet‑egress” or low‑latency private‑link requirements. |

| Priority | Recommended network pattern |
| --- | --- |
| Simplicity & lowest cost | Public subnet + public IP (no NAT). One SG rule: outbound 443 → Azure Blob. |
| No public IPs | Private subnet + NAT Gateway. Keep the NAT in a separate “egress” AZ pair and tag it for cost tracking. |
| Strict private connectivity (e.g., ISO 27001 control “information transfer policies”) | Private subnet + Site‑to‑Site VPN/ExpressRoute to Azure and VPC interface endpoints to AWS APIs → 0 NAT Gateways. |

content:
## 1. 🧠 What Is the Data Q&A Chat Agent?

The Data Q&A Chat Agent is a smart assistant designed to help you explore your Replenishment Order data more easily. You can ask it questions in plain language, and it will return answers based on the data shown on screen.

> No technical knowledge is required — just ask, and get insights instantly.

---

## 2. 💡 What Can the Agent Do?

The agent can help you:

✅ Understand your data using natural language questions
✅ Filter information (e.g., specific stores, time periods, product groups)
✅ Summarize and aggregate data (e.g., total sales, average stock, fill rate)

> 🔒 The agent only uses the data visible or connected to the page you're viewing. It does not access any external or historical data unless it’s already present.

---

## 3. 💬 How to Ask Questions

Ask your question as if you're speaking to a colleague.

### ✅ Good Examples:

metadata.title: Data Q&A Chat Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
How to Ask Questions

Ask your question as if you're speaking to a colleague.

### ✅ Good Examples:

- “Which item-store combinations are experiencing stockout?”
- “Which items have the highest excess inventory?”
- “Show me the details of the Jeans group.”
- “Filter to see replenishment results of electronics in the NA region.”

📌 Tips:

- If the answer isn’t quite what you need, try rephrasing your question with more detail.
- If you're unsure what to ask, check the sample question dropdown in the question field — it offers helpful examples to guide you.

---

## 4. 🚦 What the Agent Can’t Do

To set the right expectations, here’s what the agent does not support:

metadata.title: Data Q&A Chat Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
4. 🚦 What the Agent Can’t Do

To set the right expectations, here’s what the agent does not support:

| ❌ Not Supported | Notes |
| --- | --- |
| Free-form small talk or general chat | It's a task-specific assistant — not a general-purpose chatbot |
| Accessing unrelated datasets | Only works with the current page’s data |
| Updating or modifying any data | Read-only assistant — no data is changed |
| Sending alerts or notifications | It responds to your question only — it doesn’t monitor or notify |
| Follow-up questions | The beta version does not support follow-up context; each query is standalone |
| Direct answers | The answer to your question will always be displayed by refreshing the data. No direct answers on the chatbox. |
| Layered questions | Complex, multi-part questions need to be broken down. (Example tip* displayed below) |
| “Why” Questions | Not supported — try rephrasing to view relevant data. (Example tip* displayed below) |

#### 🔍 Examples and Tips

metadata.title: Data Q&A Chat Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
d — try rephrasing to view relevant data. (Example tip* displayed below) |

#### 🔍 Examples and Tips

Although the beta version does not support all use cases, you can often uncover useful insights by rephrasing them.

Layered questions
❌ “For my top SKU, show me the stores which didn’t sell anything in the last 2 weeks.”
✅ Ask first: “What is my best-selling SKU?” → Then, once you have the product code include it in in your next prompt: “Which stores didn’t sell [SKU] in the last 2 weeks?”

“Why” questions
❌ “Why do we have an order for product 1001027 store 1024?”
✅ “Show the details for product 1001027 in store 1024.”
This will return key data like forecast, inventory, and targets so you can assess the cause manually.

---

## 5. 🚀 Getting Started – Step by Step

> Info: Available Pages:Store Replenishment Orders under Replenishment / Inventory Management

Step 1: Open Store Replenishment Orders Page

Click to Store Replenishment Orders on sidebar:

metadata.title: Data Q&A Chat Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
ement

Step 1: Open Store Replenishment Orders Page

Click to Store Replenishment Orders on sidebar:

Step 2: Open the Agent
Click the chat icon on the *Store Replenishment Orders* which is at the right bottom of the page.

Step 3: Open Data Chat Agent

Using the agent selection dropdown, switch to Data Chat agent

Step 4: Type Your Question
Use natural language.

> Info: Note: The model can only respond based on the data visible on the page. For example, since this page only includes the latest day’s replenishment order results, it cannot answer questions about long-term seasonality or historical patterns.

Use the input box in the bottom of the AI Drawer. It will help you with pre-defined question suggestions as you type

When you’re done, hit enter or click to the send button!

Step 5: Review the Answer
The agent will return a verbal description and an in-line data-grid as a response to your question. This data grid will contain a preview dataset as a response to your question.

metadata.title: Data Q&A Chat Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
onse to your question. This data grid will contain a preview dataset as a response to your question.

Step 6: (Optional) Apply to Main Grid
Clicking to Apply to Main Grid button will move the filter and aggregation settings of the inline grid to the main page. If you want to benefit from the richer data-grid functionality in the page, click this button! It will close the AI drawer and focus on to the page.

Note that you can use Cheetah Grid functionalities and bring new columns to the data grid by clicking “Manage Column Visibility” button

Enjoy the enhanced grid

---

content:
- Know the limitations of the Data QA AgentIt can’t maintain multi-turn conversations. So you cant ask follow-up questions to maintain the conversation history. Every question is a new question from scratch.It may not answer Reasons behind the data as it is unaware of it. Use Doctor Why and Daily Digest agents for the detailed reasons.If may not answer the way of working for replenishment, typically “How” questions. Use Replenishment Domain Knowledge Agent and UI Helper Agent instead.
- Know the limitations of the page:Store Replenishment Orders page shows the most recent orders and additional KPIs. It does not maintain historical replenishment results. So, as an example, you cant ask it to compare with previous weeks' orders You can only ask questions that your data grid contains. You cant ask questions regarding other domains, e.g. Lost Sales.
- Be specific with timeframes, stores, or products

metadata.title: Data Q&A Chat Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
estions regarding other domains, e.g. Lost Sales.
- Be specific with timeframes, stores, or products
- Use the column names and terms shown on the screen  📌 For example: If the data column is labeled ty_14, refer to it as “14 days” — not “2 weeks”
- Use the displayed data as your guide
- Start simple — avoid asking multi-part or overly complex questions
- Try rewording if the response isn’t helpful

---

## 7. 📞 Need Help?

If something doesn’t look right, or you’re unsure how to phrase your question:

📬 Our clients → Contact your support team at *client_support@invent.ai*
📸 Internal testers → You can also share feedback and screenshots via the Slack channel:

@[agentic-ai-feedback](https://invent-ai.slack.com/archives/C08RKCG8GN7)

metadata.title: Data Q&A Chat Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
# 1. System Overview

This system provides a multi-tenant, web application focused on hosting AIsolutions through LLMintegrations.

- Tenants: Each customer (“tenant”) has logically isolated data in a shared AWS environment.
- Data Sync Jobs: Periodic or triggered tasks ingest data from tenants' data buckets (Azure Blob or AWS S3) into a central Amazon EFS file system, organizing tenant data under separate directories (access points under EFS).
- AI Web App: A Fargate-hosted service mounts the same EFS, loads the LanceDB-based vector database for each tenant, and serves LLM applications.

Infra-as-Code is developed using AWS CDK Framework

## 2. Component Breakdown

### VPC & Networking

A Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) is our isolated network in AWS. It provides subnets, routing tables, internet/NAT gateways, and security groups to control the traffic.

Using a VPC is required for:

es, internet/NAT gateways, and security groups to control the traffic.

Using a VPC is required for:

- Isolation of all tenant workloads from the public Internet.
- Fine-grained control over inbound/outbound traffic.

Security Groups

- EFS SG: Allows NFS (TCP 2049) only from our ECS tasks’ SG to allow mounting EFS.
- Data Sync Job Task SG: Allows outbound to EFS SG, SecretsManager endpoints, and API calls
- Web Task SG: Allows HTTP traffic from NLB, denies all other ingress.

| Component | Service(s) | CDK Construct | Key Configurations |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| VPC - Created externally | Data Sync Jobs, AI Web App | ec2.Vpc.from_lookup(...) | Import by vpc_id provided. |
| Subnets | Data Sync Jobs, AI Web App | ec2.SubnetSelection(subnetType=PRIVATE) | Private with egress |
| Security Groups | Data Sync Jobs, AI Web App, EFS | ec2.SecurityGroup | Created individually for each service: EFS SG, Task SG, Web SG |

### Elastic File System (EFS)

up | Created individually for each service: EFS SG, Task SG, Web SG |

### Elastic File System (EFS)

EFS is a fully managed NFS file system that can be mounted by multiple ECS instances concurrently. It is used for accessing LanceDB-based vector databases with low latency.

| Component | Service(s) | CDK Construct | Key Configurations |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| File System | Data Sync Jobs, AI Web App, EFS | efs.FileSystem | one_zone=True, lifecycle after 14d, bursting throughput |
| Access Points | Data Sync Jobs, AI, EFS | efs.CfnAccessPoint per tenant | PosixUser(uid, gid), CreationInfo(permissions=750) |
| File System Policy | EFS | CfnResource(type="AWS::EFS::FileSystemPolicy") | Broader allow for let Data Sync Jobs and AI Web App to mount this EFS. |

### Secrets Management

AWS Secret Manager is a managed service to store, rotate, and retrieve secret information like database credentials, API keys, and other secrets.

ore, rotate, and retrieve secret information like database credentials, API keys, and other secrets.

| Component | Service(s) | CDK Construct | Key Configurations |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Tenant Secrets | Data Sync Jobs | sm.Secret | Vector DB Connection JSON payload: {file_schema, bucket_name, …} |
| OpenAI API Keys | AI Web App | sm.Secret.from_secret_name_v2 / from_secret_partial_arn | Partial ARN lookup for dev/prod OpenAI keys |

### Container Registry (ECR)

ECR is a fully managed Docker container registry, used for storing container images used by our Data Sync Jobs and AI Web App.

| Component | Service(s) | CDK Construct | Config |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| ECR Repositories | Data Sync Jobs, AI Web App | ecr.Repository | gensight/ai-backend-service, gensight/vectordb-data-sync |

### API Gateway & Load Balancing

itory | gensight/ai-backend-service, gensight/vectordb-data-sync |

### API Gateway & Load Balancing

- API Gateway: Managed front-door for REST/HTTP APIs. Managed API Gateway provides us global caching, authentication via API Keys, usage plans, and stage management.
- NLB: Load balancer that receives requests at Layer-4 (transport) and forwards TCP to ECS Fargate tasks.

| Component | Service(s) | CDK Construct | Configuration |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Network Load Balancer | AI Web App | elbv2.NetworkLoadBalancer | Internet-facing: False; Health checks on TCP/80 |
| API Gateway | AI Web App | apigw.RestApi | Proxy ANY to NLB via VPC_LINK |
| VPC Link | AI Web App | apigw.VpcLink | Targets = [NLB] |
| API Key & Usage | AI Web App | apigw.ApiKey, apigw.UsagePlan | Throttle=50rps, Burst=100, Quota=200/day |

## 3. ECS Fargate Services

### Data Sync Service (ECS Fargate)

e=50rps, Burst=100, Quota=200/day |

## 3. ECS Fargate Services

### Data Sync Service (ECS Fargate)

Serverless containers that run data sync jobs to sync on-prem/Azure Blob/S3 data into EFS. We are using it to have Fargate runs tasks on demand. We are applying a Per-tenant isolation via separate task definitions and access points.

| Aspect | Details |
| --- | --- |
| Purpose | Vector DB data sync from source buckets to EFS / ETL per tenant into EFS mount |
| Stack | SyncServiceStack |
| CDK Constructs | ecs.Cluster, ecs.FargateTaskDefinition, ecs.FargateService |
| Networking | Task SG ↔ EFS SG (all TCP), Private subnets |
| IAM Roles | Task role (secret read), Exec role (EFS mount, SSM exec) |
| Logging | logs.LogGroup per tenant, retention 1 month |

### Web Application Service (ECS Fargate)

Serverless Fargate containers hosting the AI inference API with EFS-backed LanceDB-based vector database.

rless Fargate containers hosting the AI inference API with EFS-backed LanceDB-based vector database.

| Aspect | Details |
| --- | --- |
| Purpose | Serve AI Web Services, load vector DB from EFS |
| Stack | WebStack |
| CDK Constructs | ecs.Cluster, FargateTaskDefinition, FargateService |
| Load Balancer | elbv2.NetworkLoadBalancer + apigw.VpcLink |
| API Gateway | apigw.RestApi with proxy integration |
| IAM Roles | Task role (read vector DB secrets), Exec role (ECR pull, EFS mount) |
| Logging | /gensight/{env}/web/app CloudWatch LogGroup |

## 4. Tenant Management & Isolation

# 4. Tenant Management & Isolation
4. Tenant Management & Isolation
4. Tenant Management & Isolation
. Tenant Management & Isolation

Tenant Management & Isolation

1. Provisioning TenantsDefined in config_{env}.yml under tenants: array.Each entry contains name, source_secret_pattern, destination_secret_pattern.tenants:
  - name: xxx
    source_secret_pattern: gensight/vectordb/yyy
    destination_secret_pattern: gensight/vectordb-efs/zzz
2. EFS IsolationAccess Points: One per tenant, mapping to /tenants/{tenant} directory with POSIX UIDs (1001, 1002, …) and Group ID 1000EFS Volume: Shared file system, but OS-level isolation via access point permissions.For tenants that require more complex security isolation needs, we can set up separate EFS volumes for them.
3. IAM PoliciesTask Role: Grant read-only Secrets Manager for source/destination secrets per tenant.Exec Role: Grant elasticfilesystem:* only on authorized access points and file system ARN.
4. Application Layer Namespaces for Data Sync ServicesContainer command arguments include --customer {tenant} to scope queries.CloudWatch LogGroups namespaced by tenant.

nd arguments include --customer {tenant} to scope queries.CloudWatch LogGroups namespaced by tenant.

## 5. Data Flow

1. Client Buckets → EFSData Sync task (ECS Fargate) pulls from Client Buckets.SOON  via Site-to-Site VPNWrites a copy of LanceDB-based vector database data into EFS at /tenants/{tenant}.
2. EFS → Vector DBDuring sync, the task generate;LanceDB tableLanceDB indicesLanceDB compaction and optimization steps
3. Web App Query PathClient requests → API Gateway → NLB → ECS Fargate Web application.Container mounts EFS (/mnt/efs) and loads vector index for specific tenant.Queries answered via in-memory vector search, if necessary.Results returned through the same API path.
4. Secrets RetrievalBoth sync and web tasks retrieve database credentials or AI model keys from Secrets Manager during startup.

Problem Description

Data QA Agent translates natural language based retail analytics questions to precise SQL queries.
Being able to map user intent into database schema and related SQL query importance is very important.

In its current architecture Data QA use tool calling mechanism of openAI thus correct, enriched prompt guideing the llm to use the correct tools with to the point knowledge guides critical.

The need is to be able to make llm understand user intent and to be able to do this first we need to be able to extract some entities to guide us further. There are three main entities we would like to capture if there exists:

-) Product

-) Location

-) Time

Capturing these successfully enables us to guide llm much more successfully.

Experimentation

In its core, this is a NER(Named Entity Recognition) problem. This is an old problem in NLP domain and there are approaches including rule based systems, generative ai and transformer based question/answer systems.

pproaches including rule based systems, generative ai and transformer based question/answer systems.

*-) Rule based*

This is the oldest and most time consuming method to implement. In this approach one needs to generate patterns and capture them in syntax domain without touching semantics. This is easier to reason on, debug but does not capture the meaning, only syntax.

*-) Generative AI*

LLMs are used everywhere and with correct prompting we can guide them to extract entities in the text with a structured output. This is not a hard problem for LLMs because NER domain is not new and one of the core components of NLP since the beginning.

Generative AI is a good choice because it can capture not only syntax but also semantics using embeddings.

-) Transformer based Question/Answer

Before LLMs, NLP domain was using transformer based BERT variant models heavily. Even today they are still being used because of their performance/cost and encoder functionalities.

Even today they are still being used because of their performance/cost and encoder functionalities.

These models also use embeddings thus captures semantic meaning as well on top of syntax.

The approach is for every entity type we would like to capture, we ask one or more related questions to the model paired with the input text we would like to extract entity from. For every result model provides we have a score of confidence as well which we can use as a threshold to add to our result set or not at the end.

Evaluation

In standard binary classification, there are binary predictions made, there are actual values and there exists four values after we cross compare them, true-positive, true-negative, false-positive, false-negative. On top of these four values we create precision and recall metrics.

Precision measures what is the correct prediction ratio among the ones I predicted.

Recall measures what is the correct prediction ratio among all actual values.

the ones I predicted.

Recall measures what is the correct prediction ratio among all actual values.

In NER domain, we have a prediciton of an entity value and a corresponding actual value for that entity. Assuming a word is a token, we take intersection of actual value tokens and our prediction tokens and find true-positives. Tokens that we predicted but that does not exist within actual value tokens are false-positives. Tokens that exist in the actual value tokens but not in our prediction are false-negatives. As you may already notices, there is no true-negatives because we are only predicting existance of one class but nothing about non-existance.

For generative AI case, we use openAI. For rule based version we used spacy and en_core_web_trf model specifically. This model is a hybrid one both using rules and transformers. For Q/A we used DistilBertQuestionAnswering pipeline from transformers library of huggingface.

mers. For Q/A we used DistilBertQuestionAnswering pipeline from transformers library of huggingface.

For dataset we created a syntetic one using Claude 3.7 Sonnet having 173 rows of data.

Generative AI system prompt is as follows:

tic one using Claude 3.7 Sonnet having 173 rows of data.

Generative AI system prompt is as follows:

> Info: You are a named entity recognizer.You recognize three specific entities.Entities you recognize are:-) Product DimensionProduct groups, hierarchy nodes and product names are examples for this category of entities.-) Location / Store DimensionStore code, region name, cluster name are examples for this category of entities.-) Time DimensionRelative ranges like "3 months ago", seasonalities, explicit dates are examples for this category of entities.You will return a json including entity type as keys and found entity values as values.If you found multiple entity values for one entity type, sort them descendingly based on the importance.Example:{    "Product Dimension": [<values>],    "Location / Store Dimension": [<values>],    "Time Dimension": [<values>],}

Question/Answer questions for each entity type are as follows:

Location:

> Info: "What region names are mentioned?""What cluster names are mentioned?"

Product:

> Info: "What specific product names are mentioned?""What product groups or categories are mentioned?""What store codes (like SKU-1234 or SKU1234) are mentioned?"

Time:
