Product entity results (60 samples):

ata QA use Agent class that can be accessed as:

```py
from gensight.core.llm.agent import Agent
```

This class takes inner_tools and outer_tools as parameters aside from others. Parameter inner_tools is simply for the llm to call whenever it thinks the tool call is needed. Parameter outer_tools are used *before*making the first call to the llm, in another words enriching the prompt being fed into the llm.

This entity extraction will be an outer_tool for the agent, enriching the prompt by making a pre-call to the llm with user's question before making the actual call to the llm. If reasoning process of the llm is a multidimensional array, by using entity extraction outer_tool, we are flattening this array.

# Configuration

The default splitter configuration for our agent is as follows for knowledge base documents (around the size of 8000 characters):

Splitter approach: MarkdownTextSplitter

Chunk Size: 400

Chunk Overlap: 80 (20% of Chunk Size)

Embeddings: OpenAIEmbeddings

Embedding Model: text-embedding-3-small

Embedding Dimension: 256

Docs Retrieved (top k matched sources): 5

The file should be in .md format as shown in [Template / Guidelines on Writing LLM-Friendly Knowledge Base Documents]

This architecture describes a production-ready LLM integration for Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) systems that follows industry best practices and standard terminology. It provides a flexible framework for building AI-powered applications that can leverage external knowledge to generate accurate, contextually relevant responses.

## Core Components

### 1. Large Language Model (LLM) Integration

The system provides a flexible abstraction layer supporting multiple LLM providers:

- LLM Interface: A standardized interface for all language model interactions
- Provider Implementations:OpenAI modelsAzure OpenAI modelsGoogle AI models (Gemini)Potential extensions for other providers (e.g. Anthropic)
- Our solution suite creates appropriate LLM instances that are exchangeable based on user-defined configuration

The LLM subsystem includes:

- Output parsing and formatting
- Token usage tracking and cost management
- Error handling with automatic retries
- Tool calling integration

sage tracking and cost management
- Error handling with automatic retries
- Tool calling integration

### 2. Vector Database Integration

The system implements a provider-agnostic vector database layer:

- Vector Store Interface: A standard interface for all vector database implementations
- Connection Management: Handles connection pooling, authentication, and reconnection logic
- Supported Vector Databases:LanceDBPotential extensions for other providers

Vector stores are configured with sensitive connection details secured through secret management systems.

### 3. Retrieval Strategies

The system implements several retrieval approaches following industry standards:

trieval Strategies

The system implements several retrieval approaches following industry standards:

- Vector Search Retriever: The primary retrieval mechanism that:Converts user queries to vector embeddingsPerforms approximate nearest neighbor (ANN) searchesSupports filtering with metadata
- Full Text Search Retriever: Text based retrieval mechanism:Supports text retrieval methods (BM25, TF-IDF)
- Hybrid Retriever: Combines multiple retrieval methods:Dense vector retrieval (embedding-based)Sparse vector retrieval (BM25, TF-IDF)Keyword-based filtering
- Re-ranking: Improves search results through:Cross-encoder re-ranking modelsReciprocal rank fusionContextual relevance scoring
- Retrieval Types:Semantic search (embedding similarity)Hybrid search (combining vector and keyword)Metadata filteringMaximum marginal relevance (MMR) for diversity
- Data Retrieval:Connects to external data systems such as Relational Databases to retrieve necessary contexts based on the needs of agents

ata systems such as Relational Databases to retrieve necessary contexts based on the needs of agents

### 4. RAG Framework

The system provides a base implementation for RAG applications:

- Component Orchestration: Manages interactions between LLMs, embeddings, vector stores, and retrievers
- LLM Chain Architecture: Follows common industrial patterns:Document loaders for data ingestionText splitters for chunkingEmbedding pipeline for vectorizationRetrieval chain for context fetchingGeneration chain for response creation
- Use-Case Implementations: Pre-built solutions for common scenarios:Document Q&AConversational searchKnowledge base queryingAnalytical insights

### 5. Embedding Models

The system abstracts embedding generation across providers:

- Embedding Interface: Standardizes embedding operations
- Supported Models:OpenAI's embedding modelsOpen Source Embedding models (Sentence Transformers)

- Document Loaders: Specialized components that handle different document formats:Markdown format document loaders for text dataDatabase record loaders for structured dataCSV/Excel readers for tabular data
- Text Processing: Prepares raw text for effective embedding:Cleaning and normalizationMetadata extraction
- Text Splitting: Divides documents into optimal chunks:Recursive character splittingSemantic splitting based on content boundariesSliding window approaches with configurable overlapHierarchical splitting for preserving document structure
- Embedding Generation: Converts text chunks to vector representations:Batch processing for efficiencyCaching to prevent redundant embeddingsParallel processing for large document setsModel selection based on document characteristics
- Metadata Management: Preserves context and enables filtering:Source trackingTimestamp informationHierarchical relationships between chunksCustom metadata fields for domain-specific attributes

mationHierarchical relationships between chunksCustom metadata fields for domain-specific attributes
- Vector Storage: Optimizes how vectors are stored and indexed:Automatic index optimizationNamespace/collection managementData validation and deduplicationVersioning for tracking changes

This comprehensive ingestion pipeline ensures that documents are properly processed, chunked at appropriate semantic boundaries, embedded with high-quality vector representations, and efficiently indexed in the vector database with relevant metadata.

## Typical RAG Workflow

A standard RAG query follows these steps:

database with relevant metadata.

## Typical RAG Workflow

A standard RAG query follows these steps:

1. User query is received by the application
2. Query is converted to an embedding vector
3. Vector similarity search retrieves relevant documents from the vector database
4. Retrieved documents are potentially re-ranked for relevance
5. The LLM receives the user query and retrieved context
6. The LLM may use tools or perform reasoning steps
7. A final response is generated and returned to the user

The Daily Digest agent turns millions of rows daily replenishment decisions into narrated inventory insights.

A self-service summarization layer unblocks *both* the people (merchants, supply-chain managers) and the code that will power next-generation prescriptive agents.

## DailyDigestGenerator Pipeline

DailyDigestGenerator is a single DAG that:

1. (ETL phase) Prepares the two input datasets
2. (Generation phase) Calls the LLM agent to produce per-category and consolidated narratives
3. (Persistence phase) Upserts both “historic” and “latest” summary tables in PostgreSQL

## DailyDigestAgent

### 1. Agent Inputs

When `DailyDigestAgent` is invoked, it receives exactly:

1. Meta Context (Python dict){   "run_date": "YYYY-MM-DD",          # e.g. "2025-06-15"   "document_type": "Category",       # or "Consolidated"   "hierarchy_level": ["pg1", "country"],    # list of grouping keys   "hierarchy_identifier": {"pg1":"Accessories","country":"US"} }
2. Risk Metrics Slice (pandas.DataFrame)Columns include at least: ["product_code","store_code","pg1","country","potential_margin_loss","stockout_rate", …]One row per SKU-store (or pre-aggregated per subgroup, depending on your write-up).
3. Health Metrics Slice (pandas.DataFrame)Columns include at least: ["product_code","store_code","pg1","country","overstock_rate","excess_inventory_value","fulfillment_rate","health_score", …]

ode","pg1","country","overstock_rate","excess_inventory_value","fulfillment_rate","health_score", …]

These three inputs feed the agent’s `build_prompt()` and then `parse_response()` on the LLM output.

---

## 2. Agent Outputs

The agent must return a JSON-serializable `dict` matching the following schema:

```
# Top-level fields
run_date:                 string   # YYYY-MM-DD
document_type:            string   # e.g. "Footwear | Hierarchy" or "Consolidated"
hierarchy_level:          [string] # e.g. ["product_group_2_description"]
hierarchy_identifier:     {string:string}

kpis:                     {…}      # Aggregate KPI numeric fields

narrative_blocks:         [        # One or more insight blocks
  {
    title:       string,
    body:        string,
    block_kpis:  {…}          # Sub-subset of KPI numbers or JSON-encoded lists
  },
  …
]

string,
    block_kpis:  {…}          # Sub-subset of KPI numbers or JSON-encoded lists
  },
  …
]

# (Only for Category mode)
top_pairs:                [        # Optional: list of top product-store narrative pairs
  {
    product_code:  string,
    store_code:    string,
    body:          string,
    kpis:          {…}
  },
  …
]
bottom_pairs:             [        # Optional: same structure for bottom performers
  { … }, …
]

# (Optional) Raw LLM payload for audit/debug
raw_response:             string   # entire JSON/text returned by the LLM

metadata: {                 # Agent runtime metadata
  model:        string,     # e.g. "gpt-4o-mini"
  strategy:     string,     # "Per-Group" or "Consolidation"
  token_usage:  {…},
  cost:         number,
  run_id:       string,     # UUID
  run_timestamp:string,     # ISO datetime
  analysis_date:string      # same as run_date for clarity
}

```

## API Integration

To consume the Daily Digest summaries, we expose two endpoints in the AI Service:

### 3.1. GET /daily-digest/store-rpl/consolidated

Retrieves the latest consolidated summary document (or for a specific `run_date`).

```
GET /daily-digest/store-rpl/consolidated?run_date=2025-06-15
Authorization: Bearer <JWT>
```

- Query Parametersrun_date (optional, YYYY-MM-DD): if omitted, returns the most recent consolidated summary.
- Responses200 OK{ /* Consolidated Insight Output */ }400 Bad Request{ "error": "Invalid filter type 'foo' for column 'pg1'" }401 Unauthorized / 403 Forbidden

---

### 3.2. POST /daily-digest/store-rpl/aggregation-level-based

Returns per-group (aggregation-level) summaries, filtered by arbitrary column predicates.

```
POST /daily-digest/store-rpl/aggregation-level-based
Authorization: Bearer <JWT>
Content-Type: application/json

type 'foo' for column 'pg1'" }401 Unauthorized / 403 Forbidden

---

[

    "run_date": "2025-06-15",

    "hierarchy_identifier": {"pg1":"Accessories","country":"US"},
    "kpis": { /* … */ },
    "narrative_blocks": [ /* … */ ],
    "top_pairs": [ /* … */ ],
    "bottom_pairs": [ /* … */ ],
    "metadata": { /* … */ }
  }
]
```

Previously in [DataQA Agent Integration]  we analyzed product, location and time related entities.

This time we’re going to be analyzing:

- EX: Exact match explicit qualifiers
- K: Metrics and/or KPIs
- CP: Comparison Patterns
- EF: Business Entities
- M: Modifier and/or ranking
- T: Time periods which are not exact dates.

This is a user intent matching analysis in its core. We are trying to see whether question answer system can outperform chatgpt in terms of precision and recall.

For LLM prompting, the sub prompt we use in data QA is changed slightly because we needed to remove tool calling functionality.

> Info: User Query Understanding — Intent Extraction & Search-Term MappingPurpose: Turn the user’s sentence into a structured map of business terms.Extract Raw PhrasesTokenize the query & run NER.Assemble adjacent tokens into noun phrases (e.g., “Hair care”, “Store ABC”).Drop obvious filler words: items, stores, skus, products, data, records, list, each, all, the.Classify Each Phrase (with Priority Order)EX: Exact match or a very close match to an explicit qualifier in the utterance. (e.g. product_group_4 Hair, store_code ABC, literal column names).Also include generic nouns. Example Terms: sku, skus, product, products, store, stores, item, itemsK: Metric / KPI – facts or calculated measures already in schema, denoted by column names, labels, synonyms, or calculated fields. (e.g. sales, revenue, inventory, cover period, presence level).CP: Comparison Pattern - Phrases signaling relative change or thresholds that include column-to-value or column-to-column comparisons. (e.g

ing relative change or thresholds that include column-to-value or column-to-column comparisons. (e.g. "drop in sales")Will be paired with the nearest preceding K metric.EF: Entity-Fuzzy match – business entity that is not an exact synonym (singular/plural, typo, alias). (e.g. “Hair”, “Accessories”, “Nike”, “SKU FooBar”).M: Modifier / Ranking – adjectives or adverbs that influence sorting, comparison, or date window. (e.g. top, best, highest, fastest-moving, last month).T: Temporal – time periods or durations that are not exact dates. (e.g. last week, this month, previous quarter).K catches any schema‑defined numeric or boolean fieldMulti‑Coding RuleIf a phrase implies multiple meanings, such as a modifier and a metric (e.g., best‑selling, top revenue), assign both codes: [M, K].3.5 Candidate-List JSONProduce:[
>   { "term": "Accessory", "codes": ["EF"]},
>   { "term": "top", "codes": ["M"]},
>   { "term": "last 2 weeks", "codes": ["M"]},

odes": ["EF"]},
>   { "term": "top", "codes": ["M"]},
>   { "term": "last 2 weeks", "codes": ["M"]},
>   { "term": "performing well", "codes": ["K"]},
>   { "term": "low presentation levels", "codes": ["K", "M"]},
>   { "term": "Store ABC", "codes": ["EX"]},
>   { "term": "SKU FooBar", "codes": ["EX"]},
>   { "term": "Hair", "codes": ["EF"]},
>   { "term": "best-selling", "codes": ["M", "K"]},
>   { "term": "inventory", "codes": ["K"]},
>   { "term": "increase in sales", "codes": ["CP", "K"]}
> ]You must return a json which can be loaded with json.loads(..)

Question/Answer questions for each entity type are as follows:

EX:

> Info: What are very close or close matches to an explicit qualifiers?

K:

# 🧠 What Is the Doc Q&A Agent?

The Domain Knowledge Chat Q&A Agent is a specialized assistant trained on Invent.ai’s retail science solutions, such as Replenishment, Promotion, Markdown, Allocation, and Transfer. It’s designed to help you quickly understand and navigate domain-specific information from internal documentation.

Whether you're a team member or partner, you can ask plain-language questions and receive clear, structured answers based on Invent's solution knowledge.

---

# 💡 What Can the Agent Do?

The Doc Q&A Agent helps you:

✅ Understand core solution concepts and business logic
✅ Retrieve definitions of KPIs, parameters, and policies
✅ Clarify how specific algorithms or configurations work

📌 The agent is powered by the internal documentation provided to it — it doesn’t hallucinate answers or guess when it lacks context.

---

# 💬 How to Ask Questions

Speak to the agent like you would to a knowledgeable team member.

### ✅ Good Examples:

metadata.title: Doc Q&A: Domain Knowledge Chat Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
k Questions

Speak to the agent like you would to a knowledgeable team member.

### ✅ Good Examples:

- “What are the main KPI’s for the Replenishment solution?”
- “How does the Transfer solution decide source stores?”
- “List the input parameters for Markdown optimization.”
- “How is demand calculated in the Promotion solution?”
- “How is stockout risk calculated in the Promotion module?”
- “How is the minimum display quantity handled in the Markdown solution?”

### 📌 Tips:

- Use domain terms when possible (e.g., ‘fill rate’, ‘allocation group’, ‘lifespan’).
- If you don’t get the right answer, rephrase the question more explicitly.

---

# 🚦 What the Agent Can’t Do

don’t get the right answer, rephrase the question more explicitly.

# 🚦 What the Agent Can’t Do

| ❌ Not Supported | Notes |
| --- | --- |
| General-purpose conversation | It's a focused domain assistant, not a chatbot for casual dialogue |
| Accessing operational data | The agent does not pull live or historical data |
| Comparing across solutions | Stick to questions about one solution module at a time |
| Updating documentation | It’s read-only; can’t change or annotate source materials |
| Follow-up context | Each question is standalone; session memory isn’t supported in beta |
| Making assumptions | It does not guess — if documentation is missing, it won’t fabricate |

# 🧠 What Is the Daily Digest Agent?

The Daily Digest Agent is an automated LLM-powered assistant that delivers a high-level daily summary of your inventory management ecosystem.
It compiles key operational KPIs, highlights performance trends, and surfaces the most critical risks and opportunities — all without any manual input from the user.

This daily narration is designed to give you a quick, executive-level understanding of overall inventory health, enabling you to spot issues and take action faster.

---

## 💡 What Does the Agent Provide?

Each daily digest includes:

✅ Overall Inventory Health Summary – A balanced view of stock performance, combining key KPIs like Health Score, Fulfillment Rate, Stockout Rate, Margin Loss, and Overstock Rate.

✅ Risk Highlights – Identification of top margin loss drivers, high stockout groups, and critical unmet demand.

✅ Excess Inventory Insights – Details on overstock value, overstock rate, and top excess product groups.

metadata.title: Daily Digest Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
cess Inventory Insights – Details on overstock value, overstock rate, and top excess product groups.

✅ Operational Constraints – Key limiting factors (e.g., insufficient DC inventory) and their impact on fulfillment efficiency.

✅ Growth Signals – Positive performance notes, such as strong sales growth areas.

---

## 📊 How to Use the Agent

1. Access the Daily DigestThe agent’s narration appears automatically when you open the Daily Digest module in the Control Tower panel.
2. Select the View LevelUse the Company, Division, and Category (typically product group 1, 2, and 3 named with your clients labels) dropdown filters to change the scope of the summary.The narration will update to reflect only the selected hierarchy level.By default, the page opens from the company level.
3. Review the NarrationRead through the structured summary for a quick understanding of today’s performance.Use the breakdown sections (health, risks, excess, constraints) to identify priority areas.

---

metadata.title: Daily Digest Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
nce.Use the breakdown sections (health, risks, excess, constraints) to identify priority areas.

---

## 🚦 What the Agent Does Not Do

| ❌ Not Supported | Notes |
| --- | --- |
| Answering ad-hoc questions | The agent provides a one-way, generated narration — no chat input |
| Accessing multiple days at once | Only the currently loaded daily dataset is summarized |
| Editing or changing data | Read-only; it cannot modify metrics or operational settings |
| Predictive simulations | Focuses on reporting actual KPIs, not modeling future scenarios |

---

## ✅ Best Practices for Use

- Check it daily to stay ahead of risks and inventory imbalances.
- Drill down using the hierarchy filters if you need a narrower focus (e.g., by category).
- Correlate insights with other dashboards for a fuller operational picture.
- Use it as a briefing tool in morning stand-ups or daily business reviews.

---

## 📞 Need Help?

This document aims to standardize the process of writing and reviewing design documents. Before, delving into the details, one should keep in mind that design docs:

- propose a solution to a somewhat complex problem
- emphasize controversial aspects of the proposed solution
- also have trade-offs, and the time spent on writing a design document is time not spent on developing software.

[Template design doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/10V7WJiVGZZ47DiDwNF6N8-vQ86MRYy4po9PnSVTAwb0/edit)

When do we need design docs?

Design documents are ideal when the following conditions are met.

it)

When do we need design docs?

Design documents are ideal when the following conditions are met.

1. When the feature we will build has some ambiguity and we want to clarify the path forward before the implementation. This way we can avoid implementing a large future that will not meet our needs.
2. The feature is relatively complex and implementing/prototyping alternative ideas infeasible.

In cases where the feature scope is relatively small (the 2nd condition is not met), it is better to prototype alternative ideas. Prototyping will be explained in more detail in another section.

## What should design docs include?

1. Context and scope

This is a short section that gives an overview about the following

- Surrounding system we are building the feature into
- What feature we are building and why we are building it

1. Goals and non-goals

What are the goals of the feature? What are not our goals?

are building it

1. Goals and non-goals

What are the goals of the feature? What are not our goals?

Example for a long term forecasting feature (i.e. generate forecast for the next 6 months or so).

Goals: Runtime should be comparable to our short term forecasting modules

Non-goals: Real-time/low latency on demand forecasting

We might still want to include non-goals if a solution can achieve a non-goal without considerable trade-offs.

1. The actual design

Considering scope, context, goals and non-goals; this is the place to propose a solution. How you will present the design is flexible. However, it is important to emphasize trade-offs and controversial decisions about the design. It makes the reviewer’s job much easier if you tell them the parts they might not like about the design. Depending on the feature of interest, following tools might help you demonstrate your ideas clearly:

- System context diagram (How this new system fits in the overall landscape)

te your ideas clearly:

- System context diagram (How this new system fits in the overall landscape)

Figure 1. Demonstration of where rocks.core fits in the overall system

- Surface level API. Only demonstrate important parts related to the design and focus on trade-offs, avoid unnecessary details.

1. Considered alternatives

Explain what alternative designs are considered and what are the trade-offs that led to rejection of those ideas.

Example design doc: [scenario forecasting](https://docs.google.com/document/d/10p3BWhDBbkv61uAXTsWDPlCA7Zg-ovpl3WPKt2S7OoI/edit#heading=h.sg9pmh1xy51h). Note that this is a very extensive document and the design document for your feature might have a different structure

1. Backward compatibility

Does the proposed design require backward imcompatible changes? If so, how and to what extent?

1. Challenges

Possible challenges we will face while implementing the design and using the implemented feature.

1. Follow-up Task Suggestions

face while implementing the design and using the implemented feature.

1. Follow-up Task Suggestions

Describe the follow-up tasks to be followed for moving towards the implementation phase of this design work. Use a structured format (e.g. tables, bullet points) for task subjects and add a short paragraph describing:

- why this task is needed?
- how it can be implemented?

1. Reference work

Is there a reference work that can help people understand the design better? Avoid unnecessary details and try not to spend too much time for reference work.

## Prototyping

An alternative to design docs is prototyping. A prototype contains mostly the same information (context, scope, goals, non-goals, considered alternatives) as a design document. However, the proposed solution and alternatives are demonstrated by a mix of code snippets and English. If it is possible to prototype (small feature), prototyping is often a better choice.

The code in the prototype might be:

rototype (small feature), prototyping is often a better choice.

The code in the prototype might be:

- fully functional
- not functional (only the exposed API, required inputs, outputs etc.)
- or anything in between

A fully functional prototype example can be seen here: [rule-based-selection](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/noob-analysis/-/blob/main/rule-based-selection/rule_based_design.ipynb). Here, different user input formats are considered for a rule based forecast model selection feature, and each alternative is supported with a working implementation.

d forecast model selection feature, and each alternative is supported with a working implementation.

A not functional prototype example can be seen here: [ml experimentation design](https://gitlab.com/koraybeyaz/ml-experimentation/-/blob/main/ML%20Experimentation.ipynb). This document contains mostly non-functional code. You will get errors if you try to run any cell in the notebook. However, it demonstrates several components of the system, their relationships and how a user (imaginary) will interact with these components.

The process of preparing and reviewing design docs

The process should include the following steps:

The process of preparing and reviewing design docs

The process should include the following steps:

1. Prepare the design doc and share it with relevant parties. Google docs are ideal for design documents since it allows communication through comments.
2. Async review and iterations through comments/discussions
3. A meeting to discuss the design and finalize.
4. Update the document according to the finalized design. This final document will be useful for a long period of time.

The process of preparing and reviewing prototypes

1. Prepare the prototype, push it to a GitHub repository (preferably gensight-rd repository), leave it as an open merge request and tag relevant people.
2. Async review and iterations through comments/discussions
3. A meeting to discuss the design and finalize.
4. Update and merge the document to the main branch.

# Daily Digest RPL Formulas - Simple Mode

All formulas are calculated at store-product combination level unless otherwise specified.

## 1. Price and Cost Calculations

Average Sales Price (ASP):

- Average Sales Price = Total Sales Revenue divided by Total Sales Quantity
- Calculated over the lookback period (default 28 days)
- Grouped by product (or other configurable grouping)

Effective Price:

- Effective Price = Average Sales Price if available, otherwise use Price Without Tax

Price and Cost Imputation:Corrected Cost of Goods Sold (COGS):

- If COGS is missing or zero or negative:Corrected COGS = Effective Price × (1 - Default Average Margin)
- Otherwise:Corrected COGS = Original COGS

Corrected Price:

- If Effective Price is missing or zero or negative:Corrected Price = COGS ÷ (1 - Default Average Margin)
- Otherwise:Corrected Price = Effective Price

Default Average Margin: 30% (configurable)

## 2. Days of Supply Calculations

Average Sales Rates:Average Daily Sales:

metadata.title: Comprehensive List of All Formulas in the KPI Summary Generator - Daily Digest Agent - v0

content:
gin: 30% (configurable)

## 2. Days of Supply Calculations

Average Sales Rates:Average Daily Sales:

- Calculate raw average sales = Total Sales ÷ Lookback Days
- If raw average sales is zero, use the 5th percentile of all non-zero average sales values
- Average Sales = Raw Average Sales if greater than zero, otherwise use the imputed percentile value

Average Daily Forecast:

- Method 1 (Add Small Value): Average Forecast = (Cover Period Forecast + small value) ÷ (Cover Period + small value)
- Method 2 (Percentile Imputation): Calculate raw average forecast = Cover Period Forecast ÷ Cover PeriodIf raw average forecast is zero, use the 5th percentile of all non-zero average forecast valuesAverage Forecast = Raw Average Forecast if greater than zero, otherwise use the imputed percentile value

Days of Supply Metrics:Days of Supply:

- Days of Supply = Store Inventory On Hand ÷ Average Daily Sales
- Rounded to nearest whole number

Days of Supply Forecast:

content:
Inventory On Hand ÷ Average Daily Sales
- Rounded to nearest whole number

Days of Supply Forecast:

- Days of Supply Forecast = Store Inventory On Hand ÷ Average Daily Forecast
- Rounded to nearest whole number

Days of Supply Planned:

- Days of Supply Planned = Total Planned Inventory ÷ Average Daily Sales
- Rounded to nearest whole number

Days of Supply Forecast Planned:

- Days of Supply Forecast Planned = Total Planned Inventory ÷ Average Daily Forecast
- Rounded to nearest whole number

Total Planned Inventory:

- Total Planned Inventory = Store Inventory On Hand +Store Inventory In Transit (if available) +Store Inventory Open Order (if available) +Store Inventory Purchase Order (if available) +Constrained Quantity (if available)

## 3. Inventory Indicators

Total Inventory:

- Total Inventory = Store Inventory On Hand +Store Inventory In Transit (if available) +Store Inventory Open Order (if available) +Store Inventory Purchase Order (if available)

Overstock Threshold:

metadata.title: Comprehensive List of All Formulas in the KPI Summary Generator - Daily Digest Agent - v0

content:
ntory Open Order (if available) +Store Inventory Purchase Order (if available)

Overstock Threshold:

- Overstock Threshold = Final Target Inventory - 1 + Casepack Quantity

Overstocked Indicator:

- If Total Inventory exceeds Overstock Threshold:Overstocked Indicator = 1
- Otherwise:Overstocked Indicator = 0

Optimization Constraint:

- Optimization Constraint = Constrained Quantity - Unconstrained Quantity
- Negative values indicate insufficient inventory at distribution center

Casepack Loss:

- Casepack Loss = Rounded Need - Need
- Represents the difference due to casepack rounding requirements

Primary Constraint Type:

- If Optimization Constraint is negative:Primary Constraint Type = "Optimization Constraint"
- Else if Casepack Loss is negative:Primary Constraint Type = "Casepack Rounding"
- Otherwise:Primary Constraint Type = "Other"

## 4. Risk Metrics (Simple Mode)

Stockout Risk Calculations:Potential Stockout Days:

ype = "Other"

## 4. Risk Metrics (Simple Mode)

Stockout Risk Calculations:Potential Stockout Days:

- Potential Stockout Days = Days of Supply Forecast Planned - Cover Period
- Negative values indicate stockout risk

Is At Stockout Risk:

- If Days of Supply Forecast Planned is less than Cover Period:Is At Stockout Risk = 1 (Yes)
- Otherwise:Is At Stockout Risk = 0 (No)

Lost Sales Units:

- Lost Sales Units = Absolute value of (Potential Stockout Days × Average Daily Forecast)
- Potential Lost Sales = Lost Sales Units if at stockout risk, otherwise 0

Lost Sales Value:

- Lost Sales Value = Lost Sales Units × Corrected Price
- Potential Lost Sales Value = Lost Sales Value if at stockout risk and value is positive, otherwise 0

Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) of Lost Sales:

- Lost Sales COGS = Lost Sales Units × Corrected COGS
- Only calculated when at stockout risk

Potential Lost Margin:

metadata.title: Comprehensive List of All Formulas in the KPI Summary Generator - Daily Digest Agent - v0

content:
= Lost Sales Units × Corrected COGS
- Only calculated when at stockout risk

Potential Lost Margin:

- Potential Lost Margin = Lost Sales Value - Lost Sales COGS
- If at stockout risk and margin is positive:Potential Lost Margin = Lost Sales Value - Lost Sales COGS
- Otherwise:Potential Lost Margin = 0

Stockout Probability (Simple Mode):

- Lead Time Stockout Probability = 1.0 if at stockout risk, otherwise 0.0
- Cover Period Stockout Probability = 1.0 if at stockout risk, otherwise 0.0
- Note: In simple mode, probabilities are either 0 or 1 based on the stockout risk flag

Overstock and Constraint Values:Overstock Inventory Value:

- Overstock Amount = Total Inventory - Overstock Threshold (if positive, otherwise 0)
- Overstock Inventory Value = Overstock Amount × Corrected COGS

Overstock Units:

- Overstock Units = Total Inventory - Overstock Threshold (if positive, otherwise 0)

Total Inventory COGS:

- Total Inventory COGS = Total Inventory × Corrected COGS

tive, otherwise 0)

Total Inventory COGS:

- Total Inventory COGS = Total Inventory × Corrected COGS

Unfulfilled Demand Value:

- Unfulfilled Demand Value = (Unconstrained Quantity - Constrained Quantity) × Corrected Price

Allocated Revenue Contribution:

- Allocated Revenue Contribution = Constrained Quantity × Corrected Price
- If constrained quantity is missing, treated as zero

Lead Time Forecast:

- If cover period is greater than zero and cover period forecast is available:Lead Time Forecast = (Lead Time ÷ Cover Period) × Cover Period Forecast
- Otherwise:Lead Time Forecast = Not Available

Margin Per Unit:

- Margin Per Unit = Corrected Price - Corrected COGS

## 5. Percentage Change Calculations

Year-over-Year Percentage Changes:

- If last year value exists and is not zero:Percentage Change = (This Year Value - Last Year Value) ÷ Last Year Value
- Otherwise:Percentage Change = Not Available

Growth Rate Calculations:Recent Sales:

ise:Percentage Change = Not Available

## 6. Growth Analysis

Growth Rate Calculations:Recent Sales:

- Recent Sales = Sum of This Year sales quantity for the configured time window
- Example: Sum of sales for the last 14 days (ty__14_0_sales_quantity)

Historical Sales:

- Historical Sales = Sum of Last Year sales quantity for the configured time window
- Example: Sum of sales for the same 14-day period last year (ly__14_0_sales_quantity)

Growth Rate:

- If Historical Sales is greater than zero:Growth Rate = ((Recent Sales - Historical Sales) ÷ Historical Sales) × 100Expressed as a percentage, rounded to 2 decimal places
- Otherwise:Growth Rate = 100%

Absolute Growth:

- Absolute Growth = Recent Sales - Historical Sales
- Rounded to 2 decimal places

## 7. Aggregated Metrics (Aggregation done at product/location hierarchies)

- Expressed as a percentage, rounded to 2 decimal places

Fulfillment Rate:

- If Total Cover Period Need is greater than zero:Fulfillment Rate = (Total Allocated Quantity ÷ Total Cover Period Need) × 100Expressed as a percentage, rounded to 2 decimal places

Constraint Impact Percent:

- If Total Cover Period Need is greater than zero:Constraint Impact Percent = 100 - Fulfillment RateExpressed as a percentage, rounded to 2 decimal places

Availability Ratio:

- If Availability Ratio Denominator is greater than zero:Availability Ratio = (Availability Ratio Numerator ÷ Availability Ratio Denominator) × 100Expressed as a percentage, rounded to 2 decimal places

Average Weeks of Supply:

- Average Weeks of Supply = Average Days of Supply ÷ 7
- Rounded to nearest whole number

## 8. Health Score Calculation

Health Score Weights:

metadata.title: Comprehensive List of All Formulas in the KPI Summary Generator - Daily Digest Agent - v0

content:
Supply ÷ 7
- Rounded to nearest whole number

## 8. Health Score Calculation

Health Score Weights:

- Stockout Rate Weight: -25% (reduces score)
- Margin Loss Percent Weight: -20% (reduces score)
- Overstock Rate Weight: -15% (reduces score)
- Overstock Cost Percent Weight: -10% (reduces score)
- Fulfillment Rate Weight: +20% (increases score)

Health Score Formula:

- Start with base score of 100
- Subtract: Stockout Rate × 25%
- Subtract: Margin Loss Percent × 20%
- Subtract: Overstock Rate × 15%
- Subtract: Overstock Cost Percent × 10%
- Add: Fulfillment Rate × 20%
- Round to nearest whole number

Final Health Score:

- If calculated Health Score is less than 0, set to 0
- If calculated Health Score is greater than 100, set to 100
- Final Health Score is always between 0 and 100

metadata.title: Comprehensive List of All Formulas in the KPI Summary Generator - Daily Digest Agent - v0

content:
# 🧠 What is the UI Helper Agent?

The UI Helper Agent is a smart assistant designed to guide you through the features and capabilities of Invent.ai’s user interface pages.
It provides natural language explanations about what each page can do, how to use available filters, where to find key elements, and how to interact with the page more effectively.

The agent is powered by page-level documentation — it transforms the documentation into an easy-to-read conversational guide directly inside the UI.

---

# 💡 What Can the Agent Do?

The UI Helper Agent helps you:

✅ Explain the capabilities of the page you’re viewing
✅ Guide you through filters, dropdowns, and navigation options
✅ Clarify what different charts, tables, or KPIs represent
✅ Point you to available actions (e.g., exporting, applying constraints, running scenarios)
✅ Act as a context-aware helper — responses are always specific to the current page

metadata.title: UI Helper Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
nning scenarios)
✅ Act as a context-aware helper — responses are always specific to the current page

📌 It does not answer questions outside the scope of the current page — it only knows what’s documented for the screen you’re on.

---

# 💬 Example Questions You Can Ask

To help you get started, here are some examples of natural questions you can ask the UI Helper Agent:

- “What are the capabilities of this page?”
- “What filters can I apply here?”
- “What do the icons next to each KPI mean?”
- “How can I export the results shown on this page?”

These examples appear in the chatbox to give you inspiration — you can adapt them to your needs.

---

# 🚦 What the Agent Can’t Do

To set clear expectations, here’s what the UI Helper Agent does not support:

metadata.title: UI Helper Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
hat the Agent Can’t Do

To set clear expectations, here’s what the UI Helper Agent does not support:

| ❌ Not Supported | Notes |
| --- | --- |
| General-purpose small talk | Focused strictly on page functionality |
| Data analysis or calculations | Does not process or generate KPI values itself |
| Actions outside the current page | It only explains the page you’re on, not other parts of the UI |
| Changing system behavior | Read-only; it does not modify filters, constraints, or settings |
| Multi-page navigation | Guidance is scoped to the active page only |
| Menu Navigation help | It can’t help you to navigate through to menu. Only can help from current page’s documentation |

---

# 🚀 Getting Started – Step by Step

Step 1: Open the UI Helper Agent
The assistant appears on pages where the page help documentation is available.Examples

metadata.title: UI Helper Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
Helper Agent
The assistant appears on pages where the page help documentation is available.Examples

The assistant can’t be accessed from the Home Page.
The assistant can’t be accessed from the Report pages if they dont have a help documentation
The assistant can be accessed from “Store Replenishment Orders” page as it has a page help documentation

Step 2: Type Your Question
Use natural language to ask about the page’s capabilities (e.g., filters, KPIs, exports).

Step 3: Review the Answer
The agent will return explanations directly sourced from page documentation.

Step 4: Apply What You’ve Learned
Use the guidance to interact with the page more effectively — filter data, read KPIs, or export results.

---

# ✅ Best Practices

metadata.title: UI Helper Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
with the page more effectively — filter data, read KPIs, or export results.

---

# ✅ Best Practices

- Keep questions page-specific (e.g., “What does this constraint do?” rather than “What is safety stock?”).
- Use the wording shown in the UI (e.g., if a field is labeled “Min Discount Rate,” ask about “Min Discount Rate” directly).
- Start simple — short, direct questions yield the clearest responses.
- Refer to examples — the sample questions in the chatbox are a great starting point.

---

# 📞 Need Help?

If you believe the UI Helper Agent’s response is unclear or incomplete:

- 📬 Clients: Contact your support team at CLIENTNAME-service@invent.ai
- 💬 Internal testers: Share feedback and screenshots in Slack channel @agentic-ai-feedback

# 🧠 What is the Alert Reasoning Agent?

The Alert Reasoning Agent is a smart assistant designed to help you quickly understand and resolve specific alerts for product-store pairs. It acts as a guide, providing clear, step-by-step guidance to resolve issues efficiently.

---

# 💡 What Can the Agent Do?

The Alert Reasoning Agent helps you:

✅ Explain the reason for a specific alert

✅ Analyze the main root causes behind the alert

✅ Guide you through each root cause with actionable recommendations

✅ Direct you to the relevant pages needed to resolve issues

✅ Update the status of alerts once they are resolved

✅ Provide historical data insights to support its recommendations

📌 It acts as a focused problem solver, guiding you from alert detection to resolution.

---

# 🚦 What the Agent Can’t Do

To set clear expectations, here’s what the UI Helper Agent does not support:

metadata.title: Alert Reasoning Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
hat the Agent Can’t Do

To set clear expectations, here’s what the UI Helper Agent does not support:

| ❌ Not Supported | Notes |
| --- | --- |
| Target-increased-too-much specific | The current version resolves only the alerts of “target-increased-too-much” types. |
| Free-form chat | The agent provides pre-defined explanations and guides; it is not a conversational chatbot. |
| Data analysis or calculations | Does not process or generate KPI values itself. |
| Actions outside the current page | It only explains the alert you're on, not other parts of the UI. |
| Changing system behavior | Read-only; it only guides you on what to do, it does not modify filters or settings. |
| Multi-alert navigation | Guidance is scoped to the active alert only. |

---

# 🚀 Getting Started – Step by Step

Step 1: Go to Alert Review Page

Alert Reasoning Agent can be used in the Alert Review PageStep 2: Filter Target Spike Detected Alerts

metadata.title: Alert Reasoning Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
lert Reasoning Agent can be used in the Alert Review PageStep 2: Filter Target Spike Detected Alerts

Currently, only “Target Spike Detected” alerts can be explained with te Alert Reasoning agent. So you should filter it from the alert categories.

Firstly, select Store RPL Alerts under Alert Type, then select Target Spike Detected Alert. Finally, click to “Apply Filter” button.

Step 3: Access to the Agent

Click to Explain button under Actions column of the Data Grid. As each alert is explained individually, we access to each alert row in an independent way.

Step 4: Review the Agent's Explanation

The agent automatically provides an explanation and analysis of the alert, including its root causes.

You can click to root causes to see insights and actions for each root cause.

Step 5: Follow the Recommended Actions

The agent will direct you to the necessary pages and provide clear steps to resolve each root cause.

metadata.title: Alert Reasoning Agent – Client Training Guide

content:
The agent will direct you to the necessary pages and provide clear steps to resolve each root cause.

After you review these and make your decisions, you can return back to Alerts Review page by clicking to Return to Alerts ReviewStep 6:Update the Alert Status

Once all root causes are resolved, the agent will prompt you to update the alert's status to "Resolved." You can choose among:

- Resolving the alert. It will change the status of the alert
- Keep investigating and keeping status.
- Decide that this is not an alert and change its status to not alert.

Just click and submit your decision!

---

# ✅ Best Practices

- Follow the agent's guided path, as it's designed to ensure all necessary steps are completed.
- Use the agent's prompts to navigate to the correct pages for making adjustments.

- Lets any business user ask free-form questions about sales, inventory, price, cost, replenishment outputs, and other curated domains—without knowing schemas or SQL.
- Returns actionable results in one place: a governed data grid, with optional visualization and auto-generated insights, so users move from question → answer → explanation within a single flow.
- Keeps pace with the organization’s evolving data via incremental ingestion and curation (semantic layer + KPI registry + vector indexes), so coverage grows sprint-by-sprint rather than as one-off projects.
- Works alongside existing, page-embedded Data QA (e.g., Replenishment Results): we preserve domain-specific experiences while providing a unified, general “Ask” surface for everything else.
- Routes intelligently: queries that belong to existing Data-Grid services go through Cheetah backend APIs; open-ended questions run through a uniform data layer (UDL) with dialect adaptation—same UX, different backends.

uestions run through a uniform data layer (UDL) with dialect adaptation—same UX, different backends.
- Maintains guardrails demanded by enterprise analytics: deterministic entity/KPI handling, token budgets, SQL validation, server-side plan caching (no SQL leakage), and tenancy boundaries.

- Unlocks self-serve analytics for the long tail of questions that don’t fit a prebuilt dashboard or single domain page.
- Shortens time-to-insight by turning natural language directly into governed results, charts, and concise insights, reducing ad-hoc ticket backlogs for analysts/engineering.
- Standardizes definitions via a KPI registry and semantic layer so teams converge on the same measures and join paths—lowering rework and reconciliation costs.
- Scales with our roadmap: product squads can plug their data and APIs into the same orchestration pattern, benefiting from shared retrieval, planning, validation, and routing.
- Improves reliability and trust: consistent latency targets (Ask p95 ≤ 15s; Data-Grid p95 ≤ 18s), cost caps with auto-degrade, and transparent “why these tables/KPIs” affordances increase user confidence and adoption.

-degrade, and transparent “why these tables/KPIs” affordances increase user confidence and adoption.
- Builds a durable foundation for future capabilities: saved queries, scheduled insights, multilingual support, alerting, and GraphRAG-powered relationship discovery—without rethinking the UX or orchestration.

In short, we are moving from a single-page helper to a company-wide ad-hoc analytics surface that delivers governed answers (tables, visuals, insights) over continuously expanding data, with the same reliable UX whether a query runs through existing business services or the UDL. This is the right lever to scale decision-making, reduce bespoke reporting, and give every team faster access to consistent, trusted metrics.

## Impact

User impact

reporting, and give every team faster access to consistent, trusted metrics.

## Impact

User impact

- Universal entry point for ad-hoc questions. Reduces reliance on one-off analyst tickets; shortens time-to-insight.
- Consistent answers. A shared semantic layer and KPI registry align terminology and formulas across teams.
- Actionable flow. Results, visuals, and insights in a single surface encourage faster decisions.

Business impact

- Scalable coverage. We move from one page/one table to a sustainable way to curate dozens of tables and KPIs sprint-by-sprint.
- Operational leverage. Product squads reuse the same orchestration and governance patterns, accelerating delivery.
- Trust and governance. Deterministic planning, server-side SQL, and masking policies reduce risk and increase adoption.

Engineering impact

anning, server-side SQL, and masking policies reduce risk and increase adoption.

Engineering impact

- Clear separations of concern. Understanding (entity/KPI + retrieval), Planning (SQL), Execution (route-aware), each observable.
- Future-ready foundation. Enables features like saved questions, scheduled insights, multilingual support, and graph-aware retrieval without reworking the UX.

## Risks

Technical

- Relevance at scale. As coverage grows, retrieval quality can drift or overwhelm token budgets.
- KPI correctness. Misapplied formulas or missing dependencies erode trust.
- Cross-engine portability. Postgres-canonical SQL must remain portable to BigQuery/Databricks/DuckDB.
- Perceived latency. Users need responsive phases even when underlying execution is long-running.

Product/UX

- Expectation mismatch. Users may ask for domains that aren’t curated yet.
- Explainability. Without transparency, users won’t trust “why these tables/metrics.”

Operational/Security

inability. Without transparency, users won’t trust “why these tables/metrics.”

Operational/Security

- Cost creep. Unbounded tokens/calls can overshoot budgets.
- Data exposure. Surfacing SQL or PII in the client would be unacceptable.
- Upstream dependencies. Data profiling feeds and tenant labels must be timely and accurate.

Mitigation approach (high-level)

- Retrieval discipline (precedence, KPI-first dependencies, tiered compaction), validation before execution, plan/execute split with server-side caching, clear coverage indicators and “why” panels, budget caps with auto-degrade, PII masking, and tenant-scoped auth.

## Capabilities added & gaps closed

What we add

auto-degrade, PII masking, and tenant-scoped auth.

What we add

1. General-purpose Ask page returning governed data grids with optional Visualize and Analyze follow-ups.
2. Deterministic Understanding: Entity Mapping (with fuzzy KPI aliasing) + KPI Expansion to inject required tables/columns/join paths before planning.
3. Hybrid Retrieval with late-fusion (dense + BM25) that enforces KPI dependencies, honors hierarchical/semantic precedence, and compacts to a strict ≤ 5k-token payload.
4. Plan/Execute orchestration, always split, enabling a 4-state UX without long-lived requests.
5. No-leak Plan Cache: SQL lives server-side and is retrievable only by trusted services using plan_id.
6. Route-aware execution: Data-Grid queries run through Cheetah BE; free-form analytics run through UDL with dialect adaptation.
7. Semantic Layer with domain purpose lines, scoped synonyms, and precedence ladders plus tenant overrides.
8. KPI Registry with macro SQL, dependency graphs, join paths, and time-alignment policies.

errides.
8. KPI Registry with macro SQL, dependency graphs, join paths, and time-alignment policies.
9. Vector ingestion v2 (LanceDB on EFS) for tables, columns, and entity-value embeddings; integration with tenant labels and data-profiling feeds.
10. Observability across phases (Understanding, Planning, Execution) with cost and token governance.

What we close

- From single-table helper to org-wide ad-hoc analytics.
- From prompt stuffing to curated semantic/KPI control planes.
- From opaque long calls to phase-visible, responsive UX.
- From potential SQL exposure to server-side plans only on Data-Grid flows.

Understanding pipeline

ng) for live phases in a later upgrade; SSE only if trivial through proxies.

Understanding pipeline

- Entity Mapping (deterministic, English-first): TB/EX/K/CALC/CP/EF/M/T/N; strict EF gating; ≤ 3 resolves.
- KPI aliasing: dictionary + regex + normalization; canonicalize ambiguous terms into KPI candidates.
- KPI Expansion: required deps, join paths, time alignment, token reservation, and boosts.
- Retrieval (late-fusion): Dense + BM25 recall; preliminary rerank; merge KPI deps; hierarchical & precedence-aware column selection; compaction to ≤ 4k tokens.

Planning & validation

- SQL generation: single-statement, Postgres canonical, explicit columns, safe division, default time windows when implied.
- Validation: syntax & allowlists; one augment + retry on unknown objects.
- Dialect adaptation: UDL/sqlglot to BigQuery/Databricks/DuckDB with fixtures.

Governance planes

s.
- Dialect adaptation: UDL/sqlglot to BigQuery/Databricks/DuckDB with fixtures.

Governance planes

- Semantic Layer (YAML→JSON): purpose, synonyms, precedence ladders (product/store/time), FK edges, defaults; tenant overlays.
- KPI Registry: macro DSL with placeholders, dependencies, join paths, time-alignment; unit tests per KPI.

Data plumbing

- Vector ingestion v2 (LanceDB/EFS): tables, columns, EF values; nightly increments; weekly profiling feed from Data Platform to include/exclude low-quality objects; tenant labels from BFF.

Observability & guardrails

- Phase timers (entity_map_ms, retrieval_ms, planning_ms, validation_ms, execute_ms), coverage, EF hit-rate, validator pass-rate, token/cost metrics; $200 cap auto-degrade; SLO dashboards (Ask p95 ≤ 15s; Data-Grid p95 ≤ 18s).

### Alternatives we considered (and why we chose this)

boards (Ask p95 ≤ 15s; Data-Grid p95 ≤ 18s).

### Alternatives we considered (and why we chose this)

- Micro-barrier vs late-fusion for KPI deps: We chose parallel + late-fusion, which guarantees KPI coverage with negligible p95 overhead and preserves early recall.
- Monolithic “plan+execute” call: Rejected—too fragile for LB timeouts and obscures UX phases; we standardize on plan and execute as separate calls.
- SSE/WebSockets: Useful for live phases, but optional; we’ll adopt only if proxy behavior is trivial and stable.
- LLM-only retrieval (no semantic/KPI planes): Rejected—higher variance, less explainable, and poor scalability.

### What needs research / proof-of-value

d—higher variance, less explainable, and poor scalability.

### What needs research / proof-of-value

- GraphRAG pilot: FK + usage graphs to improve join path recall and column disambiguation.
- Embedding mixes: Text construction and dimension variants (still OpenAI embeddings) for better table/column P@K.
- Multilingual: Turkish KPI/entity alias sets and tokenizer impacts; EM/KPI Registry internationalization.
- Engine edge cases: Deeper coverage of time functions, quoting rules, and partition pruning across engines.
- Automated table rollout: Programmatic stubs for synonyms/precedence from data profiling + minimal human curation.

## Entity Mapping (query understanding)

Normalize natural-language into structured terms that drive retrieval and safe SQL generation.What:

- Entity Mapping with deterministic codes (TB/EX/K/CALC/CP/EF/M/T/N) and strict EF gates (max 1 resolver calls).
- Role assignment for EF (Product|Store) with confidence ≥ 0.70.
- EX precedence for code-like tokens and dictionary hits (no resolver call).

How:

- Serve a lean payload (≤ 5k tokens): table name + 1-line purpose, PKs/FKs/time columns, selected columns (short alias only), minimal FK subgraph.
- EX precedence (codes/dictionary) → skip resolver; EF uses tenant value indexes (LanceDB) with relevance search
- Token budgeter removes Tier D → Tier C → extra measures → lowest-scoring table while keeping the FK spine valid.
- Evaluation: Table/Column Precision@K, metadata tokens, EF hit-rate to drive improvements.

Inputs

- query: string, tenant_id: string, optional context: {page: "data_grid"|"ask"}.

Outputs (strict JSON)

metadata.title: 2. Data QA v2 Design Part 2 - Components

content:
uery: string, tenant_id: string, optional context: {page: "data_grid"|"ask"}.

Outputs (strict JSON)

```
{
  "terms": [
    {"term":"Accessories","codes":["EF"],"role":"Product","tool_status":"ok",
     "resolved":{"top_table":"products","top_column":"product_group_2_description","confidence":0.91,"hits":[...]}},
    {"term":"sales","codes":["K"],"mapped_to":"sales_quantity"},
    {"term":"last 4 weeks","codes":["T"]}
  ]
}
```

Hard constraints

- Never mark KPI/indicator words as EF (inventory, revenue, trend*…).
- EF column must belong to an allowlisted attribute family (brand, product_group_n_description, city/state/region…).
- English-only parsing in v1; code paths prepared for TR later.

Acceptance

- ≥ 95% of code-ish IDs (e.g., STORE001) mapped as EX (no resolver).
- EF resolver success rate ≥ 70% on curated tenants; abstention over false positives.

## Relevant Table/Column Retrieval (lean metadata ≤ 5k tokens)

Why: Latency and SQL correctness depend on sending a small, correct metadata slice.

We will build

- Hybrid recall (OpenAI embeddings + BM25) for tables and columns.
- Reranking with weights.  Starting with Dense ranks first. We will consider weighting later.For example: 0.45*dense + 0.35*bm25 + 0.10*alias_overlap + 0.05*join_degree + 0.05*usage_popularity.
- Hierarchical & Manually-prioritized column selection tied to a semantic layer (precedence ladders for product/store/time, domain-specific measure priority, e.g., Sales → sales_quantity, sales_revenue first).
- (Optional) KPI-aware retrieval: if K/CALC maps to a KPI, we must include required tables/columns (e.g., margin pulls cost tables).

Inputs

- terms from C1, tenant_id, LanceDB indices (tables/columns/EF values), semantic layer, KPI registry.

Outputs (served to LLM)

metadata.title: 2. Data QA v2 Design Part 2 - Components

content:
, LanceDB indices (tables/columns/EF values), semantic layer, KPI registry.

Outputs (served to LLM)

```
{
  "tables": {
    "sales": {
      "purpose":"Sales aggregated at day level",
      "pk":["product_id","store_id","date"],
      "fk":[{"col":"product_id","ref":"product.product_id"},{"col":"store_id","ref":"store.store_id"}],
      "time":["date"],
      "columns":[ "sales_quantity","sales_revenue","product_id","store_id","date","product_group_2_description","region" ]
    },
    "...": { "...": "..." }
  },
  "relationships":[ {"from":"sales.product_id","to":"product.product_id","cardinality":"m:1"}, ... ]
}

```

Token budgeter

- Hard cap ≤ 5K tokens for mapping + retrieval payload jointly.

Acceptance

- Table P@K ≥ 0.80; Column P@K ≥ 0.65 on golden set.
- Payload token count never exceeds 5K.
- KPI dependency coverage: 100% inclusion for mapped KPIs.

## SQL Generation (single statement, Postgres canonical)

Why:Produce one safe, executable SQL that respects metadata and route constraints.

We will build

- OpenAI prompt that outputs {"sql":"...;"} (single statement), canonical Postgres.
- Use provided FK edges; default LIMIT 100 for preview; prefer explicit column list.
- Time defaults (e.g., last 12 weeks) when query implies recency but no range given.

Inputs

- query, terms, retrieval payload, KPI hints, Entity Mapping

Outputs

`{"sql":"SELECT ... FROM ... JOIN ... WHERE ... LIMIT 100;"}`

Acceptance

- Validator pass ≥ 90%.
- No SELECT *; joins only on provided FK edges unless the plan explicitly states otherwise.

## SQL Validation (safety & dialect prep)

Why:Protect tenants and reduce execution errors.

We will build

metadata.title: 2. Data QA v2 Design Part 2 - Components

content:
Validation (safety & dialect prep)

Why:Protect tenants and reduce execution errors.

We will build

- Syntax check, allowed_tables per tenant, LIMIT enforcement, optional time filter guard for “recent” intents.
- One augment + retry: if unknown table/column, fetch object + FK edge then re-prompt once.

Inputs

- SQL, Tenant Policy

Outputs

- {ok: boolean, errors:[], warnings:[], augmented?:payload}

Acceptance

- Unknown-object errors reduced by ≥ 50% with augment+retry.
- No cross-tenant object access.

## Routing (uniform UX, different backends)

Why:We support both free-form SQL and functional Data-QA supported by Cheetah Backend APIs.

We will build

- Rules-based router:Data-Grid context → Cheetah Backend APIs.Ask context → UDL (raw SQL execution).
- Router sets the backend route; UX remains the same.

Inputs

- context.page

Outputs

- {route: "cheetah_backend" | "udl"}

Acceptance

- 100% deterministic route based on context config.

Acceptance

## Plan Cache & Execution (no SQL leakage)

Why:Prevent SQL from appearing in browser/network tools; improve perceived latency.

We will build

- Plan Cache: GenAI stores sql under plan_id in Redis/ElastiCache/InMemory (TTL 5 min).
- GenAI returns {plan_id, plan_summary} to BFF (Cheetah BE) → UI moves to Planning Ready immediately.
- BFF/Backend fetches SQL using plan_id server-to-server, executes, streams results.

Inputs/Outputs

- POST /understand → terms, metadata, fk_edges (Metadata stored server-side)
- POST /plan → {plan_id, plan_summary, route} (SQL stored server-side)
- POST /execute {plan_id} (backend only) → rows/schema

Acceptance

- SQL never leaves the server boundary on Data-Grid routes.
- “Planning Ready” visible to users independently of execution completion.

## UX Orchestration (4 states, phase streaming)

Why:Perceived responsiveness and clarity.

We will build

metadata.title: 2. Data QA v2 Design Part 2 - Components

content:
Orchestration (4 states, phase streaming)

Why:Perceived responsiveness and clarity.

We will build

- Four states with microcopy and progress stepper:Understanding (C1 + C2)Query Planning (C3 + C4)Planning ready — fetching data (C5 + C6)Results (table, actions)
- Entity chips, “Why these tables” details (safe summary), routing pill.
- Skeleton table while executing.

Event stream

- PREPLANNING_START, PREPLANNING_DONE,PLANNING_START (query generation), PLANNING_DONE, EXECUTION_START, EXECUTE_DONE, ERROR.

Acceptance

- Users consistently see Pre Planning Ready within p95 ≤ 5s, Planning Ready within p95 ≤ 15s  for typical queries.
- No SQL displayed on Data-Grid pages.

## Visualization (post-result, optional)

Why:Quick insight without blocking the first result.

We will build

- /viz endpoint generating a chart spec and (if needed) viz SQL aligned to the same metric and time grain.
- Non-blocking; rendered only on user action.

## Data Analysis (post-result, optional)

Why:Explain results via short, actionable insights.

We will build

- /analyze endpoint that returns 3–5 bullets (trends/outliers/drivers) from the returned data or a small summary SQL.

Acceptance

- p95 ≤ 6s; insights link back to filters where possible.

Synonyms

- Table synonyms live under tables:; column synonyms are nested under columns: in each table.
- Synonyms are scoped to their table to avoid cross-table collisions.
- We restrict synonym list length (e.g., ≤ 20 per column) to keep index sparse and the prompt lean.
- We disallow KPI names as synonyms for entities and vice versa.

Tenancy & overrides

- Files can be authored as global then overlaid by tenant overrides provided by the Cheetah Metadata Service: tenant overrides win (union-merge lists, replace scalars).
- We will save merged results to the vector database for retrieval capabilities.

metadata.title: 2. Data QA v2 Design Part 2 - Components

content:
, replace scalars).
- We will save merged results to the vector database for retrieval capabilities.

Integration with LanceDB & retrieval

- Table embeddings are computed over: name + purpose + table_synonyms.
- Column embeddings are computed over: table + column + role + top 1–2 aliases + short purpose.
- We do not push long descriptions or all synonyms into served metadata—only into LanceDB for recall.

Acceptance

- Precedence respected in retrieval (Tier B/C) and reflected in P@K gains.
- All curated tables have one-line purpose and correct FK sets.
- For curated tables, retrieval achieves Table P@K ≥ 0.80 and Column P@K ≥ 0.65 on the golden set.
- No synonym collisions causing cross-table misroutes in the golden set.

## KPI Registry

We canonicalize KPI definitions as parameterized SQL macros and explicitly declare dependencies (tables, columns, join paths, constraints) so retrieval and generation never miss required data (e.g., `margin` → requires `cost`).

```yaml
version: "1.0"
tenant: "<tenant_id|global>"
kpis:
  - name: margin
    aliases: [gross_margin, gm]
    category: financial
    default_grain: day            # day | week | month | quarter | year | any
    type: absolute                # absolute | ratio | rate | windowed
    macro_sql: |
      -- expects: revenue_col, cost_col
      (${revenue_col} - ${cost_col})
    required_tables:
      - sales
      - cost
    required_columns:
      sales:
        - sales_revenue
      cost:
        - cost_amount
    join_paths:
      - from: sales.product_id
        to: product.product_id
      - from: sales.date
        to: cost.date            # or cost.effective_date with policy below
      - from: sales.product_id
        to: cost.product_id
    time_alignment:
      policy: exact               # exact | nearest_prior | within:N_days
      params: { within_days: 0 }
    constraints:
      - name: non_negative_revenue
        check: "sales_revenue >= 0"
      - name: matching_keys

KPI Definition Rules

metadata.title: 2. Data QA v2 Design Part 2 - Components

        grain: week

```

KPI Definition Rules

- ${identifier} placeholders must come from defaults or be resolvable from required tables/columns.
- macro_sql is dialect-agnostic at authoring time; we compile to the target dialect with UDL/sqlglot.
- We support helper expressions under dependency_logic to pre-compute inputs (e.g., moving averages).

Retrieval integration (hard requirements)

When `K` or `CALC` maps to a registry KPI:

1. We must include required_tables and required_columns in the retrieval payload (Tier A/B).
2. We reserve tokens for these dependencies before allocating Tier C/D dims.
3. We add join_paths edges to the FK subgraph if not already present.

SQL generation integration

metadata.title: 2. Data QA v2 Design Part 2 - Components

content:
s.
3. We add join_paths edges to the FK subgraph if not already present.

SQL generation integration

- We pass a macro hint: kpi_name, resolved placeholders, and any helper expressions.
- The generator composes metric expressions in the SELECT and uses join_paths to constrain joins.
- For ratios, we enforce safe division (NULLIF(x,0)).
- We align grain to default_grain unless the query states otherwise.

Example

```
{
  "kpi_hint": {
    "name": "margin",
    "macro_sql": "(${revenue_col} - ${cost_col})",
    "placeholders": {"revenue_col":"sales.sales_revenue","cost_col":"cost.cost_amount"},
    "join_paths":[["sales.product_id","cost.product_id"],["sales.date","cost.date"]],
  }
}

```

## Relevant Table/Column Retrieval with Late Fusion

Goal: Keep retrieval fast; inject KPI dependencies after baseline without adding a blocking barrier.

metadata.title: 2. Data QA v2 Design Part 2 - Components

Goal: Keep retrieval fast; inject KPI dependencies after baseline without adding a blocking barrier.

```
[GenAI Orchestrator]
  ├─▶ (1) Entity Mapping (incl. KPI fuzzy aliasing) ──▶ terms ─┐
  └─▶ (2) Retrieval (recall + prelim rerank) ──▶ candidates ───┤   (parallel)
  ├─▶ (3) KPI Expansion (rules) ───────▶ kpi_hint
                           │
            Late-Fusion (inject KPI deps,compaction)
                           │

```

metadata.title: 2. Data QA v2 Design Part 2 - Components

content:
│
            Late-Fusion (inject KPI deps,compaction)
                           │

```

1. Baseline Retrieval (no wait):Recall: dense ANN (OpenAI embeddings) + BM25 for tables & columns.Candidate set: top-K tables & columns, FK spine.
2. Late-Fusion (as soon as KPI Hint arrives from Entity Mapping):Min-inclusion: force-include required_tables/columns.Boosts: add KPI boosts to scores; inject join_paths edges if missing.Compaction under ≤5k total (mapping + retrieval):Drop order: Tier D → Tier C (lowest) → extra measures → lowest-scoring table; never drop KPI deps or FK spine.
3. Hand-off to SQL Generation:The fused lean payload is the only metadata passed to LLM.

Edge cases & guardrails

- If KPI Hint arrives unusually late (rare), we will still finalize Understanding only after late-fusion.
- If KPI cannot be recognized (alias misses), we proceed with baseline; SQL-time augment & retry remains the safety net.

Acceptance

metadata.title: 2. Data QA v2 Design Part 2 - Components

content:
lias misses), we proceed with baseline; SQL-time augment & retry remains the safety net.

Acceptance

- KPI dependency coverage = 100% in the final payload.
- Additional p95 overhead for late-fusion ≤120 ms vs baseline retrieval.
- Payload never exceeds 5k tokens.

## Dialect Adaptation (Postgres → BigQuery/Databricks/DuckDB)

Why
 We support multiple engines without changing prompts.

We will build

- Postgres as canonical; UDL/sqlglot to adapt for BigQuery/Databricks/DuckDB.
- Engine fixtures for date functions, quoting, LIMIT semantics.

Acceptance

- 100% of golden queries transpile and execute across engines in staging.

metadata.title: 2. Data QA v2 Design Part 2 - Components

content:
# High-level Workstreams

1. Preprocessing: Entity Mapping (EX/EF/T/K/CALC/CP) + Relevant Table/Column Retrieval with hierarchical & manual prioritization, token ≤ 5k.
2. SQL Generation & Validation: OpenAI prompts, single-statement JSON, LIMIT, allowlists, dialect adaptation (Postgres default → BigQuery/Databricks/DuckDB via UDL).
3. Vector DB (LanceDB/EFS): ingestion redesign, tenant labels from BFF, profiling feed, EF scale (10^6 product names).
4. Semantic Layer & KPI Registry: per-sprint curation of 10 tables, KPI macros + dependency maps,
5. Routing & Execution: Data Grids in Existing Page → Cheetah Backend; Data QA Ask Page → UDL.
6. UX: 4 states, skeletons, plan-ready transition, viz/analysis after results.
7. Observability & Cost: per-stage p50/p95, tokens, EF hit-rate, $ guardrails

# Orchestration Flow

[UI] ──▶ [BFF] ──▶ [GenAI Orchestrator]

├─▶ (1) Entity Mapping (incl. KPI fuzzy aliasing) ──▶ terms ─┐

content:
] ──▶ [BFF] ──▶ [GenAI Orchestrator]

├─▶ (1) Entity Mapping (incl. KPI fuzzy aliasing) ──▶ terms ─┐

└─▶ (2) Retrieval (recall + prelim rerank) ──▶ candidates ───┤   (parallel)

├─▶ (3) KPI Expansion (rules) ───────▶ kpi_hint

│

Late-Fusion (inject KPI deps,compaction)

│

▶ Lean Metadata (≤5k tokens)

▶ SQL Generation (Postgres canonical)

▶ Validation (+ augment & retry safety net)

▶ Plan Cache (plan_id) → Execution route

# 1. Components & Responsibilities

### Frontend (FE)

- Renders the 4 states: Understanding → Query Planning → Planning Ready / Fetching → Results.
- Calls BFF with the user query and shows phase updates.
- Never handles raw SQL on Data-Grid flows; may show SQL on Ask flow if feature-flagged.

### BFF (Cheetah BE, NodeJS)

metadata.title: 1. Data QA v2 Design Part 1 - Orchestration Flow

content:
w SQL on Data-Grid flows; may show SQL on Ask flow if feature-flagged.

### BFF (Cheetah BE, NodeJS)

- Single entry point for FE; attaches tenant & auth context.
- Proxies to GenAI; enforces timeouts, retries, and cancellation.
- On Data-Grid flows: calls the relevant Cheetah Backend APIs to execute plans (server-to-server).
- Hides raw SQL from FE using plan_id (opaque handle).
- Emits phase progress to FE (simulated under Option A; “real” under Option B/C).

### GenAI Services (Fargate)

- Understanding: Entity Mapping (with fuzzy KPI aliasing) + KPI Expansion (parallel) + Retrieval (late-fusion) → lean metadata ≤ 5k.
- Planning: SQL generation (Postgres canonical) + validation.
- Plan Cache: stores SQL under plan_id (TTL 5-15 min).
- Execution: (Ask) → UDL with dialect adaptation; (Data-Grid) executed by Cheetah BE using plan_id.
- Emits observability and phase markers; enforces cost/latency guardrails.

---

# 2. UX Phase ↔ Orchestration Mapping

content:

---

# 2. UX Phase ↔ Orchestration Mapping

| UX State | What Happens | Who Drives It | Artifacts |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Understanding | EM (w/ KPI aliasing) + KPI Expansion + Retrieval (late-fusion) | GenAI | terms, kpi_hint, lean_metadata, fk_edges, route_hint |
| Query Planning | SQL generation + validation (+ augment & retry 1×) | GenAI | plan_id (SQL stored server-side), plan_summary, dialect |
| Planning ready — fetching… | Server-to-server execution starts | BFF→Cheetah or GenAI→UDL | exec_id, ETA, run stats |
| Results | Tabular data shown, CTAs for Viz/Analysis | FE | rows, schema |

> Key: On Data-Grid flows, FE never sees SQL. On Ask, we may show SQL by feature flag.

---

# 3. Orchestration Options (A/B/C/D)

content:
never sees SQL. On Ask, we may show SQL by feature flag.

# 3. Orchestration Options (A/B/C/D)

Principle: The FE always calls the BFF, never direct-to-GenAI or Cheetah BE. The BFF proxies requests, injects tenant/auth context, enforces timeouts/retries, and prevents SQL leakage by using `plan_id` handles.

We always split plan and execute into separate requests.
No API bundles the two steps in one HTTP call. This avoids long-lived requests and load-balancer timeouts and cleanly supports the 4-state UX. We will inform user during the progress instead of making them wait long with no information.

## Endpoints (FE → BFF → services)

- /data-qa/understand → Query Understanding (EM + KPI Expansion) + Retrieval (late-fusion) → lean metadata ≤ 4k (no SQL)
- /data-qa/plan → SQL generation + validation → plan_id (SQL stored server-side), plan_summary, route
- /data-qa/execute → run by plan_id (UDL path only; Data-Grid path executes in Cheetah BE)

### Timeouts (defaults)

metadata.title: 1. Data QA v2 Design Part 1 - Orchestration Flow

content:
ute → run by plan_id (UDL path only; Data-Grid path executes in Cheetah BE)

### Timeouts (defaults)

- understand: 8–10s (target p95 ≤ 5s)
- plan: 8–10s (target p95 ≤ 8s; includes 1 augment+retry)
- execute: 10s per page (pagination/streaming allowed)
- Plan Cache TTL: 5-15 minutes

## Core synchronous flow (Option A — Multiple-call baseline)

### 1) FE → BFF → GenAI: /data-qa/understand

- Purpose: Query understanding + KPI-aware retrieval with late-fusion, all within the Understanding UX state.
- GenAI work: Entity Mapping (with fuzzy KPI aliasing), KPI Expansion (rules), Retrieval → Late-fusion → Lean metadata ≤5k.
- BFF returns to FE: Understanding payload (no SQL): terms, route hint, and safe plan preface.
- Lean metadata is stored in server-side: Do not leak the metadata

Request

```
POST /data-qa/understand
{
  "context": { "page": "data_grid" | "ask" },
  "query": "gm% by category last 4 weeks",
  "client_request_id": "uuid-..."
}

```

Response

  "client_request_id": "uuid-..."
}

  "kpi_hint": [ ... ],
  "route_hint": "cheetah_be" | "udl",      // router suggestion
}

```

### 2) FE → BFF → GenAI: /data-qa/plan

- Purpose: Compile SQL from lean metadata, validate, store SQL server-side, return plan_id + plan summary (no SQL to FE).
- UX: Transition to Query Planning, then Planning ready — fetching… immediately upon success.

Request

```
POST /data-qa/plan
{
  "context": { "page": "data_grid" | "ask" },
  "query": "gm% by category last 4 weeks",
  "lean_metadata": { ... }
}

```

Response

```
{
  "plan_id": "uuid-...",
  "plan_summary": "sales JOIN cost on (product_id,date); last 4w; gm%",
  "route": "cheetah_be" | "udl",
  "dialect": "postgres",
  "phases": { "planning_ms": 900, "validation_ms": 80 }
}

```

> Plan Cache (GenAI internal): plan_id → { sql, route, tenant_id, ttl=5m, created_at }. Accessible server-to-server only (BFF/Cheetah). Ensures no SQL leakage to FE.

### 3A) Route = cheetah_be (Data-Grid path)

- FE → BFF → Cheetah: execute using plan_id (no SQL exposed).
- Cheetah → GenAI: GET /plan/{plan_id} (server-to-server) to retrieve SQL, then execute (BigQuery/Postgres).
- FE → BFF → Cheetah /execute { plan_id }Cheetah fetches SQL server-to-server: GenAI GET /plan/{plan_id}Cheetah executes (BigQuery/Postgres), streams results to BFF → FEFE → BFF → GenAI /data-qa/understand
FE → BFF → GenAI /data-qa/plan  ── stores SQL → plan_id
FE → BFF → Cheetah /execute {plan_id}
Cheetah → GenAI /plan/{plan_id}  (server-to-server) → execute → results
- UX: Planning ready — fetching… → Results.

BFF → Cheetah request

```
POST /cheetah/execute
{
  "plan_id": "uuid-...",

```

### 3B) Route = udl (Ask path)

- FE → BFF → /data-qa/understandFE → BFF → /data-qa/plan → returns { plan_id, plan_summary, route=udl }FE → BFF → /data-qa/execute { plan_id }GenAI executes via UDL (dialect adaptation), streams results to BFF → FEFE → BFF → GenAI /data-qa/understand
FE → BFF → GenAI /data-qa/plan      ── stores SQL → plan_id
FE → BFF → GenAI /data-qa/execute {plan_id}  ── UDL run → results

> Result: The Ask path never couples plan+execute in a single request; it always goes plan → execute as separate calls.
