## UX ↔ API mapping (Option A)

| UX State | FE Action (via BFF) | GenAI/Cheetah behavior | FE display |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Understanding | POST /data-qa/understand | EM + KPI Expansion + Retrieval → Lean metadata | “Identifying entities and relevant tables…” |
| Query Planning | POST /data-qa/plan | SQL + validate + Plan Cache → plan_id | “Understanding is completed… Query Planning starts…” |
| Planning ready — fetching… | If cheetah_be: POST /cheetah/execute {plan_id}; If udl: POST /data-qa/execute {plan_id} | Execute | “Plan compiled. Executing query…” |
| Results | — | — | Table + CTAs (Visualize/Analyze) |

## Option B — Job + Polling (target upgrade)

We encapsulate both Understanding and Planning as a job for true phase fidelity (keeping your endpoints as building blocks).

### New high-level endpoints

metadata.title: 1. Data QA v2 Design Part 1 - Orchestration Flow

content:
b for true phase fidelity (keeping your endpoints as building blocks).

### New high-level endpoints

- POST /data-qa/start → { job_id } immediately (kicks off Understand → Plan)
- GET /data-qa/status?job_id=… → { phase, artifacts, eta, errors? }
- POST /data-qa/execute?job_id=… or auto-execute when PLAN_READY (configurable)

Phases

```
QUEUED → UNDERSTANDING → RETRIEVAL_DONE → PLANNING → PLAN_READY → EXECUTING → DONE
(error: ERROR, CANCELED)

```

Artifacts at PLAN_READY

```
{
  "plan_id": "uuid-...",
  "plan_summary": "sales JOIN cost ... ; last 4w",
  "route": "cheetah_be" | "udl",
  "dialect": "postgres"
}

```

Polling cadence: 250ms → 500ms → 1s → 2s (cap), jittered.
Cancel: `POST /data-qa/cancel?job_id=...` cancels GenAI work and DB cursor.

> Internally, GenAI still uses the same /data-qa/understand and /data-qa/plan service routines; the job orchestrator manages phase outputs and timing.

## Option C — SSE (adopt only if trivial through LB/BFF)

metadata.title: 1. Data QA v2 Design Part 1 - Orchestration Flow

content:
estrator manages phase outputs and timing.

## Option C — SSE (adopt only if trivial through LB/BFF)

Event stream for live phases (no polling):

```
GET /data-qa/events?job_id=...
event: ENTITY_MAP_DONE
event: RETRIEVAL_DONE
event: SQL_READY      // PLAN_READY
event: EXECUTE_DONE
event: ERROR

```

- BFF proxy-passes SSE from GenAI; FE uses EventSource to update the 4-state UI in real time.
- Keep Option B endpoints for fallback or reconnection (status on resume).
- Adopt only if our LB/BFF stack handles idle timeouts and backpressure with minimal work.

## Option D — WebSocket (reserve)

- Only if infra is already WS-friendly with low effort.
- Provides the same phase messages as SSE, plus potential FE→server “cancel” without an extra HTTP call.

# 4. Security & No-Leak Guarantees

metadata.title: 1. Data QA v2 Design Part 1 - Orchestration Flow

content:
E, plus potential FE→server “cancel” without an extra HTTP call.

# 4. Security & No-Leak Guarantees

- AuthN/Z: FE → BFF with JWT; BFF → GenAI with mTLS/IAM; all plan & execution lookups are tenant-scoped.
- plan_id: opaque UUID bound to {tenant, route, created_at, TTL}; server-only SQL retrieval (Cheetah/GenAI).
- Ask page: optional feature flag to display SQL to power users; Data-Grid never shows SQL.

# 5. Observability & Correlation

- IDs: nlq_job_id (Option B/C), plan_id, client_request_id, tenant_id — logged on every hop.
- Phase timers: entity_map_ms, retrieval_ms, late_fusion_ms, planning_ms, validation_ms, execute_ms.
- Quality & cost: metadata_tokens, sql_tokens, ef_hit_rate, validator_pass_rate, coverage%, $ / query.
- SLO dashboards: Ask p95 ≤ 15s; Data-Grid p95 ≤ 18s; monthly cost ≤ $200 with auto-degrade logs when limits hit.

```
FE           BFF                GenAI                     Cheetah BE
│ POST /data-qa/understand
├──────────▶│──────────────────▶│ (EM + KPI + Retrieval → Lean metadata)
│ ◀─────────┤◀──────────────────┤ { lean_metadata, route_hint }
│ POST /data-qa/plan
├──────────▶│──────────────────▶│ plan + validate; store SQL → plan_id
│ ◀─────────┤◀──────────────────┤ { plan_id, plan_summary, route=cheetah_be }
│ show "Planning ready — fetching…"
│ POST /cheetah/execute {plan_id}
├──────────▶│────────────────────────────────────────────────────────▶│
│           │                                                        ├── GET /plan/{plan_id}
│           │                                                        │     (server-to-server)
│           │                                                        │◀────────────────────────
│           │                                                        │ execute SQL; stream rows

content:
────
│           │                                                        │ execute SQL; stream rows
│ ◀─────────┤◀────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ render results

```

### 6.2 Option B (Job + Polling) — Ask

```
FE            BFF                  GenAI
│ POST /data-qa/start
├────────────▶│───────────────────▶│ job_id; start UNDERSTANDING → PLAN_READY
│ ◀───────────┤◀───────────────────┤ { job_id }
│ GET /data-qa/status?job_id=...
├────────────▶│───────────────────▶│ phase: UNDERSTANDING/RETRIEVAL_DONE/PLANNING/PLAN_READY
│ ◀───────────┤◀───────────────────┤ { phase, artifacts: { plan_id, route } }
│ POST /data-qa/execute?job_id=...
├────────────▶│───────────────────▶│ EXECUTING → DONE (or auto-exec)
│ ◀───────────┤◀───────────────────┤ { rows, schema }

```

### 6.3 Option C (SSE) — Ask (if trivial)

```
FE (EventSource) ──▶ BFF ──▶ GenAI  (GET /nlq/events?job_id=…)
events: ENTITY_MAP_DONE, RETRIEVAL_DONE, SQL_READY, EXECUTE_DONE

```

metadata.title: 1. Data QA v2 Design Part 1 - Orchestration Flow

content:
AI  (GET /nlq/events?job_id=…)
events: ENTITY_MAP_DONE, RETRIEVAL_DONE, SQL_READY, EXECUTE_DONE

```

# 7. Discovery Week (Sprint 0) — What we deliver

- Day 1: Constraints & timeouts (LB/BFF/GenAI), cancel semantics, error model.
- Day 2: Spikes for Option A (with plan_id/Plan Cache) and Option B (in-memory jobs).
- Day 3: Spike SSE via BFF pass-through if easy.
- Day 4: Load/failure tests (100–300 users); injected slow steps; reconnection; BFF restarts.
- Day 5: Scorecard, ADR, contracts v0.9, rollout/rollback plan, kill-switches.

# 8. How this fits our current Replenishment Data-Grid

Current: `FE → BFF → GenAI → BFF → Cheetah (execute) → FE` (~25s, SQL passes through BFF)
New: `FE → BFF → GenAI(/plan) → FE (Planning Ready) → BFF → Cheetah(/execute plan_id)` (~25s total, no SQL to FE)

- We improve perceived latency and transparency (phases).
- We remove SQL from the FE/BFF network path (no leakage).
- We keep the wall-clock roughly the same; the experience is much better.

metadata.title: 1. Data QA v2 Design Part 1 - Orchestration Flow

content:
# High Level Details

## Sprint 1 (Sep 29–Oct 10) — Stabilize current flow, set foundations

Target: De-risk the existing screen-embedded path by splitting the single long call into two FE/BFF calls (SQL → data fetch) to improve perceived responsiveness; keep GenAI SQL endpoint unchanged. Start ETL Part-1 (product & store value embeddings). Prepare (but do not wire) `/understand` and `/plan` with a plan cache behind a flag.
Why now: Fastest way to reduce timeouts and unblock future orchestration.
Key outcomes:

- Current Data Grid on Replenishment Page uses two-step FE/BFF flow
- ETL jobs build LanceDB collections for product/store EF, and metadata (tables and columns) (ECS on EFS).
- New GenAI endpoints (/understand, /plan) exist behind flags; no FE wiring yet.
- System metadata endpoint (/metadata/system) live for GenAI.

## Sprint 2 (Oct 13–Oct 24) — Ask Page v2 MVP (plan/execute), tighten retrieval with KPI

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
for GenAI.

## Sprint 2 (Oct 13–Oct 24) — Ask Page v2 MVP (plan/execute), tighten retrieval with KPI

Target: Ship the Chat (Ask) page using `/understand → /plan → /execute` with no SQL leakage, routed to UDL. Retrieval becomes KPI-aware (force-include deps within 4k tokens).
Why now: Establish the “new normal” end-to-end path on a greenfield surface.
Key outcomes:

- UI shows “planning ready — fetching…”.
- /execute implemented (server-side plan fetch, auth, TTL, KMS-encrypted plan cache).
- ETL jobs build LanceDB collections for tenant-aware metadata
- Ask page live behind a flag (only available for internal users); FE never sees SQL; p95: Understand ≤5s, Plan ≤8s, Execute ≤6s.
- Retrieval ≤4k tokens; KPI aliasing & dependency reservation on.

## Sprint 3 (Oct 27–Nov 7) — Replenishment migration + Retrieval v2 + Validator v1 + Viz/Insight “Lite” (Ask, pilot)

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
27–Nov 7) — Replenishment migration + Retrieval v2 + Validator v1 + Viz/Insight “Lite” (Ask, pilot)

Target: Migrate Replenishment Data Grid to plan/execute; land Retrieval v2 (dense+BM25, late-fusion, precedence tiers, similar-table disambiguation) and Validator v1 (syntax, allowlists, LIMIT, recent-guard, 1× augment+retry).
Visualization/Insight: Introduce post-result agents on Ask Page only (feature-flag): single chart and 3 bullets, both no extra SQL, p95 ≤2s each.
Key outcomes:

- Replenishment uses plan/execute with server-to-server plan fetch; no SQL in FE/BFF.
- Viz/Insight “Lite” endpoints exist and run asynchronously from plan_id results (Ask).

## Sprint 4 (Nov 10–Nov 21) — Profiling-aware Retrieval v3 + Allocation migration + Validator v2

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
).

## Sprint 4 (Nov 10–Nov 21) — Profiling-aware Retrieval v3 + Allocation migration + Validator v2

Target: Integrate table/column profiling feed into ETL → LanceDB → retrieval scoring; migrate Allocation to plan/execute; ship Validator v2 (join sanity, anti-Cartesian, unbounded scan guards).
Visualization/Insight: Keep on Ask only; smarter templates & “why-this-chart” copy, still no re-query.
Key outcomes:

- Retrieval v3 demotes stale/high-null columns automatically; strict ≤4k token budget.
- Allocation uses plan/execute with no SQL leakage; Validator v2 reduces runtime errors.

## Sprint 5 (Nov 24–Dec 5) — Tenant-aware Metadata Service (TMS) + Validator v3 + Viz/Insight v2 (Ask)

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
Sprint 5 (Nov 24–Dec 5) — Tenant-aware Metadata Service (TMS) + Validator v3 + Viz/Insight v2 (Ask)

Target: Replace YAML at runtime with TMS (daily ETL snapshots: tables, columns+profiling, FK graph, synonyms, precedence, KPI deps, routing hints, PII flags). GenAI `/understand` & `/plan` read via TMS for pilot tenants. Validator v3 adds KPI prerequisite checks & grouping-cardinality guardrails.
Visualization/Insight: Use TMS precedence & KPI registry for better axes/units & narratives; still no re-query by default.
Key outcomes:

- TMS p95 read ≤50ms (with in-proc + Redis cache); N/N-1 rollback; KPI CI gates snapshot promotion.
- Retrieval & planning entirely TMS-backed for pilots.

## Sprint 6 (Dec 8–Dec 19) — Hardening & GA: Cost/PII guardrails + Observability + Viz/Insight GA (Ask)

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
Sprint 6 (Dec 8–Dec 19) — Hardening & GA: Cost/PII guardrails + Observability + Viz/Insight GA (Ask)

Target:GA readiness for Ask + migrated Data Grids under plan/execute with TMS, profiling, KPI, Validator v3, and cost/PII guardrails and Datadog dashboards.
Visualization/Insight:GA on Ask (pilot tenants): default enabled, auto-degrade (chart-or-bullets → bullets only → suppress) under cost/latency pressure; optional Viz-SQL re-query behind admin flag only.
Key outcomes:

- SLOs hold (Ask p95 ≤15s, Data Grids p95 ≤18s).
- No SQL leakage; per-phase metrics & correlation IDs live; monthly cost cap with auto-degrade ladder.

# Epics

### Data QA Agent Orchestration

Plan–Execute, plan cache (TTL/KMS), BFF/FE split, routing, SQL non-leak guarantees.

### Data QA ETL

Vector DB/EF ingestion (LanceDB/EFS), profiling feed + enrichment, nightly ECS, compaction/versioning.

### Data QA Tenant Metadata Service

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
rofiling feed + enrichment, nightly ECS, compaction/versioning.

### Data QA Tenant Metadata Service

Daily snapshots (tables/columns+profiling, FK graph, synonyms, precedence, KPI deps, routing hints, PII flags), Metadata API + DB + Redis cache.

### Data QA Retrieval, KPI

≤5k token retrieval, late-fusion + precedence, profiling-aware rerank, KPI aliasing & dependency reservation.

### Data QA SQL Validation

Validator v1→v3 (syntax → join/scan → KPI+cardinality+dialect preflight).

### Data QA Post-Result Intelligence

Visualization Agent (no-requery default, optional Viz-SQL flag) + Insight Agent (3–5 KPI-aware bullets).

---

# Detailed Breakdown

## Sprint 1 (Weeks 1–2) — Detailed Plan

### Sprint Target (Definition of Done)

Goal: Stabilize the current screen-embedded Data QA path by splitting the *single long call* into two FE/BFF calls while keeping the *existing GenAI SQL endpoint* unchanged. Improve perceived UX with a “planning ready” handoff, accept temporary SQL visibility in FE (documented risk), and kick off ETL Part-1 (product/store embeddings). Retrieval quality tuning stays minimal in this sprint.

### Success Criteria

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
duct/store embeddings). Retrieval quality tuning stays minimal in this sprint.

### Success Criteria

- Current Data QA flow runs as:Before: UI → BFF → GenAI(SQL) → BFF → Other Backend → UI   (single long call)
After:  UI → BFF → GenAI(SQL) → UI → BFF → Backend → UI     (two calls)
- (Nice to have) FE shows “Query Planning…” then “Planning ready — fetching…” between the two calls.
- GenAI groundwork (not wired): Implement /data-qa/understand and /data-qa/plan endpoints and internal plan cache behind a feature flag; do not integrate yet.
- ETL Part-1: LanceDB collections created and populated with dense embeddings for Product & Store master tables (pilot tenant).

#### New orchestration flow (non-leaky)

```
[UI] → [BFF] → [GenAI Orchestrator]
           ├─ POST /data-qa/understand  → { lean_metadata≤5k, route_hint }
           └─ POST /data-qa/plan        → { plan_id, plan_summary, route }

[UI] shows "Planning ready — fetching…"

[UI] → [BFF] → [Cheetah Backend] POST /cheetah/execute {plan_id}

       [Cheetah BE] executes SQL → returns rows to UI

```

- Plan Cache location: Cheetah BE or GenAI—choose one for Sprint 1.Option A (recommended Sprint 1): GenAI stores SQL by plan_id. Cheetah BE pulls SQL via signed GET (keeps current BE simple).Option B: Cheetah BE stores SQL in its Redis (requires GenAI→BE callback after /plan).

Security

- plan_id = uuidv7, bound to {tenant_id, user_id, route}; TTL=5 min; one-time read.

### Acceptance Criteria

- Data QA v1 flow changed to two FE calls; no more single-call UI→BFF→GenAI→Backend orchestration.
- Measurably fewer timeouts on the Replenishment screen; overall E2E time may remain similar, but UI responsiveness improves (step 1 finishes earlier).
- ETL Part-1 runs for at least one pilot tenant; LanceDB contains Product & Store vectors; ECS job executes nightly.
- /metadata/system endpoint live and returning all tables + FKs with short descriptions.
- GenAI new endpoints & retrieval/KPI skeleton exist behind a flag (covered by unit tests or quick manual test), not used by FE/BFF.

### Risks & Notes

- SQL visible in FE (temporary): acceptable for v1. We’ll remove leakage when we switch to plan_id later.
- BFF/FE sequencing bugs: mitigate with clear UI states and robust error handling between the two calls.
- Embedding throughput: batch with backoff; start with one pilot tenant.
- Metadata payload size (when we later adopt new endpoints): we’ve capped to ≤5k in code (behind flag).

### 3) Retrieval v2 (Understanding path)

Recall:

- Dense (OpenAI 1536) + BM25 for tables and columns; initial K for tables, higher K for columns; merge with FK spine.

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
536) + BM25 for tables and columns; initial K for tables, higher K for columns; merge with FK spine.

Late-fusion features (scored per candidate):

Example Score:
`S = 0.45*dense + 0.35*bm25 + 0.10*alias_overlap + 0.05*join_degree + 0.05*usage_popularity` (start weights; tune under A/B).

Similar-table disambiguation: prefer `latest_*` vs historical when the query implies “current” or recency; back-off if KPI requires history. (From spec: precedence & time defaults.)

Tiered columns selection (semantic layer precedence):

- Tier A: core measures/dims for route/domain (e.g., sales_quantity, sales_revenue, product/store keys, date).
- Tier B: top alias-overlap columns (synonyms & KPI-adjacent).
- Tier C: long-tail dims (group descriptions, region, week).
- Stop when mapping+retrieval ≤ 5k tokens (strict).

KPI-aware injection (v2):
If K/CALC resolves to a KPI (`margin`, `weeks_of_supply`, `sell-through`, stock-out risk):

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
ion (v2):
If K/CALC resolves to a KPI (`margin`, `weeks_of_supply`, `sell-through`, stock-out risk):

- Force-include required_tables and required_columns.
- Reserve tokens for KPI deps before allocating Tier C/D.
- Inject join_paths into FK subgraph if missing.

Output (to planner): Lean metadata + FK edges; no raw value lists; EF resolution capped to 3 high-confidence items.

### 4) SQL Validator v1 (Planning path)

Validator v1 checks:

- Syntax (dialect=Postgres or Bigquery).
- (Optional) Tenant allowlist (schemas/tables permitted for Replenishment).
- LIMIT enforcement (inject if missing for preview).
- Recent-intent guard: if query implies recency (e.g., “last 4w”) ensure time filter exists.
- Augment+Retry (1×): if unknown table/column, fetch object (+FK edge) from metadata endpoint, re-prompt once.
- Injection Control: Prevent SQL injection
- SELECT Only: Do not let DML queries, allow select only

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
- Injection Control: Prevent SQL injection
- SELECT Only: Do not let DML queries, allow select only

## Sprint 4 — Week 7-8

### 1) Sprint target (Definition of Done)

- Profiling feed integrated end-to-end: Data Platform → ETL → LanceDB → Retrieval scoring & token budgeting.
- Retrieval v3 (profiling-aware) live for Ask + Replenishment Screens + Allocation Screen routes, with strict ≤5k tokens.
- Allocation Data Grid migrated to the plan/execute, no-SQL-leak architecture (same pattern we used for Replenishment).
- SQL Validator v2 in planning path: join sanity checks, unbounded scan/Cartesian guards, route-specific row/time limits.
- Viz/Insight v1 (Ask): still post-result + no re-query, but smarter templates & KPI hints; p95 ≤ 1.5–2.0s; default OFF for Data Grids.

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
result + no re-query, but smarter templates & KPI hints; p95 ≤ 1.5–2.0s; default OFF for Data Grids.

### 2) What “profiling integration” means (scope & rules)

#### 2.1 Profiling feed (from Data Platform) — expected payload

- Table stats: table_name, row_count, storage_bytes, partition_keys, latest_partition, min_date, max_date, last_refresh_ts.
- Column stats (per table): column_name, data_type, null_ratio, distinct_count, avg_len, min/max, example_values[≤5].
- Quality flags (computed upstream or in ETL): is_stale, is_sparse, is_low_cardinality, is_high_cardinality, pii_risk, deprecated.

> Cadence: nightly or weekly (we’ll support both), delivered as JSON/Parquet in S3 or via API.

### 2.2 ETL → LanceDB (profiling-aware ingestion)

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
oth), delivered as JSON/Parquet in S3 or via API.

### 2.2 ETL → LanceDB (profiling-aware ingestion)

- Enrich each table/column vector with profiling attributes:null_ratio, distinct_count_bucket, freshness_score, stale_flag, low_card_flag, deprecated_flag, last_refresh_ts.
- Filter/compact:Drop columns with deprecated_flag=true or null_ratio ≥ 0.98 unless explicitly whitelisted.Prefer the freshest table variant in families (latest_* vs historical) by default.
- Versioning: stamp each index with profiling_version and index_version. Keep N/N-1 indices for rollback.
- Scheduling: ECS tasks ingest nightly; compaction weekly.

### 2.3 Retrieval v3 — how profiling changes ranking & budgeting

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
ingest nightly; compaction weekly.

### 2.3 Retrieval v3 — how profiling changes ranking & budgeting

- Late-fusion features extended (per table/column candidate):freshness_score (+), stale_flag (–), null_ratio (–), distinct_count_bucket (+/– depending on use), deprecated_flag (hard –∞ unless explicitly required), pii_risk (– for default routes).
- Feature formula (example start weights)S = 0.35*dense + 0.25*bm25 + 0.10*alias_overlap
    + 0.08*join_degree + 0.07*domain_prior + 0.10*kpi_dependency
    + 0.08*freshness_score - 0.10*null_ratio - 0.12*stale_flag - 0.20*deprecated_flag
- Budgeting (≤4k tokens):Reserve tokens first for KPI dependencies (Tier A), then for fresh columns (low null_ratio, good distinct_count_bucket).Demote or drop high-null, stale, or deprecated columns before touching Tier B KPI-adjacent columns.Keep the minimal FK spine intact at all times.

### 3) Allocation migration (Data Grid)

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
cent columns.Keep the minimal FK spine intact at all times.

### 3) Allocation migration (Data Grid)

- Adopt the same no-SQL-leak orchestration used in Sprint 3: /understand → /plan → /execute(plan_id) with server-to-server plan fetch.
- Hard-wire route=cheetah_backend for Allocation Pages.
- Turn on profiling-aware retrieval for Allocation queries on day one.

### 4) SQL Validator v2 (planning path)

- Join sanity: block accidental Cartesian joins; require explicit join predicates for multi-table queries.
- Unbounded scans: require time filter on large partitioned facts when the query implies “recent” (and table has partition_keys).
- Forbidden constructs: block DDL/DCL; limit subquery depth; deny SELECT * unless under small table guard.
- Dialect normalization: ensure Postgres-canonical & BigQuery SQL pre-validates for the route engine (UDL can adapt later).

### 5) Viz/Insight v1

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
ical & BigQuery SQL pre-validates for the route engine (UDL can adapt later).

### 5) Viz/Insight v1

- Viz: chart type chooser improves with profiling/cardinality hints; keep single chart; add “why-this-chart” explanation.
- Insights: 3–4 bullets; supports simple deltas/ratios and time-aware statements; quote only values present in result.
- Guardrails: same as Sprint 3; add “no suitable chart” fallback.

### 5) Risks & mitigations

- Stale/late profiling feed causes over-filtering.Mitigation: if profiling_version older than N days, bypass penalties (feature flag), fall back to curated allowlists.
- Precision vs recall trade-off when penalizing high-null columns.Mitigation: never penalize KPI-required columns; keep a minimum Tier A floor.
- Latency regressions due to extra features in scoring.Mitigation: compute penalties during ETL (pre-materialize) and keep retrieval math simple at query time.

#### ETL / Vector DB (profiling)

- Ingest pipeline for profiling feed (parse, validate, normalize) — 2d

#### GenAI Retrieval

- Feature-aware reranker (use profiling attributes in late-fusion) — 2d

- Join sanity & unbounded scan rules — 2d

- Wire Allocation page to plan/execute — FE 1.5d, BFF 1d, BE 1d

### 7) Tasks to open (titles + one-liners)

#### ETL / Vector DB

- Implement profiling feed parser — Read/validate table & column stats; store as normalized snapshots.
- LanceDB schema v2 with profiling fields — Add freshness/null/flags to table/column vectors; version indexes.
- Apply ingestion filters & compaction — Drop deprecated/near-empty columns; rebuild IVF/HNSW as needed.
- Nightly ECS job & alarms — Schedule ingestion; alert on missing or stale feeds.

#### Retrieval (GenAI)

- Add profiling features to late-fusion scorer — Incorporate freshness/null/flags into S formula with tunable weights.
- Update token budgeter with profiling-aware drops — Reserve KPI deps; demote stale/high-null before Tier B/C trims.
- Emit profiling_version & drop summary — Attach to /understand response for debugging; log per query.

- Join sanity & anti-Cartesian rule — Reject or auto-repair missing ON clauses; explain error.

## Sprint 5 — Week 9-10

### 1) Sprint Target (Definition of Done)

- Tenant-aware Metadata Service (TMS) is live and used by GenAI /understand and /plan on pilot tenants:Serves consolidated, pre-compiled metadata per tenant from daily ETL (no YAML loads at runtime).Includes: tables, columns (with profiling attrs), FK graph, synonyms/aliases, precedence ladders, KPI dependency maps, routing hints, and PII flags.Exposes fast read APIs with p95 ≤ 500 ms per key requestVersioned; supports N/N-1 rollback.
- GenAI retrieval switches to TMS (for selected tenants) and meets the ≤ 4k token budget using the new metadata payloads.
- KPI CI (unit tests) runs in CI against the TMS snapshot; green gate required.
- SQL Validator v3 uses TMS semantics (KPI prerequisites, grouping cardinality guardrails).
- A/B Retrieval experiments (late-fusion vs late-fusion+LLM column ranker) run offline using TMS metadata; report produced (no production flip yet).

Snapshot Builder (per tenant)Compiles a tenant-scoped metadata snapshot:tables[] with short desc, recency, staleness.columns[] with types, synonyms, profiling attrs (null_ratio, distinct_bucket, pii_risk), precedence_rank.fk_edges[] (minimal FK graph + cardinalities).aliases/synonyms[] normalized (Jaccard tokens ready).kpi_dependencies{KPI→tables/columns/join_paths}.routing_hints (Ask→UDL; Data Grids→Cheetah).Writes immutable JSON blobs (e.g., S3/EFS) and keyed objects into a low-latency store (e.g., Redis hash / DynamoDB).

### 4) TMS API (internal; consumed by GenAI)

- GET /tms/v1/metadata?tenant_id=…&version=latest&scope=tables,columns,fk→ returns snapshot handles / ETags, not the whole blob unless requested.
- GET /tms/v1/metadata/object?tenant_id=…&version=…&object=tables|columns|fk|kpi_dependencies→ returns a sharded object (so /understand can request exactly what it needs).
- Bulk fetch SDK inside GenAI:tms.get_snapshot(tenant, version='latest', objects=['tables','columns','fk','kpi_dependencies'])→ marshals to in-memory structs for ≤ 50 ms p95.

Caching & versioning

- In-process LRU (per GenAI worker) with TTL=15 min + ETag validation.
- Redis as authoritative key-value (tms:{tenant}:{version}:{object} → JSON).
- N/N-1 retention; atomic version switch at “built_at”.

### 5) Changes to GenAI (to use TMS)

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
JSON).
- N/N-1 retention; atomic version switch at “built_at”.

### 5) Changes to GenAI (to use TMS)

- /understandReplace YAML reads with TMS snapshot calls.Build candidate sets from tables/columns/fk_edges/synonyms, apply late-fusion rerank (weights unchanged), and apply KPI deps first.Keep ≤ 4k tokens budget; include drop rationale (profiling penalties, deprecations).
- /planUse kpi_dependencies.join_paths when composing joins.Feed Validator v3 with TMS allowlists, KPI prerequisites, and grouping cardinality limits derived from distinct_bucket.

### 6) Viz/Insight v2 (Ask)

- Viz: choose axes/encodings using precedence and distinct_bucket; better labels/units via KPI registry; microcopy “generated from current results”.
- Insights: 3–5 bullets; KPI-aware narratives that avoid invalid claims (e.g., safe division, percent deltas with denominators); still no extra SQL.

### 7) Retrieval A/B (offline)

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
afe division, percent deltas with denominators); still no extra SQL.

### 7) Retrieval A/B (offline)

- Variant A: Late-fusion baseline (S4 weights).
- Variant B: Late-fusion + LLM-assisted column ranking (prompt the model with candidate set + KPI hint to refine top-N columns under 4k).
- Run offline using the TMS snapshot as the only metadata source.
- Report: Table/Column P@K deltas, budget adherence, simulated latency increase (token counts & prompt size).

### 8) Acceptance Criteria

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
dget adherence, simulated latency increase (token counts & prompt size).

### 8) Acceptance Criteria

- TMS GA (pilot tenants):GenAI /understand and /plan read metadata only via TMS for pilot tenants.p95 ≤ 50 ms TMS reads (server logs), ≥ 99.9% cache hit on warm traffic.Rollback N-1 available and validated.
- Retrieval correctness/latency:Mapping+retrieval ≤ 4k tokens for ≥ 99% of queries on pilot tenants.Table P@K ≥ 0.82, Column P@K ≥ 0.68 (no regression vs S4).
- KPI CI: 100% pass for target KPI set; CI gating enforced on snapshot promotion.
- Validator v3: blocks missing KPI prerequisites and high-cardinality anti-patterns; unknown-object error rate further reduced vs S4.

### 9) Risks & Mitigations

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
dinality anti-patterns; unknown-object error rate further reduced vs S4.

### 9) Risks & Mitigations

- Snapshot staleness / failed ETL build→ Keep N-1 live; fail-closed to previous snapshot; alert on build failure; block promotion if KPI CI fails.
- Memory/cost of caching→ Use sharded objects (tables/columns/fk/kpi) + compression; evict by tenant LRU; Redis TTLs (24–48 h).
- Breaking semantics (YAML vs TMS)→ Dual-read mode in non-prod for a week; comparison tool reports diffs (counts, aliases, FK coverage).
- Performance regressions→ Strict p95 SLA on TMS reads; precompute ranking features during ETL to keep /understand light.

### 10) Work Breakdown & Owners (2 weeks)

#### ETL / Platform

- Snapshot Builder (per tenant) — materialize JSON + Redis/DDB objects; writer with N/N-1 rotation.
- Precompute ranking features — alias tokens, precedence ranks, profiling penalties.
- Promotion gate — mark snapshot “promotable” only after KPI CI passes.

#### TMS Service (or in-process module)

metadata.title: 3. Data QA v2 Design Part 3 - Sprint Breakdown

content:
gate — mark snapshot “promotable” only after KPI CI passes.

#### TMS Service (or in-process module)

- Read APIs + SDK — sharded fetch, version pinning, ETag support; Redis + in-proc cache.
- Auth & tenancy checks — scope by tenant; audit logs.

#### GenAI

- Wire /understand to TMS — remove YAML reads; payload builder uses TMS objects.
- Wire /plan to TMS — joins & allowlists; feed Validator v3.
- Validator v3 — KPI prerequisite & cardinality checks; dialect pre-flight.

### 11) Tasks to Open

ETL

- Write snapshot to Database / Cache — Store as tms:{tenant}:{version}:{object} with ETag and TTL.
- Implement promotion gate — Snapshot marked live only after KPI CI passes.
- Precompute retrieval features — Alias tokens, precedence ranks, profiling penalties.

TMS

GenAI

ot.

- GA (General Availability) readiness for Ask + migrated Data Grids (Replenishment, Allocation):New plan/execute (no-SQL-leak) path used by default.Tenant-aware metadata service (TMS) is the only runtime metadata source for pilot tenants; YAML loaders disabled in prod.Profiling-aware Retrieval (≤ 5k tokens) + KPI Registry inclusion active.Validator v3 enforced on planning path.
- Cost & safety guardrails ON:PII masking policy active for product/store/category strings in client responses when policy requires.

### 2) Scope

### B. PII masking & security

- Masking rules (configurable per tenant/route):Columns flagged pii_risk ∈ {low, med, high} in TMS are masked/redacted in FE responses by default (e.g., replace product/store names with codes or [redacted]).Allow role-based override (admins only) via BFF header.
- Plan cache hardening:One-time read, TTL=5–15 min, KMS-wrapped encryption at rest; bind plan_id to {tenant_id, user_id, route}.
- Access checks:Every /understand, /plan, /execute call verifies tenant scope; BFF prohibits cross-tenant calls.

### C. Observability & SLO verification

- Dashboards (Datadog):Tenant filter; route filter; rolling 7/30-day cost; error classes (validator, route, engine); top queries by cost/latency.

- Rollout plan:Week 11: enable Ask + Replenishment for 2 pilot tenants → monitor → widen.Week 12: enable Allocation for same pilots → monitor → widen.

### 3) Acceptance Criteria (measurable)

- No SQL leakage verified on Ask/Replenishment/Allocation (network traces & logs).
- TMS-only runtime on pilots; YAML loaders disabled in prod path (flag in logs).
- Token budget adherence: 99% of queries ≤ 4k retrieval tokens (Ask and Data Grids).
- Validator v3 blocks:Missing KPI prerequisites,High-cardinality anti-patterns,Unbounded scans or Cartesian joins.Augment+retry success rate ≥ 50% when unknown objects encountered.
- Cost cap: alert/auto-degrade engages at thresholds in staging and prod smoke test; monthly forecast < $200 under typical load.
- PII masking on for tenants requiring it; admin override functions.
- SLOs hold for 7 consecutive days on pilot tenants.

### 4) Risks & Mitigations

- Auto-degrade harms accuracy → keep KPI dependencies non-droppable; degrade only Tier C/D; monitor accuracy delta on a small golden set.
- PII over-masking frustrates users → surface a small banner “Some values redacted by policy”; allow self-service request for unmask (admin).
- Observability noise → standardize reason codes; sample payload logs (never data rows) for diagnostics; keep PII out of logs.
- Cost spikes on specific tenants → per-tenant caps + alerts; temporarily reduce Viz/Analyze availability.

# 1. Context and scope

## Surrounding system

- Product: Multi-tenant Retail Analytics SaaS for global retailers – Batch ETL Jobs for Agentic AI Use Cases.
- Today’s ETL: Many tenants run their own Airflow schedulers (single-tenant), with datasets in Azure Blob or AWS S3; most tenants are on Azure.
- Current pain points:Duplicated orchestration infra, tenant-specific connectivity, uneven security/governance, fragmented logs/status.Cross-cloud egress and unnecessary latencies when compute is not near data.Airflow DAGs often accumulate provider-specific details (clusters, creds), slowing development.

## What we are building and why

e provider-specific details (clusters, creds), slowing development.

## What we are building and why

- What: A central, thin, multi-tenant Airflow that orchestrates by calling a new Jobs API on an AWS-hosted Job Execution Layer (JEL). The JEL routes to the right runtime:Managed service if a job type is inherently cloud-specific (e.g., Databricks for Spark-native tasks in the future),Else AWS tenants → AWS Batch or ECS/Fargate,Azure tenants → Azure Batch (submitted from AWS using a per-tenant Azure service account / Entra service principal).
- Why:Keep compute close to data (cut egress/latency).One API for submit/status/cancel/logs across clouds.Keep Airflow thin, less dependent to cloud resources, and multi-tenant by design.Centralize governance, quotas, observability, audit.Provide an exception path for a specific AWS ECS ETL job with a thin AWS-only API to move quickly.

---

## Goals

1. Thin central Airflow (multi-tenant): orchestration-only with “submit & wait” operators; no per-tenant cloud creds or Kubernetes details in DAGs.
2. Jobs API (JEL) on AWS with:POST /jobs (async submit → job_id),GET /jobs/{id} (status w/ timestamps & exit code),DELETE /jobs/{id} (cancel),GET /jobs/{id}/logs (pointer + optional tail).Status model: PENDING → SUBMITTED → RUNNING → SUCCEEDED|FAILED|CANCELLED.
3. Routing policy:Dedicated managed backends when job type demands it (future),Else AWS → Batch or Fargate; Azure → Azure Batch, using per-tenant Entra service principal.
4. Multi-tenant architecture: all API calls & rows carry tenant_id; Postgres Row Level Security; Airflow DAG runs parameterized by tenant_id.
5. Data awareness: prefer push-based triggering (events or REST) from tenant systems; deferrable sensors as fallback.
6. Observability & governance: metrics, structured logs, cost tags, per-tenant quotas/concurrency.

Key separations

- Airflow: no provider details; one DAG per job type, many tenants via run-config; pools per tenant.
- JEL: routing, identity, provider quirks, status normalization, cancellation, quotas, logs pointers.
- Adapters: cloud-specific submit/describe/cancel; least-privilege credentials.
- Persistence: authoritative job state & audit.

## 3.2 Multi-tenant Airflow design

Deployment

- One central Airflow, internal-use only; not exposed to tenants.
- Executor: Celery/K8s is fine — tasks are lightweight (submit & wait); we can use deferrable sensors to avoid slot burn (if it fits to our Airflow version, requires triggerer component).
- RBAC: role-based access for internal teams; views filtered by tags/labels.

DAG model

component).
- RBAC: role-based access for internal teams; views filtered by tags/labels.

DAG model

- One DAG per job type (e.g., etl_daily_refresh) — never per tenant.
- For each run: tenant_id, run_date, and parameters supplied via dag_run.conf.
- Tasks in DAG:SubmitExternalJobOperator(job_payload) → returns job_id.ExternalJobSensor(job_id) (deferrable) → completes on SUCCEEDED, raises on FAILED/CANCELLED.
- Concurrency controls:Airflow Pools: pool_tenant_{tenant_id} (optional) and global pool_{job_type}.DAG‐level max_active_runs, task_concurrency.
- Data-awareness:Push-based: tenants (or a bridge) trigger central DAGs via REST; optionally translate events into Airflow Dataset/Asset events.Pull fallback: deferrable S3/Blob/HTTP/DB sensors with mode="reschedule".

What does*not*live in DAGs

- No KPO/K8s specifics, no provider creds, no cluster names, no per-tenant connection objects.
- No provider-side retry/cancel logic — this lives in JEL.

## 3.3 Jobs API (JEL) — AWS-hosted

Endpoints (v1)

- POST /jobs — Submit job; returns 202 Accepted with {job_id, status, logs?}.
- GET /jobs/{id} — Status (state, timestamps, exit code, provider run ref, log pointers).
- DELETE /jobs/{id} — Cancel; transitions to CANCELLED (with intermediate CANCELLED_REQUESTED).
- GET /jobs/{id}/logs?tail=N — Log pointer + optional last lines.

Auth & tenancy

- Public routes: API Gateway + Cognito (JWT with tenant_id claim).
- Internal routes (e.g., webhook ingestion, status): API Gateway route with AWS_IAM (SigV4).
- All database rows include tenant_id; Row Level Security enforces access.

Status model

- PENDING → created in DB before submit.
- SUBMITTED → provider accepted (store run ref).
- RUNNING → provider indicates start.
- SUCCEEDED|FAILED|CANCELLED → terminal; store exit code/reason.
- Maintain status_history (append-only events).

FAILED|CANCELLED → terminal; store exit code/reason.
- Maintain status_history (append-only events).

Idempotency

- Header Idempotency-Key (unique per tenant_id + job_type for a window). Duplicate returns the original job_id and status.

Logs

- Return pointers:AWS: CloudWatch Logs {group, stream}.Azure: Log Analytics query or Batch stdout/Storage path.
- Optional tail of last N lines by adapter call.

## 3.4 Routing policy

Inputs: `job_type`, `tenant_id`, `execution.provider=auto|aws|azure`, optional resource hints, dataset URIs.
Policy engine:

1. If job_type is pinned to a managed service → route there (future: Databricks).
2. Else if tenant.provider == "aws" → choose AWS Batch when queueing/array jobs or exact sizing is required; else ECS/Fargate.
3. Else if tenant.provider == "azure" → Azure Batch using the tenant’s service account (Entra SP).
4. Allow feature-flag overrides per tenant/job_type (canaries, cost caps, blue/green).

## 3.5 Persistence schema (Postgres, RLS)

```
CREATE TYPE job_status AS ENUM
('PENDING','SUBMITTED','RUNNING','SUCCEEDED','FAILED','CANCELLED_REQUESTED','CANCELLED');

CREATE TABLE tenants (
  tenant_id text PRIMARY KEY,
  name text,
  provider text CHECK (provider IN ('aws','azure'))
);

CREATE TABLE job_kinds (
  job_type text PRIMARY KEY,
  version int NOT NULL,
  backend_pref text NOT NULL DEFAULT 'auto',  -- 'auto'|'aws'|'azure'|'databricks'
  param_schema jsonb NOT NULL,
  default_resources jsonb,
  log_pointer_template jsonb,
  tags jsonb
);

aram_schema jsonb NOT NULL,
  default_resources jsonb,
  log_pointer_template jsonb,
  tags jsonb
);

CREATE TABLE jobs (
  job_id uuid PRIMARY KEY,
  tenant_id text NOT NULL REFERENCES tenants(tenant_id),
  job_type text NOT NULL REFERENCES job_kinds(job_type),
  provider text,  -- 'aws'|'azure'|'databricks'
  provider_run_ref jsonb, -- e.g., {"taskArn":"..."}, {"batchJobId":"..."}, {"azureJobId":"..."}
  status job_status NOT NULL,
  status_reason text,
  exit_code int,
  parameters jsonb NOT NULL,
  tags jsonb,
  webhook jsonb, -- {url, secret}
  idempotency_key text,
  logs jsonb,    -- normalized pointer {provider,group,stream} | {workspaceId,query}
  created_at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now(),
  submitted_at timestamptz,
  started_at timestamptz,
  finished_at timestamptz,
  updated_at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now()
);

CREATE UNIQUE INDEX uniq_idem
ON jobs (tenant_id, job_type, idempotency_key)
WHERE idempotency_key IS NOT NULL;

UE INDEX uniq_idem
ON jobs (tenant_id, job_type, idempotency_key)
WHERE idempotency_key IS NOT NULL;

CREATE TABLE job_status_events (
  job_id uuid REFERENCES jobs(job_id),
  prev job_status,
  next job_status,
  at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now(),
  raw_event jsonb
);

-- RLS (conceptual):
-- ENABLE RLS on jobs, job_status_events.
-- POLICY: user can SELECT rows where jobs.tenant_id = token.tenant_id (or has admin scope).

### AWS Adapter (Batch + ECS/Fargate)

- Submit:Batch: SubmitJob (job queue & compute environment per env/tenant class), parameters via env/command or S3 JSON.ECS: RunTask with overrides & network config; tags include job_id, tenant_id, job_type.
- Status:Receive EventBridge events (Batch/ECS state changes) → Lambda updates jobs.Reconciler polls DescribeJobs / DescribeTasks when events are missing.
- Cancel: TerminateJob (Batch) / StopTask (ECS).
- Logs: CloudWatch Logs pointer.

### AWS ECS Fastpath (exception job)

Job (Batch) / StopTask (ECS).

### AWS ECS Fastpath (exception job)

- Consider having a thin micro-API: POST /aws-jobs → RunTask; GET /aws-jobs/{id}; DELETE cancel; GET /aws-jobs/{id}/logs.

### Azure Adapter (Batch) — requires per-tenant service account

### Azure Adapter (Batch) — requires per-tenant service account

- Per-tenant identity: Create a Microsoft Entra application/service principal per tenant (or per group) with least privilege to the tenant’s Batch account/resource group.Store references in AWS Secrets Manager (no secrets in Postgres): cloud_credentials(tenant_id, provider, secret_ref).At runtime, JEL uses client-credentials flow to obtain tokens.
- Submit: Create Batch Job & Task using the tenant’s SP credentials; mount params via env or blob.
- Status:Option A (preferred for simplicity): the container posts back to JEL (webhook) on start/finish; adapter also polls to ensure reliability.Option B: Azure Function (Timer) polls Batch and posts to JEL internal status endpoint (IAM-signed or Cognito client-cred).
- Cancel: Terminate job/task.
- Logs:Log Analytics query pointer or captured stdout path; optional tail via SDK.

## 3.7 Security and IAM

Jobs API (AWS)

- API Gateway with two auth modes: Cognito (JWT) for public calls and AWS_IAM (SigV4) for internal automations/webhooks.
- JEL runtime IAM:AWS path:ecs:RunTask, ecs:DescribeTasks, ecs:StopTask restricted to allowed cluster/taskDefinition ARNs.batch:SubmitJob, batch:TerminateJob, batch:DescribeJobs restricted to allowed queues.iam:PassRole scoped to specific task/batch roles only.Azure path:Read Secrets Manager refs to acquire tenant SP secrets; no secrets persisted in code or DB.

Workload identities

Manager refs to acquire tenant SP secrets; no secrets persisted in code or DB.

Workload identities

- AWS jobs use task/role or IRSA to access S3, Secrets, CW Logs.
- Azure jobs: inside AKS/Container Apps (future), use Azure Workload Identity; for Azure Batch containers, access the required storage/Key Vault via SPN or managed identity as available.

## 3.8 Observability, quotas, and cancellation

Metrics (per tenant/job_type)

- Submitted/Running/Succeeded/Failed counts.
- Duration histograms (started_at - submitted_at, finished_at - started_at).
- Queue→start latency.
- Failure ratio; cancelled totals.

Quotas & concurrency

- Enforced in JEL: per-tenant & per-job_type limits; 429 with Retry-After.
- Airflow pools as secondary guard.

Cancellation

- Unified DELETE /jobs/{id} → maps to TerminateJob (Batch) / StopTask (ECS).
- Interim CANCELLED_REQUESTED with timeout; force-stop if provider doesn’t report stop in time.

## 3.9 Orchestraion Model (push preferred)

This section details how the central Airflow becomes “data-aware” when datasets are produced in tenant environments (often tenant-managed Airflows). We analyze three primary patterns—Push, Pull (Sensor), Pull (Queue)—plus a hybrid Queue-backed Push Bridge.

> Info: Regardless of the option, execution still routes via JEL (Jobs API). For Azure execution, jobs require a per-tenant Microsoft Entra service principal (service account) as defined elsewhere in this design; orchestration signals do not remove that requirement (they only tell us when to run).

### 3.9.1 Push-based from Tenant Airflows

*(Custom triggers or Data-Aware Scheduling)*Intent: Tenant systems proactively tell the central plane “data is ready”, avoiding polling and reducing latency.

#### A) Custom Triggers (Direct DAG Run or Jobs API)

ready”, avoiding polling and reducing latency.

#### A) Custom Triggers (Direct DAG Run or Jobs API)

- Flow (typical):Tenant → (HTTPS, Cognito) → Central Airflow REST (POST /api/v1/dags/{dag_id}/dagRuns with dag_run.conf = { tenant_id, business_date, dataset_uri, … })→ Central DAG submit&wait → JEL → Provider runtime.
- Variant: Tenant hits JEL directly (POST /v1/jobs) and central Airflow is used for downstream coordination only (e.g., aggregation DAGs).
- Idempotency: Sender must include a dedupe key (e.g., tenant|dataset|business_date)
- Pros: Lowest latency, minimal Airflow load, straightforward.
- Cons: Requires tenant integration work; if tenant Airflow is offline, signals may be delayed.

Example (DAG Run trigger payload)

```
{
  "conf": {
    "tenant_id": "t_acme",
    "business_date": "2025-09-19",
    "dataset_uri": "abfs://raw/sales/date=2025-09-19"
  }
}

```

Flow

    "dataset_uri": "abfs://raw/sales/date=2025-09-19"
  }
}

```

Flow

```
Tenant Airflow ──HTTPS──▶ Central Airflow (create DAGRun with conf)
DAG Submit ▶ Jobs API ▶ Adapter ▶ Runtime
        ◀────────────── status/terminal ◀──────────────
DAG Sensor (deferrable) completes
```

#### B) Data-Aware Scheduling (Datasets / Assets)

- Flow: Tenant emits a dataset/asset event to central Airflow via REST (bridge/SDK). Consumer DAG declares schedule=[Dataset("abfs://raw/sales/...")] (or equivalent Asset).
- Cross-deployment: The tenant Airflow cannot “natively” propagate dataset events across installations; a tiny bridge (Lambda/Function or small service) posts dataset/asset events into central Airflow on completion.
- Pros: Declarative “data causes runs”; great lineage.
- Cons: Still need a bridge; version alignment and event schemas must be curated.

s”; great lineage.
- Cons: Still need a bridge; version alignment and event schemas must be curated.

Recommended when: We can instrument producers to emit events; and when want the most declarative DAG triggers and lineage semantics.

Flow

```
Tenant Job done ──HTTPS──▶ Event Bridge/Bridge ──▶ Central Airflow (Dataset/Asset event)
DAG scheduled by dataset event ▶ Submit ▶ Wait
```

### 3.9.2 Pull-based — Sensor model (Deferrable)

Intent: Central Airflow periodically checks if data is ready. No producer changes required.

rrable)

Intent: Central Airflow periodically checks if data is ready. No producer changes required.

- Deferrable sensors (required): use mode="reschedule" or fully deferrable sensors to avoid holding worker slots.
- Targets:Object storage: S3KeySensor / Azure Blob (custom or provider sensor), parquet/manifest exists for business_date.HTTP/REST: tenant exposes a “readiness” endpoint.DB watermark: look for a row in a control/metadata table.
- Backoff & jitter: Start at short intervals, exponential backoff, max timeout; jitter to avoid thundering herds.
- Failure modes: 4xx (bad conf), 5xx/transient (retry), timeouts (alert); surface clear reasons.
- Pros: Zero tenant work; easy to retrofit.
- Cons: Higher latency, extra control-plane calls, and more operational tuning (timeouts, intervals, backoff).
- Security: Read-only credentials per tenant dataset (for Azure we would still need tenant service principal for Blob/Key Vault access).

Example (HTTP sensor pattern, deferrable)

need tenant service principal for Blob/Key Vault access).

Example (HTTP sensor pattern, deferrable)

```
wait_ready = HttpSensor(
    task_id="wait_ready",
    http_conn_id="tenant_ready_api",
    endpoint="/v1/ready",
    request_params={"tenant_id": "{{ dag_run.conf['tenant_id'] }}",
                    "business_date": "{{ dag_run.conf['business_date'] }}"},
    mode="reschedule",          # deferrable
    poke_interval=60,
    timeout=6*60*60,            # 6h
    exponential_backoff=True
)

```

Flow

```
DAG Task: Deferrable Sensor ──polls──▶ S3/Blob/HTTP/DB
Ready? yes → Submit ▶ Wait
```

- Flow: Tenant (or tenant Airflow) publishes dataset-ready messages → queue. Central DAG uses a deferrable QueueSensor (long-polling) to receive a message matching {tenant_id,dataset,business_date} → ack/delete → continue to submit job via JEL.
- Message contract (example):{
  "event_id": "uuid",
  "tenant_id": "t_acme",
  "type": "dataset.ready",
  "dataset_uri": "abfs://raw/sales/date=2025-09-19",
  "business_date": "2025-09-19",
  "dedupe_key": "t_acme|raw/sales|2025-09-19"
}
- SQS specifics: Use long polling (e.g., 20s), set VisibilityTimeout ≥ 2× processing, delete on success, DLQ for poison messages. FIFO only if we need strict per-tenant per-dataset ordering (MessageGroupId = tenant|dataset).
- Pros: Works even if tenants can’t call central Airflow/JEL directly (they can publish to a queue using their cloud).

if tenants can’t call central Airflow/JEL directly (they can publish to a queue using their cloud).
- Cons: Sensors are still part of DAG execution; we must manage sensor scale, visibility timeouts, and acknowledgement semantics. It pushes queue semantics into orchestration code; less declarative than datasets.

Flow:

```
DAG Task: Deferrable QueueSensor ──long-poll──▶ SQS/ServiceBus
On match → delete/ack → Submit ▶ Wait
```

### 3.10.4 Hybrid — Queue-backed Push Bridge (recommended for resilience at scale)

Intent: Combine the best of push and queue: tenants send HTTPS → we buffer in a queue → a small bridge reliably converts messages to DAGRuns or dataset events (or calls JEL directly).

ue → a small bridge reliably converts messages to DAGRuns or dataset events (or calls JEL directly).

- Flow:Tenant → (HTTPS, Cognito) → JEL Ingest → SQS/Service Bus → Bridge Lambda/Function →Option A: Create central DAGRun or Dataset/Asset event (Airflow remains the orchestrator), orOption B: Call POST /v1/jobs (JEL submits directly), while Airflow coordinates downstream DAGs.
- Why this is strong: Backpressure, retries, DLQ, centralized idempotency & dedupe, burst smoothing, clean separation from DAG code.
- Security: Tenants never get direct queue creds by default. All ingestion via HTTPS (Cognito + HMAC). Internal components use IAM/Managed identities.
- Observability: Track ApproximateAgeOfOldestMessage, consumer errors, DLQ depth. Alert if age exceeds thresholds.

Recommended when: Multi-tenant at-scale with bursty producers. This keeps Airflow thin and removes queue semantics from DAG code.

Flow

cale with bursty producers. This keeps Airflow thin and removes queue semantics from DAG code.

Flow

```
Tenant ─HTTPS▶ JEL Ingest ─enqueue▶ SQS/ServiceBus ─▶ Bridge
Bridge: (A) create DAGRun / dataset event   OR   (B) call JEL /jobs
```

## 3.10 Scheduling model (multi-tenant)

We can support three complementary scheduling patterns:

``

## 3.10 Scheduling model (multi-tenant)

We can support three complementary scheduling patterns:

1. Event-driven (preferred when data readiness triggers work)Producers (tenant Airflows/apps) push a “data ready” signal. Central Airflow runs consumer DAGs or directly calls JEL.
2. JEL-managed CRON (recommended for simple/recurring single-step jobs)Use AWS EventBridge Scheduler to invoke the Jobs API on a schedule per tenant & job type. This bypasses Airflow for timing and keeps orchestration thin. Works for AWS runtimes and Azure runtimes (because the Scheduler calls JEL in AWS, and JEL routes to Azure with the tenant’s service account).
3. Airflow-driven CRON (for orchestrated, multi-step DAGs)Airflow runs on a schedule (daily/hourly), and each run submits work via JEL (possibly fanning out across tenants). Use when run ordering, DAG-level dependencies, or dataset semantics matter.

ing out across tenants). Use when run ordering, DAG-level dependencies, or dataset semantics matter.

We standardize schedules as data in the JEL database and reconcile them to the chosen control plane (EventBridge or Airflow).

CREATE TABLE schedules (
  schedule_id uuid PRIMARY KEY,
  tenant_id text NOT NULL REFERENCES tenants(tenant_id),
  job_type text NOT NULL REFERENCES job_kinds(job_type),
  cron_expression text NOT NULL,               -- e.g., "cron(0 3  ? *)" or standard CRON "0 3  *"
  timezone text NOT NULL DEFAULT 'UTC',        -- IANA TZ (e.g., "Europe/Istanbul")
  start_after timestamptz,                     -- optional: don't trigger before
  end_before timestamptz,                      -- optional: stop triggering after
  jitter_seconds int DEFAULT 0,                -- optional randomization window
  payload jsonb,                               -- default parameters for submit
  enabled boolean NOT NULL DEFAULT true,
  overlap_policy text NOT NULL DEFAULT 'skip', -- 'skip'|'enqueue'|'cancel-previous'
  engine text NOT NULL DEFAULT 'eventbridge',  -- 'eventbridge'|'airflow'
  created_by text,
  created_at timestamptz DEFAULT now(),
  updated_at timestamptz DEFAULT now()
);

created_by text,
  created_at timestamptz DEFAULT now(),
  updated_at timestamptz DEFAULT now()
);

-- Helpful fast lookups:
CREATE INDEX idx_schedules_tenant ON schedules(tenant_id, enabled);
CREATE INDEX idx_schedules_engine ON schedules(engine, enabled);

```

Why “schedules as data” matters

- One pane to pause, delete, or change schedules across tenants.
- We can switch engines (eventbridge ↔ airflow) without touching DAG code.
- We can add holiday calendars / black-out windows later by augmenting this model.

## 3.12 EventBridge Scheduler (JEL-managed CRON)

How it works

- A small JEL control-plane reconciler reads enabled rows where engine='eventbridge' and creates/updates/deletes corresponding EventBridge Schedules.
- Each schedule targets an API Gateway route (e.g., /internal/jobs) authenticated with AWS_IAM (SigV4), posting JSON:

argets an API Gateway route (e.g., /internal/jobs) authenticated with AWS_IAM (SigV4), posting JSON:

```
{
  "tenant_id": "<tenant>",
  "job_type": "<job_type>",
  "parameters": { ... merged from schedules.payload ... },
  "execution": { "provider": "auto" },
  "schedule_context": {
    "schedule_id": "<uuid>",
    "fire_time": "<2025-09-22T03:00:00Z>",
    "occurrence_id": "<deterministic-uuid>"
  }
}

```

",
    "fire_time": "<2025-09-22T03:00:00Z>",
    "occurrence_id": "<deterministic-uuid>"
  }
}

```

- Idempotency: JEL constructs Idempotency-Key = sha256(schedule_id + occurrence_id) so retries from the Scheduler or network flaps do not create duplicates.
- Timezone: store IANA time zone in the schedules.timezone column; the reconciler sets the appropriate ScheduleExpressionTimezone on EventBridge Scheduler (AWS supports this).
- Jitter: if jitter_seconds>0, the reconciler sets a random delay or uses a Flex window if available; else JEL waits a random short delay before submit to spread load.
- Overlap policy per schedule:skip: if a previous run is RUNNING (or not terminal), don’t submit a new one.enqueue: always submit (queue up).cancel-previous: attempt to cancel the prior run if still active, then submit.

Why this is recommended for simple recurring jobs

ancel the prior run if still active, then submit.

Why this is recommended for simple recurring jobs

- Operationally lighter than Airflow for timing.
- Reliable managed infra with pause/resume and per-schedule DLQs if we enable them.
- It directly calls JEL, which routes to AWS or Azure; Airflow stays thin.

Observability

- JEL is still the system of record for job runs; we can correlate schedule name or schedule_id in job tags.
- CloudWatch metrics on schedule invocations + JEL metrics give full coverage.

# 4. Considered alternatives

### What we care about

- Multi-tenant scale & safety: onboarding many tenants without DAG churn, enforcing tenancy (RLS), quotas, and least-privilege identities.
- Compute near data: avoiding cross-cloud egress while preserving performance.
- Operational clarity: one source of truth for status/logs, predictable on-call, reconciler for missed events.
- Delivery speed: shipping a reliable MVP in 8 weeks with 1 FTE.
- Extensibility: adding backends (Databricks, Step Functions, ACA Jobs) without touching DAGs.

### Key insights

ity: adding backends (Databricks, Step Functions, ACA Jobs) without touching DAGs.

### Key insights

- Pushing provider details into DAGs (KPO per tenant) does not scale and increases blast radius.
- A central Jobs API (JEL) makes tenancy, retries, cancellation, logs, and quotas consistent across clouds.
- Azure runtime introduces the per-tenant service-account (Entra SP) lifecycle; it’s the right long-term choice for data gravity, but adds setup/rotation overhead.
- If the 8-week window or staffing is tight, postponing Azure runtime and reading datasets via HTTP/SAS (staging to S3 when needed) is a pragmatic acceleration—at the cost of egress fees and latency—and keeps the same API/DAG patterns for a smooth later cutover.

## How we make the final decision

### Decision criteria (and why)

erns for a smooth later cutover.

## How we make the final decision

### Decision criteria (and why)

1. Time-to-Value (weight: high) — We need a solid MVP in 8 weeks with 1 FTE.
2. Multi-tenant scalability — Avoid per-tenant DAG/config sprawl; enforce quotas and clear tenancy.
3. Data gravity & cost — Prefer in-place compute; avoid systematic egress.
4. Security posture — Minimal secrets in Airflow; least-privilege identities; per-tenant isolation.
5. Operability — Single job ledger, normalized states/logs, metrics/alerts, and a reconciler.

### Decision rule we applied

job ledger, normalized states/logs, metrics/alerts, and a reconciler.

### Decision rule we applied

- Primary architecture: adopt G (Baseline) — Thin Airflow + AWS-hosted JEL with routing and a unified status/logs plane. This optimizes for scalability, governance, and long-term multi-cloud agility.
- Near-term delivery: if Azure adapter scope fits the 8-week plan (as we outlined), ship Azure-first MVP plus the AWS ECS fastpath for the one exceptional AWS ETL job.
- If Azure adapter cannot fit or presents undue risk in the 8-week window, adopt F (Azure-postponed) for Phase 1: run in AWS only, bridge Azure datasets via HTTP/SAS (or explicit copy to S3), and schedule the Azure adapter as a focused 4–6 week follow-on project. The API, DAGs, and observability model remain unchanged—only the routing/adapter choice flips later.

### Final decision

bservability model remain unchanged—only the routing/adapter choice flips later.

### Final decision

- Adopt Baseline G as the target architecture (thin multi-tenant Airflow + JEL on AWS).
- Deliver MVP in 8 weeks with:Azure Batch adapter (or Alternative F if scope/time risks arise),AWS ECS fastpath for the single “pure AWS” ETL job,Airflow submit & wait operators,push-based triggers, quotas, reconciler, metrics/alerts.
- Commit to Azure per-tenant service accounts (Entra SP) for the full Azure adapter; explicitly call out creation/rotation/deprovisioning and least-privilege scoping as a known challenge with mitigations (automation + secret refs + health checks).
- Plan Alternative F as a pre-approved contingency: if Azure runtime is not feasible in the MVP window, we proceed AWS-only and schedule the Azure adapter as a 4–6 week follow-up, then flip routing via registry flags with no DAG changes.

### Final decision

- Target architecture: G — Thin Airflow + JEL (AWS-hosted). It best supports multi-tenant scale, compute-near-data, and long-term agility.
- MVP in 8 weeks (1 FTE):Deliver Azure-first if feasible (Azure Batch adapter + Airflow thin operators + quotas/reconciler/metrics), and ship the AWS ECS fastpath for the single special ETL.If Azure runtime cannot fit, use F — Azure postponed as the pre-approved contingency: run in AWS, bridge Azure datasets via HTTPS/SAS/staging, then add the Azure adapter as a focused 4–6 week follow-on and flip routing with registry flags—no DAG changes.

#### Scheduled Cron Job Alternatives

We *can* run one DAG on a daily/hourly schedule and then fan-out across tenants in that run:

Pattern A — Sweep & submit

on a daily/hourly schedule and then fan-out across tenants in that run:

Pattern A — Sweep & submit

- DAG scheduled once (e.g., daily at 03:00).
- First task queries JEL’s schedules table (or a view) to compute which tenants should run now in their timezone.
- Use Dynamic Task Mapping to call SubmitExternalJobOperator for each due tenant/job pair, then wait on ExternalJobSensor.
- Respect per-tenant Airflow Pools and JEL quotas to avoid stampedes.

Pros

- All orchestration logic (even per-tenant holiday calendars) can be expressed in Python.
- Deeper in-DAG relationships are easy (e.g., run job A then B for each tenant).

Cons

- Scheduler load: one DAG run now fans out to N tenants → many mapped tasks.
- Timezone & DST logic becomes our problem to be managed (Airflow “timetable” can help, but still code to maintain).
- Retries and jitter are less ergonomic than EventBridge for pure periodic work.

When to choose Airflow-CRON

and jitter are less ergonomic than EventBridge for pure periodic work.

When to choose Airflow-CRON

- We have dependency logic across multiple jobs inside the same tenant-run (true orchestration).
- We want to see the per-tenant run tree inside the Airflow UI.
- We consciously accept scheduler load for a more “in-DAG” experience.

Use EventBridge Scheduler (via JEL) when:

- The job is single-step (submit → wait) and independent per tenant.
- We want ops simplicity, time zone correctness, easy pause/resume, and low latency.
- This includes the pure AWS ECS ETL exception job (daily cron): EB → JEL → ECS RunTask.

Use Airflow schedule when:

- We need multi-step orchestration within the same tenant run (dependencies, branching, retries at step level).
- We need to combine data-driven triggers (Datasets) with time windows.
- When our users prefer run visualization inside Airflow for these flows.

tasets) with time windows.
- When our users prefer run visualization inside Airflow for these flows.

Do not mix for the same job_type
Avoid double-scheduling (Airflow + EB) for the same job_type/tenant, or we will get duplicates. We should select one engine per schedule row (`engine='eventbridge'|'airflow'`) and stick to it.

We will stick with EventBridge + JELfor simplicity.

1. Azure per-tenant service accounts (Entra SP)Risk: Creation, least-privilege scoping, rotation, and de-provisioning across tens→hundreds tenants; secrets hygiene.Mitigation:Automate via IaC (scripted SP creation, role assignment limited to Batch RG).Store only secret references in Postgres; secrets live in AWS Secrets Manager (or Azure Key Vault per policy) with rotation policy.Add a credential health check step in adapter; surface clear 401/403 diagnostics.
2. Status drift / missed eventsRisk: EventBridge or Azure polling gaps cause stale states.Mitigation: Push-based updates and a reconciler that re-describes non-terminal jobs stale >N minutes.
3. Cold starts / queue latencyRisk: Batch pool spin-ups or Fargate image pulls delay SLAs.Mitigation: Keep-warm windows, mixed spot/on-demand, image slimming, regional registries.

delay SLAs.Mitigation: Keep-warm windows, mixed spot/on-demand, image slimming, regional registries.
4. Sizing constraints (AWS Fargate)Risk: Exact 8/64 not supported at 8 vCPU tier.Mitigation: Route those job_types to Batch (EC2) or ECS on EC2; encode in registry.
5. Data-ready contract inconsistenciesRisk: Tenants emit different payloads.Mitigation: Canonical dataset URI & idempotency key conventions; provide a small producer SDK/snippets.
6. Operational single-dev bandwidthRisk: 1 FTE in 8 weeks.Mitigation: Phase scope: AWS-only jobs over public network, AWS ECS fastpath for the exception, shared adapter interface; defer Azure Batch, Databricks & UI.

### Week 3 — EventBridge Scheduler Reconciler (Create, Basic Update, Delete)

Build

- Reconciler service (Lambda or container) that:Reads schedules where engine='eventbridge'.Computes desired EventBridge Schedule spec:Uses ScheduleExpression (convert/keep cron(...)).Sets ScheduleExpressionTimezone from schedules.timezone.Target = API Gateway route /internal/jobs (or /internal/aws-fastpath for one exceptional job), auth = SigV4 using a dedicated invoker role.Payload JSON includes tenant_id, job_type, merged payload, and schedule_context (see Week 4).Creates missing EB schedules; soft-updates minor diffs (cron/tz/target/payload hash); deletes EB schedules not present or disabled in DB.
- State tracking:Store EB schedule ARN and a spec hash back into DB (schedules), so drift can be detected.

## Appendix B — Example Airflow DAG snippet

```
from airflow import DAG
from airflow.utils.dates import days_ago
from my_platform.operators.jobs import SubmitExternalJobOperator, ExternalJobSensor

import days_ago
from my_platform.operators.jobs import SubmitExternalJobOperator, ExternalJobSensor

with DAG(
    "etl_daily_refresh",
    start_date=days_ago(1),
    schedule=None,
    max_active_runs=20,
    catchup=False,
    tags=["etl", "multi-tenant"]
) as dag:
    tenant_id = "{{ dag_run.conf['tenant_id'] }}"
    business_date = "{{ dag_run.conf['business_date'] }}"

    submit = SubmitExternalJobOperator(
        task_id="submit_job",
        job_payload={
            "job_type": "daily_etl_refresh",
            "parameters": {"tenant_id": tenant_id, "business_date": business_date},
            "execution": {"provider": "auto"},
            "tags": {"tenant": tenant_id, "biz_date": business_date}
        },
        pool=f"pool_tenant_{tenant_id}"
    )

    wait = ExternalJobSensor(
        task_id="wait_for_job",
        params={"submit_task_id": "submit_job"},
        mode="reschedule"  # deferrable
    )

    submit >> wait

## Appendix C — Tenant onboarding to Azure (service account)

Per tenant:

1. Create Entra App Registration (service principal) spn-jobs-<tenant>.
2. Assign minimal roles to the Batch Account / Resource Group (e.g., Batch Contributor scoped appropriately).
3. Store client id/secret (or certificate) in AWS Secrets Manager under azure/<tenant>/batch-sp.
4. Add a cloud_credentials record pointing to that secret ref.
5. Add tenant_id with provider='azure' in tenants.
6. Test: POST /v1/jobs with that tenant runs via Azure Batch.

The Remi Agent Suite represents a family of AI assistants embedded throughout the Invent platform. Each assistant is purpose-built to enhance specific layers of decision-making such as analytics, explainability, monitoring, and guided enablement. Together, these capabilities provide contextual intelligence where users work and make decisions.

---

## 1) Remi Analytics

*Previously: Data Q&A Agent*Training Guide → [https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/agenticai/pages/5133402126/Data+Q+A+Chat+Agent+Client+Training+Guide?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiNWI4MTY4OTQxZTQ0NDJmMmE2MmJlMmZlM2VkZTI4YzMiLCJwIjoiYyJ9](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/agenticai/pages/5133402126/Data+Q+A+Chat+Agent+Client+Training+Guide?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiNWI4MTY4OTQxZTQ0NDJmMmE2MmJlMmZlM2VkZTI4YzMiLCJwIjoiYyJ9)

nt+Client+Training+Guide?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiNWI4MTY4OTQxZTQ0NDJmMmE2MmJlMmZlM2VkZTI4YzMiLCJwIjoiYyJ9)

The Remi Analytics capability enables users to explore Replenishment Order data directly through natural-language questions. It operates on the currently visible dataset, allowing non-technical users to filter, summarize, and aggregate metrics such as sales, inventory, and fulfillment rate. It translates business-friendly questions into actionable insights without requiring SQL or BI tools.

Primary Value
Empowers data-driven decision-making through natural-language interaction and no-code analytics.

Use Cases

- Quickly identify top and bottom performers within any product group.
- Investigate category-level inventory or stockout trends.
- Support planners during daily or weekly replenishment reviews.

Examples

- “Which items have the highest excess inventory?”
- “Show replenishment results for store 1024 last week.”

## 2) Remi Reasoning

*Explainability + Guided Resolution + Action Recommendation*

Remi Reasoning provides transparency into how recommended order quantities are generated and why alerts are triggered. It combines factor-level contribution analysis, threshold deviation insights, and AI-supported action recommendations that guide planners to the most appropriate corrective path. The objective is not only to explain whathappened and why, but also to recommend what to do next to correct or optimize outcomes.

### 2.1 RPL Reasoning

d why, but also to recommend what to do next to correct or optimize outcomes.

### 2.1 RPL Reasoning

*Previously: Doctor Why*Training Guide → [https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/agenticai/pages/5569511467/Doctor+Why+Agent+Client+Training+Guide?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiYjRhNGIwZjk3YjFjNDMxNmFhZjJkYWUyMzg2YmEyZWMiLCJwIjoiYyJ9](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/agenticai/pages/5569511467/Doctor+Why+Agent+Client+Training+Guide?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiYjRhNGIwZjk3YjFjNDMxNmFhZjJkYWUyMzg2YmEyZWMiLCJwIjoiYyJ9)

Scope & Positioning
RPL Reasoning interprets recommendation logic at store–item granularity and breaks down each decision into measurable contributing components, including demand forecast, safety stock, presentation minimums, DC/vendor constraints, capacity or packaging restrictions, rule-based adjustments, and business configuration overrides.

Key Functional Outputs

restrictions, rule-based adjustments, and business configuration overrides.

Key Functional Outputs

- Contribution Breakdown: Numeric influence of each factor on the final quantity.
- Decision Rationale Summary: Clear articulation of the inventory logic for the period.
- Behavioral Comparison: Similar item/store comparisons to highlight anomalies.
- Expected vs Actual: Differences between planner expectations and model decision.
- Governance Traceability: Evidence trail supporting audits and compliance.

Action Recommendation
When the model’s rationale indicates suboptimal behavior, RPL Reasoning proposes contextual, data-driven recommendations mapped to accountable personas, for example:

- Review planogram or presentation minimum parameters.
- Reassess vendor lead time estimates.
- Investigate unexpected forecast drivers.
- Evaluate store–SKU eligibility rules.
- Trigger a targeted business rule update.

Use Cases

ivers.
- Evaluate store–SKU eligibility rules.
- Trigger a targeted business rule update.

Use Cases

- Validate replenishment logic.
- Compare expected vs actual model behavior across similar items.
- Support model governance and validation processes.

Example

- “Why did store 1045 receive a quantity of 120 units for this SKU?”

### 2.2 Alert Reasoning

*Previously: Alert Reasoning Agent*Training Guide → [https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/agenticai/pages/5430149416/Alert+Reasoning+Agent+Client+Training+Guide?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiOGI4M2Y5NTUwNDIwNDRkZGI3YzY4N2IwNGVkYWMzYTUiLCJwIjoiYyJ9](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/agenticai/pages/5430149416/Alert+Reasoning+Agent+Client+Training+Guide?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiOGI4M2Y5NTUwNDIwNDRkZGI3YzY4N2IwNGVkYWMzYTUiLCJwIjoiYyJ9)

Scope & Positioning
Alert Reasoning clarifies which KPI triggered an alert, how far the actual value deviated from the acceptable range, and what the root causes are.

Diagnostic Capabilities

ual value deviated from the acceptable range, and what the root causes are.

Diagnostic Capabilities

- KPI Threshold Deviation Quantification: Severity of the breach.
- Multi-factor Root Cause Attribution: Inventory, forecast, parameter, constraint, and related drivers.
- Resolution Path Prioritization: Actions most likely to deliver fast correction.
- Impact Visibility: Stores/SKUs/DCs affected.
- Follow-up Monitoring: Track whether the risk decreases after the resolution.

AI-driven Action Recommendation
The agent recommends guided steps validated by replenishment science, including direct navigation to the appropriate configuration or monitoring pages, for example:

- Review and correct vendor lead times for the affected item.
- Investigate unexpected negative stock events across the listed stores.
- Presentation minimum is driving excess; evaluate lowering the display rule.

Examples

sted stores.
- Presentation minimum is driving excess; evaluate lowering the display rule.

Examples

- “Explain why the alert was triggered for product 100245.”
- “List the main causes behind the ‘target-increased-too-much’ alert.”

*Previously: Daily Digest Agent*Training Guide → [https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/agenticai/pages/5364023297/Daily+Digest+Agent+Client+Training+Guide?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiZDkzMGFhYjQ0MjFlNDFjYzgxMGIzZGNmOGVhYTJhNzIiLCJwIjoiYyJ9](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/agenticai/pages/5364023297/Daily+Digest+Agent+Client+Training+Guide?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiZDkzMGFhYjQ0MjFlNDFjYzgxMGIzZGNmOGVhYTJhNzIiLCJwIjoiYyJ9)

RPL Action Board automatically generates a high-level operational summary each day, combining key performance indicators such as Health Score, Fulfillment Rate, Stockout Rate, Margin Loss, and Overstock Rate into a prioritized narrative. It highlights risks, improvement signals, and growth opportunities to enable proactive monitoring and action planning.

Primary Value
Enables leadership visibility by transforming raw metrics into daily strategic guidance.

Use Cases

- Daily operational briefings or morning stand-ups.
- Identifying emerging risks across divisions or categories.
- Prioritizing performance interventions by impact and urgency.

It dynamically understands where the user is within the platform, the data or component being viewed, and the most relevant documentation or guidance to surface. By combining global knowledge with local context, it delivers personalized, proactive support throughout the product experience.

e with local context, it delivers personalized, proactive support throughout the product experience.

Accelerates onboarding and improves product adoption by making knowledge accessible at the moment of need.

- Provide in-context explanations linked to charts and tables.
- Support self-service onboarding and training.

# 1. Context and Scope

## Surrounding system

Product: A unified scheduling subsystem that allows tenants (and internal platform operations) to define time-based triggers for running registered Jobs (pipelines) without embedding schedule logic into ad‑hoc scripts or external Airflow DAGs. Schedules must be persisted (auditable, queryable, toggleable), multi-tenant aware, idempotent per fire window, and integrated with the Jobs API so that a schedule fire submits a job just like an on-demand request.

Current scheduling implementation:

at a schedule fire submits a job just like an on-demand request.

Current scheduling implementation:

- Single Lambda-based scheduler (cheetah-external-schedules) triggered every 15 minutes via EventBridge
- Polls all schedules from a centralized schedule table in PostgreSQL
- Uses cron-parser to determine if each schedule should fire
- Directly invokes job-specific Lambda functions based on job_namespace and job_name
- No persistent execution history or status tracking beyond scheduled_at timestamp
- Jobs defined across multiple namespaces: forecast, alert, allocation, replenishment, parameter, wrpl, promotion, data, etc.

pain points:
ain points:

- Limited precision: 15-minute polling interval prevents sub-15-minute schedules and causes delays up to 15 minutes
- No execution tracking: Minimal audit trail—only last execution time stored, no success/failure history
- No concurrency control: Cannot limit concurrent executions per schedule or tenant
- Single point of failure: One Lambda processes all schedules; if it fails, all schedules are affected
- No idempotency: Duplicate executions possible if Lambda times out or is invoked multiple times
- Difficult troubleshooting: Limited visibility into why schedules didn't fire or failed
- Scalability concerns: All schedules processed in a single 15-minute window; doesn't scale beyond ~100-200 schedules
- No multi-tenant isolation: All customers' schedules processed together without quotas or rate limiting
- Inflexible scheduling: Cannot easily pause, resume, or temporarily disable individual schedules

ng
- Inflexible scheduling: Cannot easily pause, resume, or temporarily disable individual schedules
- Manual intervention required: No API for CRUD operations—schedules managed directly in database
- No schedule differentiation: Cannot run multiple schedules with different parameters for the same job type

- Per-schedule EventBridge rules (one rule per active schedule) for precise, minute-level cron execution
- Persistent fire history in job_schedule_fires table tracking every attempted execution with status progression
- RESTful Schedule API for CRUD operations (create, read, update, delete, pause, resume schedules)
- Multi-tenant aware with row-level security (RLS) ensuring tenant isolation
- Idempotent execution using unique constraints (schedule_id, planned_for) and idempotency keys for job submission
- Concurrency controls with configurable max_concurrent_runs per schedule
- Two implementation options:Option A: Enhanced standalone system with direct Lambda job execution (2-3 week implementation)Option B: JEL(Job Execution Layer)-integrated hybrid with Jobs API submission for cross-cloud routing (6-8 week implementation)
- Observability with structured logs, CloudWatch metrics, and Datadog integration

- Drift detection via nightly audit Lambda reconciling EventBridge rules with database state
